reviews.review: Small and exquisite. Doesn't have the grandeur of Sulemaniye or the Blue Mosque, but the interior of this mosque has the most exquisite tile work. Its tiny in comparison to its more famous compatriots but that adds to its charm, as you can get up close to the tiles and see the individual brush strokes on each hand-painted masterpiece. This mosque is a little hard to find, in the alleys behind the Spice Bazaar, but ask around and make the effort to visit. You won't regret it

Gorgeous Ceramic Tiles.... This is not a huge mosque, but the ceramic tiles adorn the walls are very special and beautiful. Just fell in love with the colours of the ceramic tiles. It's located in one of the busiest shopping districts of historical downtown area.
Beautiful blues. This mosque is not so well-known, but has exquisite tile work and is definitely worth a visit. Located not far from the ferry points and other better-known mosques.

A place where you forget about everything and just enjoy the moment. The place is surely for praying. But for not muslims it turns into a place to enjoy beauty of accurate paintings, architecture and light play. Try to come here at the sunset to enjoy the orange, velvet and pink shadows on the walls and ceiling that penetrate through the windows... A place for reset and enjoyment...

Interesting. Not the most fascinating or beautiful place we visited when in Istanbul, but a necessary stop historically. It is pretty much a 19th century "palace" - more European than Turkish. But it was interesting, nevertheless.
STOP PRESS. We tried to visit today 7th Sept 2016 and found it closed for renovation ! Bummer. 5 stars given on strength of previous visit.

Visit this mosque if you want to sense how it feels like to walk through a painting!. One of the most impressive and beautiful collections of Ottoman Turkish Iznik tiles anywhere. This is a must-visit mosque if you are in Istanbul. The interior is covered wall-to-wall with the most amazing Iznik tiles, consequently if you stand in the middle of the mosque which is bathed with light coming from all four directions, you will get a taste of how it feels to walk through a painting! The entrance can be a bit tricky to find. The mosque sits above shops, as it has been since the Ottoman times, you will need to go up a flight of steps between the shops from which will get you get the mosque courtyard which then leads to the mosque entrance door. Have fun!!

NEED TO BE SEEN. Rustem Pasha Mosque is one of the oldest mosques in the area,the most interesting thing that if you look at the tiles detailed you will see all is coplately diffrent to comparing with the other mosques,and the atmosphere in there that you feel is very peaceful,that was nice to see such a place

Under serious renovation in Aug 2016. I was really excited to view the tiles here, which my guide book recommended. However, I found the mosque to be under serious renovation in August 2016. Practically every wall was boarded up and unable to be seen by visitors and the prayer space was severely diminished. Save this one for visit at a later date!

Incredible Iznik Tiles at Rustem Pasa Mosque. Although the mosque is currently closed for restoration, it is well worth visiting when it is open. It is decorated throughout with the most amazing panels of Iznik tiles, which you can really appreciate as you can inspect them from up close rather than from a distance as in many other mosques. In my opinion, it is one of the most beautiful sights in Istambul.

Bluer than the blue mosque. This was how our guide described this place. We were not able to get in the blue mosque so we were brought here instead.Entrance is free. Did not look interesting from the outside. It is located near the Spice Market so we had to wait a few minutes for people to get out after the prayer time. We had to leave our shoes outside so make sure to wear socks uf you plan to visit.Felt light and airy inside. The tile work was beautiful.
Neil Williamson . Worth a visit very nice mosque. Popular place to visit especially busy on holy days. Easy to get to close to public transport
A hidden gem. It is very busy near Spice Bazaar, but nearby is this beauty. It is a must for those who enjoy Turkish ceramics.

Closed for works !!. I was in Istanbul during June 2016 and went especially to Eminönü on Monday 22 of June to visit Rüstem Pasa Camii, but unfortunately it was closed for restoration works.A paper on its door was mentioning "closed for works" without any other indication about when it will reopen... (((What a pity! I was so disappointed and sad because I was so eager to visit this awesome historical mosque and see the beautiful blue tiles that cover its walls.

A little gem. In amongst all the large, obvious mosques in Istanbul is this somewhat hidden gem, with it's unique tiles. Not worth a trip specially to see it, but if in the are definitely plan an extra hour to swing by it.

A very good surprise. I wanted to go to this place because I love ottoman history so I needed to know the mosque of Rustem pasha. I thought it was gonna be just another mosque but I really liked it, beautiful and I think it has one of the biggest chandeliers. I also like the places near it, there are many interesting shops.

Beautiful Jewel. One of the nice examples of Sinan's architecture in the heart of the old city. This little Mosque is well known for the huge number of original İznik tiles. The location is fantastic to discover an area with hundreds of local stores and shops, very close to the Spice Bazar.

Closed for restoration. This wasn't easy to find, as the entrances are hidden in the market district. When we did get past the entrance, we were told that it was currently closed for restoration (although a small portion remains open for prayer). We thought as much when we saw the scaffolding!

Hidden Gem, Peaceful Mosque!!. This is a very very beautiful mosque which is somehow not famous among tourists. But I would definitely recommend everyone to go inside and enjoy its peace and calamity. Even more quiet and peaceful than the Blue Mosque.

Currently closed.. We walked around this mosque twice trying to figure out where there was an entrance. Ran into fellow tourists who had done the same. Was quite hoping to see the Iznik ceramic tiles, but alas, the mosque is closed.
Peaceful Mosque. Hidden away in Eminonu, this small yet charming Mosque is somehow sheltered from the hustle and bustle right outside. Beautiful Mosque, would definitely recommend visiting!

A beautiful hidden gem. I don't think many tourists go to see Rusem Pasa Mosque, but they should. I found it to be more peaceful and more beautiful, and certainly less crowded, than the Blue Mosque. It took a bit of doing to find it, but at Rustem Pasa, we were two of about 10 people inside in the afternoon. That includes tourists and people praying. It was wonderful! Not being familiar with mosques, at Rustem Pasa we could really enjoy its beauty and even feel comfortable relaxing to meditate for a bit, which is always welcome in the hustle and bustle of city sightseeing. Here you can get up close to the tile work, see its beauty and the intense color. Definitely worth a visit. Also be sure to support the vendor outside, he was selling postcards and other great yet inexpensive souvenirs. Have a good look at the outside of the mosque, too, great tiles there as well.

Small yet historic with blue tiles. Rustem Pasha was one of the Sultan's popular Commanders, who built this mosque. The number of minarets signify the ranking of the person who built them. This mosque is unique in having one minaret.The building style is the same with multiple domes & good engineering work to convey the voice of muazzen & imam. The use of traditional Blue tiles & each one individually made in a different pattern is amazing & art lovers would love it.You can also buy a little tile of your choice as a souvenir at the entrance of mosque.The mosque is in use & wudhu arrangement is there in order to offer prayers. This mosque has a number of shops attached to it & close to it is the Spice Bazaar .

A mosque paid for by the local shop keepers. This is my favorite mosque a short distance from the Spice Market. If you were facing the Spice Market with the Golden Horn at your back, you would go right a short distance, The Rustem Pasha was built and paid for by the shopkeepers in the neighborhood surrounding the mosque. It has many variations of decorative tiles and is completely accessible. No barriers and fewer people than the Blue Mosque. It is truly a peaceful oasis for reflection and appreciation of this unique architecture. Tip: Shoes off before entering and head scarves for the women.

a beautiful mosque set on the bosphorus. i was meeting up with some friends that wanted to show me this beautiful mosque that isnt like any other mosque i have visited,though it was small it had a high ceiling and large windows to take in the views with beautiful painted interior that didnt even feel i was in a mosque.

A blue jewel. Amazing Mimar Sinan mosque, with the most beautiful blue faience I ever seen.a little bit dificult to find the entrace. The easiest way to get there is from Eminonu. On the right side of the Egiptian Bazar, walk until the Mehmet Efendi Cofee Shop where you turn to the right, then strait ahead until nearby the minaret. The entrace is very small and easy to miss.
My favorite mosque in Istanbul. If you are interested in gorgeous tile, peaceful and happy mosques, decor and simple beauty. This is the mosque for you!

Not to be missed mosque in Istanbul. This mosque has some of the best and most beautiful examples of Iznik tiles in Istanbul. It is easlity accessible as it is just near the spice market and certainly much less crowded than the blue mosque. You can take time there to appreciate the art and become inspired by it. Definitely worth seeing. we were here in August of 2014 but did not post this until now; the visit drop down did not go back to that date.

Absolutely magnificent. This relatively small mosque has beautiful Iznik tiles.Located behind the Spice Market, the narrow steps going up to the entrance are not easy to find unlessyou ask a local business. Definitely a rewarding andvery memorable visits awaits!
Another mosque, not to miss in Istanbul. Comparatively smaller than Sulaimania Mosque, but another piece of art. Beautifully decorated with tiles, not to miss....

Right in the spice bazaar area. This is a lovely mosque open to visitors. Remember Friday's are prayer day so you need to plan your time. Women must wear shirt that has at least three quarter sleeves, pants or skirt down to your shins and head covering. Men must have shirt with sleeves, no muscle shirts. You take your shoes off and place in a bag then into a cubby. The mosque is lovely with beautiful tiles. The mosque has a little park outside with benches. You can people watch, enjoy the fountain, watch the parrots up in the dead tree.

Very beuat. If you ask me, I'd say this was the loveliest mosque we saw in Istanbul. It is not grand but it has the most beautiful iznik tiles and interiors. It is nestled in the Spice Market above street level so you won't find it without a guide or location app. The entrance is obscure but once you get there you enter an oasis of calm and serenity in the middle of this bustling market.

Be sure to look up!. Near the Spice Market, the highlight here are the tiled ceilings. Elaborate masterpieces that make for a nice photograph to take home. Not a whole lot more to see though, and the central part of the floor is blocked off only for Muslims coming to pray.

A remarkable Ottoman jewelry. A refined blend of over 80 models of ceramic Iznic. Perfect proportions and finesse finisafelor recommends it as one of the most elaborate works of the great architect Mimar Sinan.
Small and Beautiful. Not a frequently visited mosque by all the masses but so worth a visit. Hard to find near the spice market but keep looking!....exquisite tiles are the main feature.

Not as visited as the Blue Mosque, but in many ways better. The Rustem Pasha Mosque is near the Spice Market, and it is, like all of the mosques we saw, open to anyone. There is a bench to sit on to take off your shoes, a cubby to store you shoes, scarves to cover your head if you don't have one and a rack with free Qurans in a variety of languages! But all of that is secondary to the inside of the mosque; every inch is covered with Itzak blue ties. Every inch! And the lamps are low so that anyone who wants to sit on the rugs and read and pray can see what they are reading. There is a section that is roped off that is for prayer, and the casual visitor would do well to respect that, but the mosque is completely available to wander through, to take pictures, to touch the tiles. It is intimate. An amazing experience.

Small mosque but beautiful iznic tiled walls & charming.. Rustem Pasha (b.1500 – d.1561) was the grand vizier (chief minister) of Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent. He was married to the Sultan’s favorite and only daughter, Mihrimah. Rustem Pasha mosque is in the straw-mat weavers’ market and adjacent to the Spice Market. The mosque was designed by the famous Ottoman imperial architect, Mimar Sinan, who also designed Suleiman’s own mosque, and the mosques of the sultan’s first son Shezad and daughter Mihrimah.Smaller in size than most others yet very beautiful and charming on the inside with blue iznic tiled walls. Most remarkably it had just a few worshipers and one could move around freely. This mosque is striking in its contrast to the grand Suleymaniye mosque a short distance from it. A little further from the Suleymaniye mosque is the Shezadi mosque. We visited all three mosques in one afternoon within a span of four hours including walking time.
Great place to visit . Amazing archeological building of the old times. Very well maintained place. Nice and clean.Must visit this place. Easy access.

Our favorite Mosque in Istanbul. Small, intimate, and absolutely beautiful, an island of calm within the tumult of the Spice Market/Egyptian Bazaar neighborhood. Like St. Chappelle in Paris, but without any crowds at all.We did a complete 360 of the place before we found the entrance, the innocuous staircase that looks as if it goes nowhere in particular.Without Rick Steves' Istanbul guidebook, would have never even known about this place, much less found it! This is the highlight of the "Back Streets Walk" chapter of that particular book.Sure, a guide can take you right to it, but be a detective, and find it yourself! And if you can't, ask! Part of the fun.

A hidden gem. To be honest I found this mosque by accident. We were lost in the alleys tossed around by the crowd until we reached the area near to the mosque. Found a shop selling cushion covers and table runners and we were invited by the shopowner to the 1st floor for more choice.Looked out the window and realised that the shop is part of the mosque complex or annexed to the mosque. Saw worshippers going about with their affairs. Visiting the mosque is like opening a jewellery box. Beautiful inside out.
Smaller gem from Sinan. Smaller, hidden mosque, but a 'must' to visit for it gorgeous Iznik tiles -- a peaceful oasis in the bustling spice market

Path less travelled. We hired a local guide who chose this Mosque over the Blue Mosque because our time in Istanbul was limited. If you want to avoid the crowds at the Blue Mosque this is an excellent choice. The Iznik tiles here are truly lovely and our guide said more impressive than those of the Blue Mosque.
Great Architecture. Often overlooked but definitely worth a visit. Right next to the Egyptian Bazar so easy to get to. Even if you only have 5 minutes worthwhile.
Lovely Smaller Mosque. Nice, quiet and away from the bustle. Despite the hype around sultanahmet and other mosques, in a way this is our favourite.
A landmark mosque. A landmark mosque and is so magnificent in size and history. Every body can come inside and people can pray 5 times a day. In a very crowded and vibrant area of Istanbul.

More beautiful than the Blue Mosque and less crowded. This place was awesome. There were less people here than at the Blue Mosque so I felt like I had a much better experience. The artwork and architecture was amazing.
Very Beautiful Mosque. This Mosque came to me as a surprise. Very beautiful and very calm atmosphere contrasting from the loud and busy Spice market.
Worth a visit when near Spice Bazaar.. A smaller mosque located at one edge of the Spice Bazaar. Worth seeing different size mosques. Be persistent in searching for the entrance.

Stunning Iznik tiles in beautiful Sinan designed mosque. Rustem Pasha is probably my favourite Istanbul mosque. Tucked away, up hidden steps in the market area, it is a masterpiece of design on a constrained site. The Iznik tiles which adorn it are endlessly fascinating and beautiful.

Most beautiful mosque ever. Have been to many mosques as a tourist, and this one inspired me more than any other. It is small, more intimate, and covered with the most gorgeous Itzik tiles! It is famous for its tiles, and it does not disappoint. Go off the beaten path (it is near the Spice Market) and duck into this sweet mosque. So pretty!

The beauty of Iznik tiles. Well, there are little words needed to explain the beauty of this mosque. The contrast of the colorful Iznik tiles and the lamp light is really breathtaking. The design of tulip patterns are unique and modern! I took some pictures but not many. I just sat on the carpet and was looking the dome and walls of the mosque. . . . This is the place to visit and spend alone. The tile panels of the courtyard is also breathtaking. They sell several souvenirs at the entrance.
Hidden gem!. This Mosque is off the beaten path - a truly hidden gem that takes a little bit of searching to find!

Magnificuent ancient jamii. Rustem pasha is almost hidden within the surrounding shops and bazaars. I could have missed its entrance. You could see it from Eminonu square. Great mosque to visit, full of history. It is almost 500 years old.
Hidden gem . Rustic, hidden gem, with again beautiful architecture. Right near Egyptian bazaar and the Bosphorus cruise pier perfect way to spend the morning

A small but interesting mosque.. Rustem Pasha did not spare expense on the tilework. All of the tiles are excellent examples of the best in Iznik tiles. The mosque sell a nice book on the subject of the tiles used in the construction. Being one of the richest men of the time helped. Not of the scale of the Suleymaniye and other large mosques, but nice all the same.

So Estetic. this mosque is the best building that i ever been...Rustem pasa is the person ( sadrazam) of kanuni sultan suleyman... and he build this with own money...certainly you must see that place in istanbul after Haghia Sophia...
Beutiful. Beautiful Mosque, maybe one of most beautiful in area. Rich history about that and I would say very well spent time. Atmosphere is calming,.

One of my favorites. I stayed in Istanbul for 9 days and visited a number of mosques. This one was one of my favorites. Another of Sinan’s masterworks, it has a rich backstory, which if you love history, please look up. I was it in it for the art. The painting, the tiles, the architecture. Yes, there’s no mosque like the Blue Mosque, but this one rivals in detail and craftsmanship.

A mosque with beautiful tile-work!. This was a mosque associated with three of the most colourful Ottoman characters. Rustem Pasa, the crafty Grand Vizier and son in law of Sultan Suleyman, who commissioned this mosque; Mihrimah Sultan, his wife and the Sultan's daughter, who got this mosque completed after her husband's death and Mimaar Sinan, the master Architect, who designed and got this mosque built. It has exquisite decorations like the marble pulpit and altar, the elephant feet dome bases and the deep blue rich tile work on the walls. This is a small but one of the most artistic mosques of Istanbul.

Average mosque. We visited the place on recommendation from the hotel but didnt necessarily find it unique. We were given the impression that the mosaics and space here were even better than Haagia Sofia but that was not the case in our view. Recommend skipping if on a tight schedule.
Nice small mosque. A small interesting mosque in the marketplace. Many locals (including taxi-drivers) don't know about its existence.

A diamond in the market place. A beautiful mosque truly hidden in the sokaks of the market. I was happy to run into it. Do not be afraid of the stairs. Go up. From its balcoky we could take some beautiful pictures from the market below.

good history and artifacts. As we visited with a group, our group in charge told us a good amount of history. Sometimes we only watch the artwork, but the history and listening to it makes it more interesting

The mosque of the longest serving Vezier of Kanuni. One cannot understand from the modest entrance that this mosque is actually an impressing complex that included a school. The mosque is famous for its blue tiles.

Istanbul's most beautiful mosque - small and exquisite. Tucked away in the maze of streets near the Spice Bazaar is this wonderful mosque built by the great Ottoman architect Sinan in 1560. The walls, both inside and out, are encased in glorious Iznik tiles, many painted in a striking tomato-red hue. It is open to visitors outside of prayer times.

Another Beautiful Mosque. We enjoyed as much as we could and tried our best not to miss any place, but still we missed a lot in Istanbul.
But we didn't miss this beautiful Mosque and we Loved it.
Every Mosque you visit, will find some extra. This Mosque seems like an Old + Modern style of constructions.
Great Massons and great Architect.
Wonderfuuuulllllllllllll

Exquisite and unmissable. Not east to find, tucked away not far from the Spice Bazaar. But well worth the search. The interior is exquisitely decorated with Iznic ceramic tiles - a riot of turquoise, scarlet, cobalt blue, green and white intricate designs. The little mosque is one of the jewels of Istanbul. Great-taking and memorable

Small but beautiful. It was hard to find the entrance as the spice bazaar (well more like a regular bazaar than a spice bazaar) was so crowded and loud. We went up the stairs and there were only a few people praying. Tiles were beautiful and you can buy postcards with photos with tiles from the mosque very cheap.
Nice building. You won't spent a lot of time here but it's a nice decorated place to visit. No entrance fee I believe, so if you're into this a must see.
another unique mosqque. as I mentioned in my other reviews there are some mosques that are unique in Istanbul and you should see. this one is another one.

Intimate and welcoming even on a rainy day. This was the first mosque we visited in Istanbul and by far our favorite. It's right next to the Spice Market and it was surprising to find the mosque completely empty. Rustem pasha is much smaller than the others we visited, and perhaps that's why the typical candelabra style lighting worked so very well. It gave the interior and almost magical feel. If you have time for only one mosque make itbthis one. Tilework is magnificent as well

Lovely smaller mosque. We went here with our tour guide, and it provided a great contrast from the larger mosques. It felt much more like a place where you could pray, vs the larger mosques which were intimidating.Don't miss the tile work here, which I think is called Idzak tile.

A small mosque/ quick visit but BEAUTIFUL!. This is the mosque to visit if you want to see great iznik tile work. As usual with mosques, be mindful of prayer times. As with most mosques in Istanbul, you will be asked to cover your head/shoulders with a scarf (if you are a woman) and possibly you legs if they are bare (men and women) and to remove your shoes, all before you can enter the mosque. This is a smaller mosque, but beautiful.  If I recall correctly, there are certain areas that you can't photograph, so be mindful of that.
quick visit. it is located in the middle of a very crowded markets maze, I tried to get to the main entrance for more than an hour, in vain....

Tricky to find, but worth it!. This mosque is lesser-known than ts Sultanahmet counterparts, but not any less beautiful. Rustem Pasha Camii sits under the shadow of the famous Suleymaniye. Known for its 80 different kinds of wildly-colorful Iznik tiles, the most lavish for a mosque in Istanbul! Worth getting lost for in dodgy alleys and walking around the Grand Bazaar & Spice Market for more than two hours, trying to find an exit. :) It's best for those who want an up close & personal look at these famous Iznik tiles.

Beautiful Mosque. We visited this mosque as part of a day 2 tour recommended by private tours and we were very pleased . This mosque it's interior covered with some of the most exquisite Iznik faience tiles ever produced. We were given opportunity to take pictures and they gave us free gifts including beautiful quoran in both English and arabic

Beautiful Interior. This is a relatively small mosque in Istanbul standard. But the interior is very nice. It is in a busy market area and the entrance is not as prominent as other mosques. But we loved the mosque.

After the Blue Mosque. Before coming to Istanbul a friend mention a must see mosque that is even better than the Blue Mosque. While it took only a bit of effort to find, this mosque is a must see because of the tile work. In my humble opinion, people should be coming to this mosque instead.

Iznik Tile Heaven. Easily passed by while darting through the Spice Bazaar area, be sure to find the entrance to this heavenly mosque among stalls of woolen sweaters and soap and just around the corner from a small fish market (mosques used to be funded by immediately local shops). Once inside you will encounter the most amazing examples of Iznik tiles decorating both the interior and exterior of this wonderful mosque.
small but beautiful. i like this Mosque it does not have many people , you can go at your own pace truly spent quiet time to enjoy in side , love the nice title inside and the window

Beautiful small mosque. This was such a pleasant surprise. This beautiful mosque felt very intimate. We were the only ones there when we visited and the quiet peacefulness was in such contrast with the blue mosque. This is a must see!! It has gorgeous tile work and felt more like you were in an actual working mosque and not just a tourist sight. Worth the confusion trying to find it!

exellent arhitecture. While in Istanbul visit Rustem Pasha Mosque. it is not easy to find, because it`s hidden between shops in Spice bazaar, but it`worth to look for. Blue mosque and Hagia Sophia are also beautiful but Rustem Pasha Mosque is mosat beautiful.

Good side trip. We were in the spice market, then got off looking for the mosque, after getting lost several times and asking directions we found the mosque. Its very small but beautiful, no crowds. I think everyone would enjoy the side tour

Very old historic Mosque. Magnificient Mosque. Guides at this place are very knowledgable and will teach few basics of Islam.You must go to next door Egypt bazar for spices shopping. Relax and sit outside Mosque to enjoy the busy Istanbul. Local trains are the best mode of transport.

Worth a visit. Planned by the imperial architect Sinan in 1489 and built in 1560. Do not trust those who say that it is not worth to walk all the way down here, they do not even know what they are visiting; the mosque is just few steps away from the spice market and it is a wonderful example of ottoman architecture of the classic period, which counts among the Vizir’s mosques and therefore is less impressing than the imperial mosques but nevertheless quite valuable. The Rustem Pasa mosque, in particular, is rather unique since it is built above ground level from where you can look down at the crowed little alleys of the market. It also features, inside, wonderful Iznik blue tiles dating all the way back to the XVI century when Iznik was at the top of its production and the quality is exquisite.

hishamabdullah. There is the most beautiful mosques in IstanbulMostly tight engineeredIt seems that one designer (architect Sinan)Whole beautiful inside and out and easy to access and is located in the area to be you from passing out

a hidden gem!. its situated just behind the fabulous spice bazzar...walking through the market on the outer side of the spice bazzar and you really have to seach for the entrance as all around the area and beside the entrance there is such a massive bundle of goods to see taste wear and buy!... walking in and looking inside it was actually quite different from the rest..the wonderful architecture but slightly different to what i had seen...
Beautiful mosque. Rustem Pasha is a beautiful mosque situated in the Eminonu district by the port. Well worth a visit. Open daily.
the oldest Mousqe in Instabbul. the oldest Mosque in Istanbul, it is really blue inside, very close to Misri Bazar and rounded by hull sale market
Awesome. This is a must place to visit in Istanbul and in Turkey. Great architecture. Beautiful work inside. Non-Friday mornings are a better time to visit. takes about 1 hour to visit.

Very good mosque. This mosque is situated near a huge meeting place in Istanbul: Eminonu square; Galata bridge, Golden Horn and Bosphorus river pier meet here; From outside this mosque has similar view like New Mosque or Sultan Ahmet mosque, it has different architecture inside.Two big and beautiful mosques are situated here: Yeni Camii mosque and Rustem Camii mosque. Spice bazaar is there with good aroma. Sulemaniya mosque is not too far. Galata Tower is visible from here. Beautiful Bosphorus river is also visibleFrom city center it is very very easy to go by public bus or by tram. From airport taxi is the bets transport though a bit expensive, better to take taxi then change it at a metro station and then tram.

Amazing...if you have the time be sure to see this Mosque.. We were fortunate enough to hire a private guide for a week. This was one of our stops...there are so many amazing Mosques it can be a bit overwhelming.My advice in Istanbul is to hire a guide. They can get you around easily, many people do not speak any english...including Taxi drivers. I have no idea how we could have possibly done everything we did without her.Always take a light weight scarf in your handbag...and a pair of foot socks. You MUST cover your head inside the mosques and you MUST remove your shoes. They will hand you a scarf..but everyone else has been wearing it...not something I would recommend. Believe me..you do not want to be barefoot. I took some cheap foot socks and tossed them at the end of the day.

Beautiful Camii. Eminonu experimental stages of the turmoil easily accessible yet very elegant mosque that is easily overlooked. Taking some time off before a new structure of the market fevk noise and leave yourself a unique experience eye-catching tile of the forest...
Beautiful small mosque. We took a tour of this mosque with the Viking Cruise; even though it is small, it fells more intimate and is more beautiful than the Blue Mosque. Definitely worth to visit.

Simply blue.. . I love the simplicity of this mosque. It's full of blue Iznik tiles and we had the place all by ourselves. But what I remembered most about this mosque is the story behind it. Architect Sinan's love is shown in his works. It's not often you see a man build a mosque to show his love..

Gorgeous little mosque, a real gem!. Tucked away along a narrow street next to the Spice Bazar this gem is easy to miss. The tiles inside are truly beautiful and I love that it was not filled with tourists. It is a small mosque but it's decoration with handprinted tiles is truly special and as you enter you truly get to experience this space in a more personal and authentic way than in any of the other mosques I visited while in Istanbul.
it is nice. Nice mosque inside the bazar area. you can pass by but don't plan it if you are not passing by the bazar

Hidden treasure well worth a visit -- beautiful tiles.. This mosque is easily accessed from the area around the Spice Bazaar but many people overlook it. Has beautiful tiles and decor in a more intimate setting than some of the larger mosques.

One of the nicest mosques in Istanbul. Whilst Istanbul has a number of grand mosques, this one is far more modest, and as such is a lot quieter. It's interior style is also a bit different to the other mosques nearby
Wonderful tiles !!!. Tiny but Mimar Sinan's one of the best. İf you love İznik tiles, you have to visit that mosque. Wonderful !!!

Such a gorgeous mosque. Another fine example of Turkish mosque, filled with gorgeous detail and extraordinary light. This mosque was not very crowded, and is an excellent opportunity for a more quiet, contemplative mosque visit.

I have been there before . This is a small mosque situated close to the spice bazaar, but not as close as yeni camii. What makes it unique are the iznic tiles that it is decorated with. I had heard before, but I hadn't seen, that they give away pocket edition of the Quran, translated in English. I have also read people's comments saying that this does not happen any more. But it does. This time, I got lucky myself and I got my free book. A beautiful gift of them to keep and read. Since I am a Christian with no wish to leave my faith, I will stick to the most naive version of their gesture, since this has been happening there for quite a while now and I accept it as a gift

Small, exquisite and not at all crowded. This mosque is near the Spice Bazaar and can be easily visited at this same time. It's small and intimate but the tile work is exquisite. The best of all the mosques we visited in Istanbul. It certainly isn't as large or as imposing as the Blue Mosque or many other close by, but that's what made it such a lovely place to visit. It was raining but we didn't mind removing our shoes because the reward was so high.

See this mosque if you see any. This mosque is much smaller than Blue Mosque or Hagia Sophia, but to me was much more accessible in the sense of being able to understand what it is all about and being very beautifully decorated at the level and in places where visitors can see close up. Sinan Masterpiece. Rustem Pasha Mosque was one of the most special places that we visited in Istanbul. It is a Sinan architectural masterpiece on a much smaller scale than some of his larger mosques. Truly a gem -- intimate scale, exquisite craftsmanship. The Louse Paşa. In an attempt to stop him marrying Princess Mihrimah, the enemies of Rüstem Paşa spread rumours that he was suffering from leprosy. When examined by the court doctors it was discovered he had nothing more contagious than an infestation of lice. His subsequent marriage to the princess gave him privileged power and he amassed a huge fortune, which gave rise to the nickname "Kehle-i-İkbal", the"Louse of Fortune". The mosque is considered to have been built by Mimar Sinan in 1561 but it was damaged by fire in 1660. The dome, mounted on eight pillars, collapsed during an earthquake in 1766. Both the exterior and interior were altered during renovations in the 18thC. A measure of Rüstem Paşa's wealth can be seen by the amazing display of İznik tiles which cover most of the mosques interior. The faience of the İznik craftsmen was at its zenith and the panels include a dazzling assortment of geometric designs and bold, vivid floral patterns using various pigments, including "Armenian Bole". A panel on the left hand side of the entrance gate is the finest abstract example of 16thC art with the tiles being placed asymmetrically .

Interesting and accessible. Very interesting insight into a wonderful museum and its fascinating tiled artwork.It is a real mosque and not as large as some of the others, but possibly the most beautiful.

a small treasure. Tucked away in some small street behind the Spice Bazar and up some steps, you will be amazed by this little gem of a mosque. The blue of the Iznik tiles is amazing.

Rustem pasha, who was one of the grand viziers in 16th century AD known as Turkish century, was the grand vizier and son in law of Suleiman the magnificent known as aslo lawgiver who was the sultan of Ottoman empire for 46 years. Rustem Pasha was the Crotian Janissary and he was educated by Ottoman state and he became the vizier for Ottoman empire in 16th century. He was rasied by Rolexana in a short time as soon as he got married with her daughter, Mihrimah, so he was appointed by grand vizier and became son in law of Ottoman Sultan Suleiman I. He became one of the richest officials during his 13 year duty and he had built a lot of mosques, caravanserails, baths and charity kitchens from his native country Belgrade to İstanbul. He wanted chief architect Sinan built a mosque for him so Rustempasha mosque was built by Sinan very close to Suleymaniye mosque. Rustem pasha mosque is one of the most beautiful mosques in Istanbul in the area of Grand Bazaar. It is located about 200 yards far away from Spice market in Eminönü Square today. It is really worth visiting to see beautiful tiles and wall decorations of interior part of the mosque.

Most beautiful mosque in Istanbul. This mosque makes up for its diminutive size and lack of direct accessibility by offering the most beautiful Iznik tile work you'd see while in Istanbul. This is a functioning mosque so you'll have to wait outside of a prayer service is on. You can visit this mosque enroute to your Bosphorus ferry that departs nearby.
Gem of Eminonu. One of the beautiful mosques where tourist can enter. Do not forget hide your hair, shoulders and knees for the women.
Gorgeous tile work. Beautiful mosque. Much smaller than the other must see mosques in Istanbul. No lines to get in. Very comfortable inside as well.
Hidden in Istanbul. Very worm sharm mosque, hidden in Istanbul, very hard to find entrance. From windows you can see crowdy streets
Smaller but still beautiful.. This is a beautiful mosque which was slightly underwhelming because we saw it the same day we saw the Blue Mosque.

Small and Absolutely Beautiful Do Not Miss It. A Bit of a walk to get there. It took a bit of a walk from our hotel, but perhaps the most lovely mosque of all. It is small, intimate and quiet. The tile work is beautiful, the feeling inside quite affecting.

Great mosques of the empire. Also like this one, I like mosques and history. It is very large also and very interesting to see the internal decorations, how they are maticalously installed and designed and produced.

Tiny but beautiful. Not a classic "tourist attraction" but well worth your time. This mosque is above street level, which makes it seem "hidden" in some sense. Ask for directions, and when you get close, look for a stairway up to the mosque. The tiles in this tiny mosque are spectacular, and make it worth going out of your way to visit. Unlike the more "touristed" mosques, this one doesn't have barriers set up to keep tourists away from parts of the mosque. Keep in mind that if you arrive and someone is praying you should speak softly to avoid disturbing their prayers and avoid walking in front of them while they are praying. You will be asked to leave during formal prayer times, but at other times you are welcome to visit as long as you remove your shoes and dress appropriately. This is one of my favorite small mosques in Istanbul because it is so beautiful and the light coming in at different times of day creates a myriad of peaceful shifting highlights and shadows. Do yourself a favor and visit when you are near the Spice Bazaar/NewMosque/ Galata Bridge area.

Surprisingly quiet, a jewel of Islamic art. One of the three favourite mosques in Istanbul. The entry is almost hidden, it's just a small door giving access to a flight of stairs. The mosque is sopraelevated with respect to the ground. This is really an artistic masterpiece, fully decorated both inside and outside with Iznik ceramic tiles.The place is still in use, so it is well kept. Some of the modern forniture (book cases, shoe rack) is really horrible, but the atmosphere is authentic and the complex is clean and surprisingly not crowded with tourists (it's really close to the New Mosque and the spice bazaar in Eminonu).
Impressed!. Nice place to see. We had visited it several times. We took pictures and enjoyed the space. The visited hours are accommodated. Don't miss it!
nice mosque. different kind of mosque with internal deco and arts... nice view at spectacular area... easy to spot at eminonu area
Tiles of izmit. One most exicitong examples of architecture sinan and best examples of tiles of izmitYes i said if you want to see best examples no way out
Beautiful Mosque on the edge of spice market. Smaller and more accessible than the Blue Mosque and the tiles are stunning! They even gave us each a small english Quran in parting. Worth going
Great view and architecture.. You should visit to get more experience. There are too many foreign people and it is free to enter in.
A jewel of Islamic culture. Just as impressive as the Blue Mosque. Blue Iznik tiles! Built by Sinan! Quiet and contemplative! Worth visiting!
Mosques. This is an architecture of Sinan so that this is such an important place in order to our view. We really loved this territory
full of brilliant blue tiles. Rustem Pasha is a very small mosque on a narrow street behind the Spice Market. Its inside is full of brilliant blue tiles.
beautiful. a must see for beautiful blue and gorgoues light that comes in. a real gem in the city and everyone must come visit it when they get time. take your time and see the beauty.
Beautifully tiled small mosque. This small mosque had exquisite mosaics and was lovely. It was not full of tourists which was also great!
Blue tiles interior.. Being one of the imperial mosques, this building is famous for diversity of blue tiles interior work.
A historical mosque hidden in the spice bazaar.. Hidden gem. Right in the middle of the spice bazaar. Gorgeous, peaceful. My personal favourite out of all the mosques we visited.

Nice off track mosque. This is a mosque which you would normally not come in your itinerary. But if you are at the spice market, do make it a point to go and see it. A few steps away (ask anyone for directions), it holds the old world charm and looks like the time has stood still. There is no rush in this place. Things go by slowly. But the architecture and the motifs are good to see.

Small but beautiful. Certainly worth seeing. Not big, but has one of Istanbul's most beautiful tile decorations. Accesible from Hasırcılar street through a narrow staircase. Also offers pocket versions of Coran and brochures about Islam. It's possible to borrow scarves and mantles on the spot for free.

Jewel of a mosque. This small mosque is easily missed among the glorious giant mosques that adorn Istanbul, but it is well worth a visit. Not far from the Spice Bazaar and the New Mosque (Yeni Camii), it is upstairs from street level and wonderfully quiet and peaceful. Its glory are the wonderful Iznik tiles of the highest quality and endless variety. A place to cherish.

A tiled gem. Finding the entrance is not easy but well worth the effort. The decoration is magnificent and the atmosphere welcoming and calm. You can even pick up a free copy of the Quran at the entrance.

It is a hidden gem in Istanbul. As other reviews say it is the small Blue Mosque. Well worth a visit especially because it is not as crowded as the 'big one' and in my opinion it is a lot more charming. Bit difficult to find, you can miss it easily as the entrance is from a back street of the spice bazar. This surrounding makes it authentic.
Lovely mosque. A wonderful mosque - full of beautiful Iznik tiles. Much smaller than some of the other famous mosques but so worth a visit.
Hidden.... It is hidden in the bazaar and u have no idea how a raw of stairs suddenly leads to a mosque like that!!

Smaller than other mosques and a rare gem. For many people this ends up being their favourite mosque. It doesn't have the grandeur of the more well-known ones, but where it lacks in grandness it compensates in spirituality. The interior design is so detailed it leaves you speechless. Go there and you won't be disappointed! If you only have a short period of time, I would even prioritise this over the Suleimaniyye mosque complex.
Most beautiful and intimate mosque. Small gem tucked away in the spice bazaar. Certainly the best Iznik tile display seen within the area.
Beautiful mosque. A beautiful mosque, close to Galata bridge and the spice bazaar, well worth a visit and look amazing when lit up at night.
Gorgeous. A very elegant mosque. A very sophisticated architecture, decorations and atmosphere. A very considerate tone of blue, which was pleasant.
Hidden gem. Stunning Iznic tiles adorn the interior of this mosque, making it more blue than the Blue Mosque. Less Touristy and not that easy to find, but it was worth seeing.

Peaceful & calm mosque . Small with amazing ceremic blue in the middle of old ottoman bazaar opposite to the eminonu main bus station hundreds meter from new mosque & spice bazaar if you keep wondering in the old bazaar up to reach sulimanye mosque don't miss.Mahmoud Yamani Jordan

Not so well known, totally worth the detour.. Beautiful ceramics. If you liked the Blue mosque, this one will blow you away with the number of beautiful tiles in such a small mosque.It reminds me of the Sainte Chapelle in Paris by its size and details.

Beautiful tiles, but poor light placement. The tiles are a very pretty blue, and the mosque itself isn't too large. However, the poor light placement makes it difficult to truly appreciate the building.

Very Interesting.. Very interesting to see and hear about other faiths and practices. Beautiful inside and free Qurans to take away for those who wish to know more. It was nice to see a smaller mosque rather than the massive queues for the Blue Mosque. Beware, for those of limited mobility the only way in was quite a few narrow steps and also the only WCs available are for men.
pleasant surprise. not so easy to find. Got there by mistake. It's very beautiful. Ceramic tiling on the inside make it special. Typical Byzantine section mosque architecture.

Calm and quiet. A very calm and impressive atmosphere in this mosque. Not to be missed and a good substitute if the Blue Mosque happens to be closed at your visiting time. Great history involved in this very, very old city.
A hidden gem of Istanbul. A hidden gem of Istanbul. Calm and magnificent small mosque. not to be missed when you in Istanbul..

Small and lovely. Kind of out of the way. Small compared to the mosques on the tourist circuit, but that's what makes it nice. If you're also into self discovery or prayer or just some nice silence, you'll like this mosque.
My Favorite Mosque. Even after seeing some of the larger and more well-known mosques, this was my favorite. The tiles were beautiful, and it was much more intimate.

A hidden gem of Istanbul. Great quiet little mosque. You really get a medieval feel from the architecture of this building. If you want to escape the crowds of the Blue Mosque, come here and indulge in all the free literature this hidden gem offers.

Gorgeous and peaceful. This place is worth visiting if you are at Suleymaniye Mosque or at the Spice Market. It is a small mosque but it is very beautiful. The interior decorated with Iznik tiles is really beautiful.
Lovely mosque in the middle of the market . Unexpectedly beautiful mosque with stunning blue tile work hidden within the local bazaar. Definitely worth a visit.

must see. another must see in istanbul, turkey. the interiors have the effect of roman culture. tiles work are very good inside.

Beautiful Mosque. This is a much more intimate mosque than the Blue Mosque, where you can get up close to see the gorgeous blue tiles. Not as busy as the Blue Mosque, an oasis in the sea of humanity outside. I highly recommend a visit.

PEACEFUL... BEAUTIFUL .... The Rustem Pasha Mosque (Built 1561-1563) is near the Spice Market and well worth seeking out. The interior is covered in beautiful floral and geometric Iznik tiles. It is a peaceful place off the tourist track. Go!
An absolute delight. Not too easy to find but well worth the effort. No wonder it was said that Sinan loved this one. The staff was friendly and helpful and I, for one, shall never be bored of that.

MUST see this mosque!. It is in the area of the Spice Market and is well worth a visit. It is not as popular as the Sultanahmet mosques and it is a beauty. I was there when the crowd level was low so it was quiet and peaceful. You will NOT find more exquisite iznik tile anywhere in Istanbul.
beautiful mosque. Smaller mosque than the big and famous ones but it is beautiful, worthy to see it. It is close to New Mosque and Galata Bridge.

Beautiful little mosque!. I love this little mosque, because it so small and peaceful with beautiful tiles and carpet. I prefer visiting mosques like this one as opposed to the touristy Blue Mosque. Only a handful of people were there, not touristy at all. The mosque was so peaceful and serene and is tucked away in an alley with lots of restaurants and shops in the hustle and bustle of Istanbul. Do visit the Blue Mosque because of its fame and grandness, but do not miss this little beauty.

Worth finding. This is a very small mosque that can be hard to find the entrance - it is near the toilets up a flight of stairs . Although this is small it is very ornate and worth a look when you are finished in the spice market
more blue than blue mosque. and just next to spice bazaar...and tiles are amazing there, better than the blue mosque, during the praying time closed, scarfs are avaliable at enntrance

Bluest of blue. A beautiful mosque. Far more blue than the Blue Mosque. A must see when you are next in Istanbul. We saw it on the Topkapi Palace.

Favorite mosque that we visited. The tiles in here were out of this world. I enjoyed looking around this mosque much more than other mosques we visited on the trip. It wasn't very crowded so we really got to look and enjoy all of the beauty of this place. Certainly worth the trip!
The floral mosque. You will be surprised to see the amazing blue tiles covering all the walls inside. All are different and beautiful.

The Rüstem Pasha Mosque was designed by Ottoman imperial architect Mimar Sinan. The Rüstem Pasha Mosque was designed by Ottoman imperial architect Mimar Sinan for the grand vizier Rüstem Pasha (the husband of one of the daughters of Suleiman the Magnificent by Hürrem Sultan (Roxelana), Mihrimah Sultan). Rüstem Pasha died in July 1561 and the mosque was built after his death from around 1561 until 1563.[1] The mosque complex hosts now a religious school.
perfect tiles.... probably the most beautiful iznik/nicea tiles of the whole city are found here in this small mosque...do not miss...

Blue quartz hand painted tiles. Standing atop a narrow stairway, this mosque is small, historical with beautiful tiles. I expected a lot more opulence, beauty... When I visit a monument, it talks to me. I feel a sense of peace engulfing me, even if I'm in a crowd. Maybe because this was built after his death? I don't know...

Amazing time of peacefulness.......... Silence, awe, grandeur, murmurings of prayers from the public. The colors, the architecture, the history, the religion meshing with the each other preserved with such finesse. Gorgeous, Amazing, Serenity, Beautiful, Peaceful place of worship.....

Hidden Gem. This is a quaint Mosque but full of history. There are ushers ho supply you with a scarf and skirt if your attire is not appropriate to enter. There are actually free Qurans outside in English for a little freebie souvenir. Worth stopping by and seeing but be aware. Someone in our group was walking and a pick pocket actually walked by and took his stuff out of his fanny pack which was facing forward. Another person in the group alerted him and he got his stuff back immediately.

Great experience!. I rate it as a second after Gilhane Park in Istanbul. We went there by bus from Kabatas and it was quite a long ride. But the park is totally wirth it especially during Tulip Festival! The territory is very big and well-kept!

Little Jewel by the great architect Sinan. I last visited this rather hard to find Mosque two years after the big Earthquake. It was hard to find as it is situated up stone steps near the Egyptian (Spice) market. It was closed to visitors having sustained damage in the Quake with a few cracked walls. The caretaker came and let us in as he knew the effort we had made to find it. After removing shoes and donning suitable attire we had a good look around. I was so pleased on this trip to find it had been restored. The tiles inside are just beautiful and because it is small it has a special ambiance. The original caretaker has passed on but I was pleased to learn he saw his beloved Mosque restored. This is not a "Great" building but has it's own beauty and calm and well worth the search.

Unbelievable Iznik tiles everywhere. One of the 3-4 must see mosques right next door to the Spice Market. Every surface is covered in exquisite Iznik tiles and you don't need to go on a tour to go see it.

Not big Mosque, but very attractive. This small mosque located near the spice bazaar in Sultan Ahmed area. The mosque is integrated within the souq (market) buildings. The entrance is hidden between the shops, but you can see the Minaret from the square outside the spice Bazaar. You can reach the mosque by taking the staircase to the first floor. The mosque has a very nice collection of Iznic Tiles with a fantastic decorations. Must visit while visiting the area.

Tiles, tiles, tiles. The tile work in this mosque is in itself worth the visit. Every corner has a different display of beautiful Iznik tiles - blue, red, green and white. A dizzying array. The surrounding markets are worth exploring too.

Hidden and quiet!. This mosque is in the middle of the crowds, close to the spice bazaar, but it's entrance is really hidden. It's small but beautiful! And best of all, very quiet!! One of the nicest mosques no doubts

Tucked away but worth a search. I knew this was located near the spice market but walked all around it and still could not find the entrance. The second time, I found a small staircase behind a cherry vendor, and he waved me through to a lovely secluded courtyard, and then I went in to a beautifully tiled small jewel box of a mosque. All those beautiful aqua, white and blue tiles? They're all here, tucked away from the bustle of the busy waterfront street and the market. Well worth the search.

Lovely small mosque. The entrance to the mosque is a bit difficult to find. There is a few stairs to climb to get to the mosque. Once you go up, you will find that this is a very small but a very beautiful mosque. Not more than 10 tourists were there when we went. It was really peaceful and calm. Just like how a mosque should be. Highly recommended.

My Favorite Mosque. After touring the Blue Mosque and Aya Sofia once can think that they have seen enough mosques. However Rustem Pasha is really nicer in many ways than any other mosque. First is it off the beaten track so it is NOT filled with heaps of tourist and tour groups. It is small, quiet and quaint. The big attraction are the stunning blue tiles both inside and outside the mosque. While the blue mosque also has nice tiles the sheer size of the place makes it harder to appreciate them. At Rustem Pasha you can appreciate the tiles close up and without the pressing tourist throngs all around you. It is near the Spice Market at Eminonu. If you are facing the water at the bridge just walk to the left about 7 minutes and it is the first mosque you come to along the water edge. This was my favorite mosque we visited in 3 weeks in Turkey. Don't miss it.

Small and Beautiful. It's nestled among the stalls near the spice market. The tiles are some of the most beautiful I saw in Istanbul. The space is also a beautiful reprieve from the hustlers and bustle just outside its walls.

Out of the way Mosque. It took me forever to find this Mosque, but it was worth the effort. It located near the water as well as the spice market. The red tile in Mosque is supposedly sets it apart from others. It is a small Mosque in comparison to others and not many visitors on the day that I was there.Rindge Leaphart

Lovely blue tiles inside, but very small.. This mosque near the Galata Bridge is quite small but the blue tiles inside are dazzling. While I wouldn't go too far out of my way to see it, mainly because it takes longer to get here and find it (even our taxi driver had no idea where it was) than you spend inside. Admission is free, but women must wear a headscarf( provided free) and men cannot wear shorts without a scarf wrapped around their legs.

This mosque is a (almost hidden) gem. From Eminonu this looks a big mosque but it actually quite small but is built above the shops using the old warehouses of the Spice Bazaar. As a result the entrance is little hard to find and you have to walk up stairs which are hidden amongst the shops to get in the patio. Built in 1561 by the architect, Sinan this little mosque with it's beautiful blue and white tiles is in many ways a miniature of the blue Mosque. A lot smaller but just as beautiful if not more so as the tiles have not faded. A good contrast to the massive mosques most visitors see.Leave your shoes outside (as there are no plastic shopping bags like the other busier mosques) to see the blue tiles and stained glass windows, a beautifully decorated mosque you can get a clear view and photo. This mosque is a gem, don't miss it. I would definitely add this mosque to the top mosques to visit in the city. Also as you are away from the normal tourist track, there is a lot of good affordable local food around the area.

peace and quiet. The mosque can only be reached by steps leading up from the hectic street market below but once up there it is a haven of quiet. The building is by the great 16th century architect Sinan and one of his finest.

Beautiful Spot. One of the prettiest mosques in Istanbul. Near the Egyptian Bazaar, so not out of the way, but a bit complicated to access. It's worth asking for directions, to spend some time with the gorgeous tiles and see the contrast to the far busier, more 'touristy' mosques.

Beautiful mosque - neat and small. It is not very crowded. Less tourists are there unlike blue mosque. All the mosques in Istanbul are in the ottoman structure and looks almost same from outside. The interior was beautiful anyways.

Charming small mosque. You will find true peace and spiritually in this charming small mosque near the Spice Market, in an area of teeming streets, like old Istanbul. It is a great place to think and get away from the hubbub of Istanbul life.

Better than Blue Mosque. A lot smaller but just as beautiful. At least it does not have the smell of a thousand feet inside. It is also peaceful as a house of prayer should be. The blue tiles are beautiful and right on the walls so you can get a clear view (and photo). There are a lot of good, affordable local food around the mosque, not like Sultanahmet. Please don't all rush there; you'll spoil it.

Mimar Sinan at his best!. wonderful! is rather complicated to get there, but lovely (at the entrance you will see a plate)! You have to stroll around the Egyptian Bazaar (Misir Carsi) in Eminonu, but the surroundings are a joy! the entrance is little and you have to walk to a stair to get in the patio, but the mosque itself is a gem! don't miss it!
Little Gem. Loved this little mosque with it's beautiful blue/white tiles, built in the 16th Century.A good contrast to see, as opposed to the massive mosques.

Beautiful smaller mosque. This mosque is a little difficult to find near the Spice Bazaar but the tiles are beautiful and the visit is much more relaxed than the Blue Mosque since there are few visitors. One can even leave the shoes behind outside if one is adventurous (which we were not as we brought plastic shopping bags from other mosques we visited and carried the shoes in to ensure no one took our shoes). I would definitely add this mosque to the top mosques to visit in the city.
Peaceful Mosque. Visiting the Rustem Pasha Mosque early one evening was just lovely - a very peaceful place with exquisite blue tiles.

Nice!. Our tour guide took us here briefly. Wanted us to see what blue tiles REALLY look like!! (The Blue Mosque SHOULD have looked like this, but apparently too many photos have caused fading.)Built by Suliemon the Magnificent's son-in-law.Close to the Egyptian spice bazaar. If you are in the area, I would recommend going to see this.
A Beautiful Mosque. Much smaller and more modest that the Blue Mosque but well worth a visit. Absolutely gorgeous tile work. Adjacent to an interesting shopping are more for locals than tourists.

For lovers of the Iznik tiles. The variety of Iznik tiles that cover the exterior and interior walls educate. Fine testimony of Ottoman craftsmanship.
Scarves and skirts are provided to ladies who forget to tag these times along. Avoid the five daily prayer times; eg. 1pm and 5pm.

Don't miss it!. Of all the mosques we visited in Istanbul, this one left the most memorable impression. It is relatively small when compared to other more famous ones and it is tucked behind the Spice Bazaar in the busy merchant district, so perhaps easy to skip. Although not as famous as other ones, we found it most charming. The story of it is also nice (you'll have to discover it on your own).
Beautiful Mosque with beautiful iznik tiles. Mosque is small but beautiful. Inside of mosque is covered with beautiful iznik tiles which has lots of different patterns. Must visit.

Great Mosque near Eminonu Cruise area. This mosque could be visited if you are near spice bazaar or have reached Eminonu to take the Bhospherous cruise. Nothing great compared to Sulemaniye Mosque but still offers glimpses of the old heritage.

This is a Gem!. Situated above the Spice Market, it is a 16th century jewel - small and perfect. It is as if you walked into a blue Faberge Easter Egg. This is my favorite building in all of Istanbul.

Small exquisite mosque built by Sinan. Built in 1561 by the greatest Ottoman architect, Sinan for the son-in-law of the grand vizier to Suleyman I, this exquisite gem of a mosque is semi-hidden by being raised above the warehouses of the Spice Bazaar. Covered with sheets of glorious Iznik tiles and a startling number of stained glass windows, the beautifully decorated mosque is a riot of patterns, reflected light, and decorations that work together in a strangely harmonious fashion. The almost classical garden outside the mosque in the waiting area adds a calm meditative air to those waiting to enter. This mosque is too often overlooked. For tiles, windows, and beauty of design, this is one of the great mosques of Istanbul.

Beautiful hidden away treasure. Lovely mosque famous for its blue tile interior - very calm and peaceful compared to the major attractions and well worth finding- you have to go up stairs to the lovely courtyard to get in. Remember to dress appropriately.

Beautiful tranquil tiled mosque. Close to Spice Bazaar, upstairs, with cloistered balcony. Inside it is beautifully tiled in blue mainly geometrical and flower designed tiles - quite stunning and so peaceful. Carpeted. Worth the effort to find it.

Exquisite work. Much preferred this small mosque to the Blue Mosque massive structure. Mostly covered with the blue tiles, it appears quite stunning and that is why they say it is bluer than the Blue Mosque. The experience in this edifice is more intimate and we were able to watch the prayer rituals more closely.

In alot of Way The Best in Istambul. Wondered into this Mosque.. while just strolling the streets, from the outside it makes quite an impression. It was not as busy as the Blue Mosque and decided to go in. Not alot of people were at the time and besides admiring the architecture, tapestry and colors.. its a great place to just sit down.. and meditate or pray...

Beautiful Place of Worship. Everyone wants to visit the Blue Mosque while in Istanbul, but the Rustem Pasha is a beautiful alternative that should not be missed. As other reviews have mentioned, you approach the mosque through a small, narrow walkway past a small spice bazaar. Built in 1560, on the wall outside of the mosque is interesting tile work of historical significance. Also available outside of the entryway are a number of free books on Islam in various languages. The inside of the mosque is absolutely stunning. The blue tiling is accented by the gold calligraphy throughout.The dome is absolutely magnificent with a number of different tile patterns throughout.
A well hidden gem. Easy to miss the narrow stone entrance off a busy shopping street, up a stone staircase to the quiet Mosque courtyard. Beautiful tiled interior.

Quaint Mosque for a meditative break. Smaller mosque but not to be missed. Gorgeous blue tile work all throughout is very unique with calligraphy work on done and stained glass. Walk through Spice Bazaar- quick half hour stop on way to other mosques in the area.

Stunning mosque off the beaten track. This beautiful mosque is covered from floor to ceiling in beautiful blue tiles. And it's quiet and away from the crowds. The walk through the backstreets behind the spice bazaar are an attraction unto themselves. I highly recommend taking half a day to explore the backstreets on your way to this gem of a mosque.

Tranquil oasis near the spice market. We were not sure how to reach the mosque, so we asked someone sitting on a stairway near the spice market where we might find it. It turned out to be up that very stairway. We were the only people there when we visited and found it charming. It is small and intimate, unlike the Blue Mosque, so the lovely tiles seem more vibrant. Glad we were able to see it.
Better than Blue mosque!. Uncrowned, beautiful mosque decorated with the blue Iznik tiles that are also found in the Blue mosque. A real gem!

Small mosque with beautiful interior. There's a very lively local market outside of the mosque, which has so much flavours and varieties. It's within a stone's throw from the Egyptian bazaar, which to us was more like a tourist trap. Not many tourists come here, but there was no issue with communicating with shop keepers and others.

Hidden Jewel. Located just inside the bustling Spice bazaar, its very peaceful, quiet and beautiful inside. Much smaller in size than the Blue Mosque, but just as grand. A definite must-visit destination in Istanbul.

Time Stands Still. This Mosque is a step back in time, when we visited we were the only group of about 4 people, I found the place atmospheric but tinged with sadness, I remember looking through a window onto a courtyard, the sight before me had not changed in many centuries, I loved the quality & workmanship on the doors well worth a visit.

Bluer than the Blue Mosque!. This mosque makes for a perfect combination with a visit to the Spice Bazaar, located just across the street. The mosque has a cordoned off section where visitors can observe the actual prayers going on, (of course appropriate clothing is required to enter) and the architecture and tiles are beautiful. My friend and I observed the entire prayer session which was very powerful and peaceful. Less visited than the other more famous Istanbul landmarks but a must-see and very authentic.

A small gem. If I returned to Istanbul, I would skip the Blue Mosque and go straight to this one. A small gem that is truly blue, not crowded and just peaceful, especially after walking through the Egyptian spice market

A little gem away from the main sites.. Although this mosque does make it onto every ones list of places to visit and is not as grand to look at from the outside it is really beautiful inside with an amazing variety of blue tiles all around.

If you like Iznik tiles.... If you like or love these blue tiles, it's worth it. Some people call it a hidden gem but it is surprisingly full of tourists to be truly hidden. ;) The tiles are fantastic.
Magnificent. A must see place, for prayer or to admire the architecture, among the nicest mosques in Istanbul, go before sunset
Nice visit. It is breathtakingly beautiful, but it is not a huge mosque. It is definitely worth a visit. Remember to bring a scarf to cover your hair if you're a woman. And don't wear shorts.

Must visit Mosque in Istanbul. This mosque is a hidden gem in Istanbul. Its not as crowded as blue mosque and the regular tourist crowd do not come here as it is not in the must visit places. It is as beautiful as blue mosque and so peaceful. we could click some beautiful pictures inside . Detailing inside is so pretty and since it is not crowded we could go and check some of the beautiful tiles and mosaic art. If you in Istanbul, Please make sometime for this beautiful mosque . you will not regret it .
Could not visit it, at any time.. We tried, but could not enter. Then we were told in our hotel that the current Iman don't want any visitors, only male Muslims during prayer time.
Nice Place. This is one of the nicely built mosques amongst the many mosque's in Istanbul. There is generally no queue to visit this mosque.

beautiful mosque. really loved this mosque, right by the water. we enjoyed spending time here just drinking in the atmosphere, before having a coffee at a bar outside. really beautiful tiles on the walls and a great sense of history. lovely

A hidden gem!. Much more beautiful interior than the blue Mosque. Please do visit. Close to the Egyptian bazaar and we did this attraction on the same day as the Bosphorus tour with a tour guide. Loved this little hidden gem and it's gorgeous interior. Feels so calm inside. Not worth missing!Also, try the local delights from a bakery just outside the entrance to the Mosque.

A slightly different mosque. After all the Mosques you'll get to see in Istanbul - the Blue Mosque, the Suleyemaniye Mosque, New Mosque and others it might seem a little strange to wend your way to this far smaller place of worship.So why do so many people do it (apart from the fact that it is featured in such works as the Lonely Planet Pocket Guide to Istanbul which describes it as a 'gem')?Well mainly because it has some very pleasing tile work. And because it is on a more human scale. It is truly a different feeling to be in a mosque that doesn't see thousands of visitors every day. There will be locals around, the entrance is up a somewhat dank staircase, the whole place isn't festooned with annoying carpet salesmen (double bonus!) and all told it is a far quirkier vibe to visit this place than some of the other big name attractions.If you are in the Eminonu area to see, for example, New Mosque and the Spice Bazar or plan to walk over the Galata Bridge to see the tower of the same name then if you have the time to spare to find this place it will give you a different experience to the other Mosques.Recommended for its difference as opposed to its grandeur.

Go for the location. It does have many beautiful tiles to see but I really liked being in this area where the locals shop. Lots of party stores and food/grocery shops with cheaper prices than the tourist area. Bring a compass in case you get lost; notice where you started. Just ask a souvenir shopkeeper for help if you're totally confounded.
beautiful. This is well worth a visit for the tile work. Its stunning on the inside and I loved spending time in this masterpiece.

Hidden gem. Not many turists in this small but amazingly beautiful mosque. It is near to the spice market, elevated to make it less noisy vs the market, this is truly my favourite mosque in Istanbul! Beautiful ceramics and magic atmosphere

Worth a visit. This mosque is my top of the things to visit in Istanbul, and I wasn't mistaken. There weren't too many visitors so we don't feel so crowded in. This allows us to really take our time to appreciate the beautiful design on this mosque. They even have free translated Quran I can take home for a nice souvenir for my elderly at home.

Somewhere special. This little mosque is very special. Set just above and behind the spice market, it was built by a wealthy man many, many years ago and has only one minaret as he didn't want to upstage the Sultan and his newly built Suleymaniye mosque. The interior is decorated with 16 century Izmir tiles. I had a very special interaction with a Moslem lady here, who saw us westerners (my daughter and I ) taking our shoes off and donning our scarves, and who volunteered to explain the mosque's interior features to us. We then held hands - women across different cultures, coming together for a moment of quiet communion, thinking thoughts of peace. Wonderful.

Beautiful to the smallest detail. Grandeur usually implies great size, but Rustem Pasha's grandeur derives instead from exquisite beauty. It's beautiful when looking at the whole interior, when looking at specific features, all the way down to individual tiles. You can enjoy it peace, too, as only a handful of tourists are there at any time. Make sure you see it when the sun is shining.Unlike other Istanbul mosques high on the priority list, this one is not only small, but tricky to locate. Walk west on the main passageway through the Spice Market, and about 200 meters further on the right, look for a simple doorway leading to stairs to the second floor. If you go to the Spice Market, the New Mosque or the Galata Bridge, make sure you walk a little further to Rustem Pasha.

A beautiful Place. Found this mosque much smaller than the famous Blue Mosque but love the serenity of the place. Th blue mosaic tiles were a delight to behold and I left the place feeling gratified to have seen it.

Beautiful tilework. The mosque is very conveniently located at the edge of the Spice Bazaar, making it easy to get to. The tiles used in this mosque are really the best in terms of design - superb detail, intricacy and use of colors. The little stall set up outside the mosque had some very nice souvenirs for friends back home or just a memento of having been there. Not much of a view from outside the mosque itself but wander downstairs and watch the "happenings" around.
Beautiful. Beautiful old building. Very nice!! Two cultures together in one. But be quick, go early in the morning there, because there are too many people who want to see this beautiful

Bluer than the Blue Mosque. A real gem, quiet and peaceful in the midst of the crowds, amazing tiles, prettiest mosque ever, dating back to the 16th century, built by Sinan the Great, Ottoman equivalent of Michelangelo

An oasis of calm in the midst of a busy local area. At the bottom of Uzunçarşı Caddesi ("Longmarket Street") is a two storey stone building with a small arched doorway. This is the doorway to stairs that lead to the Rüstem Paşa Mosque. This hidden gem is very easy to miss, because it does not have any imposing entrance, and is actually on the second floor of a structure with its street-level space occupied by shops.We climbed the stairs and arrived at the mosque. The mosque was commissioned by Suleyman’s Grand Vizier and son-in-law Rustem Pasa and was built in 1561. No entry fee is required. The façade of the mosque was covered with lovely Iznik tiles, but were in many places cracked and needing repair/restoration. The interior was amazing – covered from top to bottom with dazzling Iznik tiles with floral designs and patterns. There were just two other people when we were there, so it was very quiet - it seems this is a mosque for locals not tourists. It felt more intimate and was certainly an oasis of calm in the midst of a busy bustling area.

Amazing tiles and wonderful history. From the second you walk in to this mosque the blue tile hits you.. It's beauty is extraordinary. The history of this mosque only adds to the experience. Once you've visited the Blue Mosque and here you'll think they called the wrong one blue

Great break from the spice market. As you walk through the never ending spice market, the site of this beautiful mosque is a relief fromthe hustle and bustle of the market. As you calm your nerves in its serene environment, you are then ready to re-enter the battle that is the market.

A hidden gem!. Such a delightful and beautiful place to visit. Seems more spiritual than the big mosques. It is much less crowded, although it is plenty big, and the tiles are AMAZING! Go and see it, definitely worth the adventure since it is a bit off the beaten track!

Good to Combine With Other Mosques in Area. This mosque is tucked away near the Spice Bazaar, and we really enjoyed visiting it along with the New Mosque (in front of Spice Bazaar), and the mosque of Suleiman the Magnificent on the hill above. Quite a nice trio of architectural wonders that are not as crowded as the Blue Mosque, and therefore much more pleasant. Rustem Pasha is another Sinan project, and is a bit hard to find as it is smaller and less prominent in its location among the small streets behind the Spice Bazaar. The usual requirements for visiting, no shoes, heads covered for women, also apply here.
Better than Blue Mosque!. Although the Blue Mosque attracts most of the attention, this far smaller building deserves a visit. It is exquisite in its proportions and the beauty of its tiles.

Most beautiful mosque. It is much calmer than Blue Mosque and awat rrom crowds.Amazing architecture.A must see from Mimar Sinan.Enjoy a walk around the mosque in the little streets -Tahtakale- and go to Valide Han which is very close.

It is incredible and magnifique!. It is incredible and magnifique! Mimar Sinan at his best! Do not miss it! Is rather complicated to get there, but it worth it! You will love it! A tiny, beautiful, unassuming mosque just a little out of the way from the much larger and more famous mosques. After visiting many very beautiful and amazing mosques, Rustem Pasha mosque is just nice. Make the effort only if you are around the area and very much interested in seeing different architects of mosques.

Beautiful mosque with a relaxing atmosphere. The Rustem Pasha Mosque was a bit hard to access. We had to wind through some narrow alleyways to find the entrance but the trouble was worth it. The interior of the mosque is very beautiful and also very blue. It is a small mosque so there were far less people that in the Blue Mosque. We could sit inside and listen to the sound of people praying. It was a very relaxing and soothing experience. I highly recommend it if you are at the Spice Bazaar and have a few minutes to spare.
Hidden gem. This small mosque next to the Spice Bazaar is worth a quick visit. It has exquisite tiling. It is upstairs from several alley ways and can be hard to find but well worth the effort.

Glorious small mosque with Iznik tiles. Find your way to this little mosque by architect Sinan for close up views of Iznik tiles. It is beautifully intimate, in comparison to the grandeur of many of Istanbul's other mosques. As a bonus, there is excellent baklava just near the entrance steps at Develi Baklava - try the katmer!
