Art, history and life. The mosque is beautiful. Listening to the call to prayer amidst the crowd was soothing. The square is great for people watching. Plus, after the prayer, you can visit, shop, and eat at the Spice Bazaar.

Beautifull Mosque. This was my favourite mosque, it had an olde world charm about it. The ceramic tiles were gorgeous.
You can buy nice little souvenirs outside.

Smaller Mosque but still worth it. Tucked in the middle of the hectic port area is Rustem Pasha - far smaller than any of the mosques we'd seen but worth visiting (feels more intimate as it's not as grand as the others). Again shoes must be removed before going inside and they do not have bag dispensers so bring your own. per usual, women must wear scarves on their heads. It was probably one of our favorite mosques.

Spiritual place with history. I loved the architect of the mosque, the design of the walls and the history of the building.The mosque looks like some other mosques in the city, it is not huge like Sulimaneya Mosque, did not have big garden to relax in, you can sit and pray if you wish.

More blue than the blue mosque. Visit Sultanahmet Mosque (aka The Blue Mosque) first. Then behold the vivid blue of Rustem Pasha Mosque. It is small in comparison but more beautiful by an order of magnitude.

Hidden Gem!. Thanks to our hotel staff, we found out about this beautiful mosque. It is an amazing little mosque just by the spice bazaar. Thousands of beautiful handmade tiles will stun you as soon as you walk in. Probably the most beautiful mosque in Istanbul.

Simple and elegant. While Istanbul is filled with its share of mosques, what makes Rustem Pasha so worthy is the fact that the mosque unlike others is not crowded yet offers everything that other mosques offer, Beautiful artwork, serenity and the location is perfect for an after visit relaxation with its bazaar and the ambiance. The mosque is an active worship center and it is advised to be dressed accordingly when you visit it. It is one of the mosques that you can visit peacefully and take your time to enjoy

Hidden Gem of Istanbul. My wife and I visited in June of 2014. Rustem Pasha was on one of the tours we took about the city of Istanbul. It turned into one of the most beautiful sites we visited. The exterior is only ok to see, but the inside rivaled the other places of worship we'd visited. The blue-tiled interior may be smaller than its larger brothers the Blue Mosque and Suleyman Mosque, but this one is less traveled by tourists and you just get lost in staring at the elegant tile work. We enjoyed it so much, we ended up going back and touring a 2nd time. Couldn't recommend it high enough.

Impressive collection of Iznik tiles. The interior of the Rustem Pasha Cami is lined with beautiful Iznik tiles that capture one's attention for a long time. What's lovely about this place is that it is a small mosque, not crowded with tourists, and you can spend a long time here to admire the beautiful works. This is a must-go, and after the visit, you can check out the local market or head on to the Spice Bazaar, not far from the mosque.
Excellent Islamic arcticture. The design and lay out of the mosque is similar to the other Istanbul mosques but the area is unique in nice neighborhood

Beautiful not so touristy mosque.. When I visited, although it was easy to see from the square near it, etc, I didn't find it's entrance that quickly quickly. I had to ask. The one I found was right behind a kebab restaurant. Although not as grand, touristy as the Blue Mosque, I found the mosque quite charming. I personally loved it. Maybe, because I have always loved islamic design/art and beautiful tile work and this place definitely had gorgeous bold tiles adorning it. Swoon. Personally, one of my favorites. When I visited, there was only one other tourist already there. And only another entered after me. The guards that monitor the place are very nice.

Astonishing. I'd say this is the most beautiful mosque in Istanbul. There are really quite a few mosque worth visiting in Istanbul, but this small mosque with amazing tilework (Iznik blue tiles) has a special charm and beauty. Definitely a must see!

Small Gem Near the Spice Market. Take a few minutes to find one of the staircases that lead up to the mosque level. The beautiful tiles that adorn the facade hint at the lovely interior--classic Ottoman tiled walls in blue and white, with splashes of other colors to highlight the floral designs. This small mosque was designed by Sinan, the master architect who also designed Sulemaniye. It's easy to miss, tucked into the shops along the road bordering the Golden Horn. Just look for the small dome with a single minaret.

Most beautiful Mosque in Istanbul!. This is a small mosque right beside the Spice Market, and I think it is prettier than the Blue Mosque, more serene, and it is much less crowded as well. The tiles are absolutely beautiful! Well worth a visit.

Small mosque covered in Iznik tiles. A small mosque near to Spice bazaar. Can be missed easily if one does not know it exists. One has to climb a staircase up to reach the mosque. The entrance to the staircase looks like you are going to a private property, there is a small sign with the mosque name on it on the wall, just pay attention. When you reach the mosque, enter through the visitor's entrance. Shoes off and women need to cover their body, including hair. There is almost no crowd here, only the locals who come and pray. I took a few photos there and it took less than 5 minutes for the visit.

NICE. The stories were interesting. It is a serene blue and white tiled mosque. Not much to see though and unless the guide is with you to regale you with stories of Rustam Pash, you may find it a little boring

nice for a quick peek along the way. One of the lesser visited mosques, therefore you can appreciate the tiles and the ceiling better than in the main tourist magnets. Easy to combine with a visit to the spice market (Egyptian).

Just one of many. It is nice Mosque but not in top 10 to visit while stayin in Istanbul. I took time to visit this Mosque in winter 2014 and it was worth visitng, but in the end, is there anything not worth visiting for a traveller ?

Really beautiful Mosque in Istanbul. It's a must visit in Istanbul. Very beautiful Mosque built by famous Ottoman architect Mimar Sinan for a Grand Vizier Rustem Pasha. Mosque have a very impressive interior with very beautiful tiles. Very near you can get also to Egyptian spice bazaar which is 1km away.

Intimate,beautiful mosque. Like a sultanahmet mosque in smaller version this is a lovely and intimate small mosque. Nice addition to it that at mosque they provide plenty of brochures about muslim religion from which you can find some intresting facts which are non-muslims unknown and intresting to read. I really enjoyed my time in this beautiful small mosque which is for sure wort visiting.
A hidden gem. Hidden away - accessed by steps from one of the side streets near the spice market (get directions or a good map) - impressive tiles interior.
Beautiful Blue Tiled Mosque. The Rustem Pasha mosque has one of the most beautiful interiors, adorned with beautiful blue tiles. It is a small treasure.

Do Not Miss this for the Tile Work!. A must-visit mosque for the incredibly gorgeous tilework! It's not far from the spice bazaar, so definitely do not miss it. When I went I was one of a handful of people; quiet and peaceful and very stunning.

Visit for the tiles . While tge mosque itself is relatively modest compared to others in Istanbul, the tilework in this mosque is stunning and what makes it worth a visit. Moreover, we had the place virtually to ourselves when we visited. This allowed us to see another side of Istanbul, and the surrounding market area is really fun to explore.
Small but beatiful. Small mosque not far from spice bazzar and beatiful that you must visit if you are in Istanbul nice decorate just behind the spice bazzar

Love this mosque and the tile. I came here right after Suleyman Mosque. To get here from the shopping streets you have to go into small little dark stair cases that say "Rustem Pasha Cami". There are several entrances and you can't really see where they go, but they do go up above the street level and into the light! The mosque is really lovely - I like the ones with all the decoration and so I give this a 5 because of all the tile and painting. It is not as large as Suleyman or as scenic, but more intimate. Since there were hardly any people inside, it felt quite personal. There was an interesting piece of black and white motif above the entrance door (on the inside). Sort of like a maze. I asked the man in attendance and he looked through some books, but did not find a picture. or it's meaning. He guessed it said Allah forwards and backwards (why not?), and I was grateful for his effort. I would definitely go back.
Beautiful Mosque. This mosque is beautiful with it's blue, white, and red colored titles on the wall. This is a must see.

Nice to see, hidden and small. This is a small mosque, wich you have to look for thoroughly in between the spicemarket/bazaarshops. When you have found the entrance it's nice to take the effort to take off your shoes and look around. It'll only take you a few minutes. I like it that the mosque is low key and still in daily use.. (So please be respectfull and quiet)
Beautiful peaceful quiet... Tricky side lane access. Well worth visiting for peaceful escape from the busy market. Exquisite tile interior. Very quiet and wonderful mosque.

More Blue and More Beautiful than Blue Mosque. Very small hidden Mosque some where near the Egyptian(Spice) Bazaar. More impressive blue tiles and very serene and peaceful . No crowds so you can just take it all in. Definitely not to be missed if in Istanbul.

Iznik at its best by the Grand Bazaar. Often overlooked this beautiful mosque has recently undergone restoration and is renowned for the beauty and importance of the Iznik tiles used in its decoration. Drop in for some peace and quiet after visiting the Grand Bazaar and don't forget to walk round the side to Rustem Pasha's Hamam, which is now a furniture warehouse - superb marble interiors on four floors.

Absolutely Beautiful Mosque--Must See!. Sure. You're a tourist. They told you to go to the Blue Mosque and Aya Sofya, maybe to Yeni Cami. But this mosque needs to be on your list as well.It is probably one of the most beautiful mosques in the world, and the tiles--so historic and gorgeous--must be seen. Read up on tile work before you got, just so that you can appreciate the craftsmanship that went into this mosque's construction. Getting there is a bit difficult: you have to go through the Spice Bazaar, and then through the back entrance down a street, and up a couple stairs. Ask along the way--it's definitely worth the extra effort.
excellent tiles. i guess the most beautiful mosque in istanbul with tulip designed tiles, from 16 th century by the master arcitect sinan, very close to spice bazaar market too
Great example of iznik tiles. A fabulous place to see ottoman design iznik tiles up close. Smaller but much less crowded than the blue mosque.

"Bluer" than the Blue Mosque. Visited after seeing the Blue Mosque - in heavy snow!Rustem Pscha is near the Spice Raker and not easy to find (up sme steps through a small entrance off narrow busy market street)Very quiet and more impressively blue than the more popular Blue Mosque.Would recommend asking the way from the Spoce Market - it's worth it!

Typical Iznik. Small size mosque (comparing to othes), not so known and a bit difficult to find (near Yeni Mosque, just ask a local to point you the entrance) but it's very beautiful because it is covered all with blue iznik tiles.

Hard to Find. This was the first mosque we went to - definitely see before the bigger mosques in Istanbul otherwise it may be a bit disappointing. But if you start in the spice bazaar, as we did, it's close and worth a stop. It was hard to find; we passed the door the first time. It's just a cement hole in the wall, and there was a man selling prayer bead necklaces outside the door (he may always be there?). Go up the stairs. It was nice, quiet, and no crowds.

Small, not much people, but very beautiful tiles. May be you should have a little difficulty in finding it, Nevertheless is just a few steps from the spice bazaar in a street paralel of the sea, in the middle of two street shops. Don´t be afraid of the entrance and go ahead. Perhaps, like me, you are the only one ther. But take your time and enjoy the excellente and beautiful tiles in the calm interior.

Little Gem. Sort of like the Istanbul counterpart of the Parisian St. Chapelle.
Small mosque but it is where you can see the best tiles ever, anywhere.

Beautiful, small and calm!. We came here while the mosque was closed and the security advised us to come back in 25 minutes, so we went for a coffee quickly. When we came back the mosque was still closed, so we sat in the courtyard for a little while and waited- it's such a calm and quiet place, just above the hustle and bustle of the market. When the mosque reopened, we were shown the way in by very friendly staff. It's much smaller than other nearby mosques, however the tiled walls are beautiful and I would highly recommend going here. The interior is just stunning.

A hidden gem. This beautiful small mosque can be a little hard to find. There are just doorways (but with a decent sign) on the SW and SE corners with apparently nothing other than stone staircases leading upwards. You are in the right place. (The market area here is west of the Spice Bazaar and sells e.g. hardware, wooden utensils etc). https://www.google.co.uk/maps/@41.0178008,28.9687851,150m/data=!3m1!1e3. it may also help to walk to an open car park or square on the south side of the main road, look for the roof of the Mosque, and then just walk towards it. Once inside the proportions are delightful, as is the tile and other workmanship. Some handy history here http://www.turkeytravelplanner.com/go/Istanbul/Sights/GoldenHorn/rustempasa.html

Beautiful mosque. Blue mosque or the sulaymaniye mosque all has its own charm but this particular mosque remains my favourite. Maybe its because this one was less crowded and gave me much better chance of seeing and exploring. The entrance is tricky and there is a bit of climb but set and camouflaged in a market, this mosque is no lesser than the other famous mosques whether in terms of architecture of the beautiful artworks around

Ottoman and beautiful. The mosque is especially nice inside and does not show much from the outside. The Iznik ceramic tiles are mostly authentic. Photographers will definitely enjoy their visit here.

Smaller and very interesting. If you are into ottoman architecture this one is special . It was built over a shopping complex back in the 1500;s deliberately so the rentals from the shops could support the complex of the mosque . It has the most beautiful tiles decorating it and if you like art they are really interesting to see. It is not as busy as the other more famous mosques so will be more pleasant to visit.
Great place. This was absolutely one of the most amazing place in Istanbul we visited. Just come and hear about many great stories about it and enjoy the best atmosphere ever.

“GREAT PLACE”. This mosque may be underwhelming when compared to other mosques but it is beautiful nonetheless. The design of the mosque by the famed architect, Mimar Sinan is truly inspiring in its modesty and simplicity. Unlike any other mosque, it is perched on top of a neighbourhood and one has to take the staircase to reach the entrance
Beautiful. Hidden in the corner of the market, you might not find the entrance right away -it's upstairs! But it's definitely worth the visit thanks to the peace you'll breath ad the fantastic tales.

A must visit mosque in Istanbul, Turkey. Rustem Pasha was a great general & this is another must see mosque. We walked from the Ambassador Hotel near the blue mosque. Along the way we experienced great local shops & foods which were wonderful & very inexpensive. Definitely must eat in the local street-side restaurants next to the mosque at a fraction of the cost of the main tourist areas.

Small but beautiful. This mosque is not huge but its inside is very beautiful. You will find lots of Iznik tiles and patterns on the walls. I am not into tiles but I really liked seeing this art.
If you are around the area I recommend spending 10minutes of your time to go inside. Outside you can buy smal souvenir-tiles for yourself.

Not a must go. Rustem Pasha mosque is not must go if you have visited the blue mosque. It's just a smaller version of the latter. You can skip that if you are on a short trip. You wouldn't be missing out.
Nice. I really enjoyed our visit to this mosque, it's special in some way. It was really calming just to sit there.

Tricky to find, but well worth it.. I loved this mosque. I was determined to see it this visit to Istanbul and had read favourable reviews about it here and elsewhere. We were in Istanbul for 5 days and could see this mosque in the distance, but when you are closer it is difficult to find. I had read that it was on the first floor and there are commercial businesses on the ground floor, so I kept digging around the market (it is just next to the Spice Bazaar or Egyptian Market) and the shops for a sign. I could not find anything in the hustle & bustle. We came across a staircase leading up through an open doorway and thought we would follow it. Up through the ancient stone stairwell it opens to the mosque and surrounds. It is quiet, even in the open areas around the mosque, the cacophony that is constantly with you in Istanbul, is dulled down and is a quiet soundtrack in the background. There is no one around, except for the curator who offeres you head scarves and shows you where to store your shoes.The inside is exquisite, the colours are bright and vibrant (has recently been restored). Inside it is so quiet. There is only 5 other people inside the mosque, with us being the only tourists. I loved the smaller size of this mosque, although it is no less impressive than the Blue mosque. Visit here, it is well worth the trouble of finding the stairs, and you don't feel pressured or rushed as you take in the beauty of the carpets, chandeliers, carvings, windows, and other fittings inside. A quiet and respectful place for reflection, where you are made to feel welcomed. My favourite mosque in Istanbul.

Probably my favorite in Istanbul . All the other mosques like Hagia and the blue mosque get all the press but this little mosque next to the spice bazaar is such a little oasis amidst the bustle that is the bazaar. My wife and I were the only two people inside it when we visited and it was such a calming and wonderful experience to just sit and appreciate the beauty of it all. Compared to the other larger mosques, I didn't feel like I was packed in tight with hundreds of other visitors, it ended up being a very unique experience I won't soon forget. Definite must go!

in my view -- The Number One Mosque to visit. The big Mosques (the Blue, the New) get all the press, but this small, intimate mosque is a true treasure to visit. The tiles are exquisite and the proportions perfect. Do. Not. Miss.Our guide Serif Yenen took us here -- a special visit.
beautiful tiles. Very nice, little, quite and enchanting! The entrance may be a little hard to find but it's the stairs up behind the kebap-shop!

Must visit in the Spice bazaar. What a gem, worth searching out thus away from the crowds of tourists..... A real feel of history and craftmanship with beautiful tiles. Cards and books for interesting souvenirs for sale.
so beautiful. seriously don't miss this beautiful mosque, tucked away in the thick of the market area. It is stunning.

A mosque that is really blue. Rustem Pasha Mosque is the mosque that really deserves the name “blue mosque’. It is much more ‘blue’ than Sultan Ahmet’s mosque as inside it is entirely covered by the famous Iznik tiles. (Iznik is the name of a town, former historical Nikaea, which is the center of the porcelain and green and blue tiles production ). The mosque was built by Mimar Sinan in 1560. Rustem Pasha was grand vizier and son-in law of Suleyman the Magnificent. He was one of the wealthiest persons in the Ottoman Empire.

hard to find but worth the effort. Go for the original tiles. The artisans who made them are a lost breed and they are fascinating and lovely to look at. It is a small mosque but cozy I have to say the people wojking there were friendlier than in most I have visited.

Small, little-visited, blue-tiled interior. A historic, but not a large mosque set amid a densely-alleyed neighbourhood selling tools, plastic stuff and kitchenware. Wasn't easy to spot its unpretentious entrance. Walls richly decorated with tiles, but seems like too much of a good thing, and somewhat oppressive as a result. Also, lighting isn't good. Interesting, but doesn't have wow factor unless you're a tile aficionado.

Small but very nice mosque. The entrance to the mosque was hidden inside a very busy bazaar, but we were so glad we found it. The mosque is smaller than Blue mosque or Suleymaniye, but it's just as beautiful. If you are in the area - definitely visit it.

More beautiful than the Blue Mosque. More beautiful than the Blue Mosque because the scale works better. The blue mosque is too large for its decoration, this one is perfect. ( and Sokollu Mehmet Pasa is even more perfect than this one)
More blue that the blue mosque. It is a very small cami close to the Egyptian market and I think is interesting to visit it if you are somewhere close to the region. Nothing spectacular though
Small jewel. It is a small mosque, but has wonderful tiles, including some with red patterns. It is a very short walk from the spice bazaar.
Great small mosque. Great mosque renowned for blue tiles. Went with a tour group and were not disappointed. Recommend to anyone going to Istanbul.
nice. to nice mosque I would give 5 but rustem pasa was ugly and bad person, so my final is 4.Interesting to visit.
A little difficult to find but worth it. This mosque was a little difficult to find but once you find it -- you will be so glad you did. It is incredibly beautiful.

beautiful. Mesmerising, and pleasant. You can see on it all the typical elements of the architecture and design of the ottoman culture; and its emplacement allows to could visit right after it the egyptian market or the dolmahbache palace.
A total must see if having a trip in Istanbul!

Intimate and Exquisite. A visit here was included in a complimentary walking tour offered guests of the wonderful hotel, Sirkeci Mansion. What a nice surprise it was! Small and quiet -- and with no entry fee, as seems appropriate for a house of worship -- it exudes spirituality, so unlike the larger, more crowded and better-known mosques on Istanbul's tourist radar. The blue tiles, set off by the orange carpet and over-arched by crisp-white domes with sparing but intricate detail and a massive chandelier of sparkling glass are a visual delight. Well worth seeking this special place out.
An accidental find. This was an architectural treat and gave us more of a feel of how people in Istanbul today relate to their grand Ottoman past.

Beautiful tile work. Small, non-touristy mosque with beautiful tilework inside. It is near the Spice Market and definitely worth the step inside to see it. It's small and doesn't look like much on the outside, but absolutely breathtaking inside.

Prettier than the Blue Mosque (in my opinion). We arrived to the Rustem Pasha Mosque just after the prayer time ended so there were still several people in their praying. The mosques' close 30 minutes before and after the call to prayer. my friends and I enjoyed this smaller mosque's detailed tile and artwork, as well as being able to experience/watch the prayer's who were still there. It felt so much more intimate than the Blue Mosque because of the large crowds there.
small but beautiful mosque. Designed by Sinan, this is a lovely small mosque next to the Spice Bazaar with lovely Iznik tiles on its interior and exterior walls.

small version of blue mosque. almost difficult to find, directly across the plaza where the spice bazaar starts, the entrance around the corner of another bazaar. hardly any visitors. some of the best iznik tiles and very accessible for viewing unlike the blue (sultanahmet) mosque
Amazing Tiles. Smaller mosque but tiles are amazing. Don't miss this one. Entrance is hard to find.....it's actually in the spice market. Ask someone.

A hidden treasure...stunning blue tiles. A bit tricky to find but oh so worth it.Walked passed it the first time so be on the lookout.Scarves are provided free.There is no entry cost.The inside is so stunning....I just loved all the different pattern of tiles.It is still a mosque is use but so tranquil amongst the busy city.There are some very reasonably priced souvenirs for sale at the mosque...I wish I'd bought some of their packets of cards, however I did buy a book of the tiles...soooo worth it as a memento! Highly recommended!
GREAT PLACE. wow wow wow wow wow wow wow wow wow , the minarets and the calligraphy is perfect , i lloved ths mosque also, wow wow wow wow wow wow
best iznik tiles. its blue internal colour is amazing, very calm and not easy to find, with small doors to the street, many times you can be alone inside just feeling intense "blue" peace

Nice little gem opposite Eminonu bus station. This mosque may be underwhelming when compared to other mosques but it is beautiful nonetheless. The design of the mosque by the famed architect, Mimar Sinan is truly inspiring in its modesty and simplicity. Unlike any other mosque, it is perched on top of a neighbourhood and one has to take the staircase to reach the entrance. As it is hidden among the maze of bazaar and can be quite tricky to get here, just take note that it is located directly opposite the Eminonu bus station. There is a public restroom connected to the building of the mosque. Walk along the wall that connects to the restroom and you can spot a discreet entrance with a sign indicating the name of the mosque. Given the fact that it was designed by an acclaimed architect, you have to drop by for a visit to be awed and to be inspired!
Beautiful blue tiles. Unlike the Blue Mosque, there was no wait to get in and the tile work in the Rustem Pasha Mosque was more impressive.

Popular with tour groups. This mosque is situated in the midst of the Egyptian Bazaars at Eminonu. It is a very old building and quite characteristic in that it is almost built up on stilts to survey the surrounding stalls. Entrances are not immediately obvious, as accessed up steps from the alleyways. Dome of this mosque is really splendid, but it is very popular with tour groups as close to port area. Regard as a must see even if only a few days in Istanbul.

Hidden Gem. Thankfully we had a friend show us this place. Small but easily the most beautiful mosque in Istanbul. The interior is covered in Iznik tiles. A beautiful and serene place not to be missed.

Small but calm and beautiful Masjid. To be here you have to be in Eminunu. Easy by tram or ferry as it got a Tram & ferry station. Its hard to find the way to reach this Mosque/Masjid. But yeah its close to Spice market. Near spice market der are smaller crowded markets and entrance to this masjid is inside that. A very small stairs and prayer area is on first floor. Very calm and nice atmosphere. Could be a nice visit if you are in Eminunu. 20-30 mins will be enough. And no fees.

HIDDEN GEM MOSQUE. A friend told us about this small mosque next to the "New" Mosque in the old city near the Spice Bazaar. It has the most magnificent tiles and located in a street bazaar area with great discounts!

another great architectural pearl. i think mosques in Istanbul are great escape from all busy streets, markets and crowds. first of all, they are all different, than it is very quiet inside and relaxing. than there are nice wall decors, which you can look at...
Just a simple mosque. Id try to skip this one. Its just another simple mosque in Istanbul. There are other ones who stand out. I always visit the Blue Mosque.

Unexpected surprise. Yes, this was for me the Rustem Pasha Mosque. It took me a while till I found it due to a poor touristic map that I found in my hotel. Anyway it is in the Eminonu District, near to the Spice Bazar, that side facing, somehow, to the Galata Bridge – it is better to ask the locals while you are in the area. Was a surprise because is very beautiful – the tiles interior coverage is outstanding with blue dominant color – and really quiet and peaceful – no many tourists have the chance to find it and to make this place crowded. On the large terrace there is a stand from where you can get a Koran for free. If you have time in Istanbul, pay a visit to this place.

Impressive, Hard to find, Best Mosque in Instanbul. It takes a bit of doing to find the entrance to this mosque, but with your city map and no Turkish, you can still find it. Ride to Eminonu on the tram, get out and start asking, pointing to the map/your guidebook. We consider it artistically much more interesting than, say, the Blue Mosque.

Beautiful Little Gem. Though it's small, the Rustem Pasha Mosque is one of the most beautiful in Istanbul - really worth the short walk out of the way of the bigger mosques - the title work is absolutely exquisite! It also has a cozy feeling, without as many tourists.

Loved this small beautiful mosque. Do not miss this small charming mosque near the Spice Bazaar. You need to climb a winding staircase to find it but once you do you will be amazed. Intimate with beautiful blue and red tiles, like no other mosque in the city. Out of 7 mosques I visited, this one was my favorite.

Beatiful ceramics. Rustem Pasha Mosque is an inconspicuous, simple mosque from the outside. İt's not come to sight because of it's periphery is full of buildings. Mosque has very nice blue ceramics. İf you have got enough time, you visit it. But you give priority to Blue mosque and Hagia sophia
Better than sultanahmet. Ambiance is better than Sultan Ahmet Mosque very historical and mistic place ...its near spice bazaar in Eminönü

More memorable than the Blue Mosque. This mosque is smaller than the Blue Mosque or Surleymaniye Mosque but more memorable because of the exquisite design and glorious tiles. We felt dwarfed at the other two mosques but felt there was a better balalnce between human proportions and the grandeur of a soaring dome here.

Small, hided and beautiful. This mosque even if it is in Egyptian Bazar is very good hided. To get there you have to climb on the stairs. Great mosaics planned by Mimar Sinan. Very historical place but often missed by tourist. There I could speak in English with some Turkish about the Islam, Istanbul and life in Turkey. This is one of my check point in Istanbul.

Beautiful mosque of tiles. I really liked this mosque because it is smaller and more intimate than the Blue and Suleymaniye mosques -- you are closer to the mihrab and minbar. The Iznik tiles covering the walls are beautiful. We found the mosque after leaving the Suleymaniye Mosque on our way to the Spice Market. The mosque's entrances are a little difficult to find so keep your eyes open as you enter the Spice Market area.

Good. its a good and quiet mosque. its a bit away from the main area. the approach is via the bazaars. no place to keep the strolley and bags. so we were a bit confused whether to leave our stuff on the entrance gate which was a crowded market place or to carry it on our backs.. since the mosque is on a higher floor and with no elevator nor escalator. overall experience was good
Better than some of the others. EAsier access not as overwhelming and beautiful tiles. Women must be covered. Not as extensive as Topkapi. Near trhe Spice Market

Cute and Hidden. This small, cute mosque is hidden in the narrow streets just outside the Spice market/bazaar. Its worth a visit while also exploring the spice market and market streets around this bazaar., where the perfumes of the teas and spices can be quite strong and absolutely wonderful.

Intimate and Beautiful. A short distance from the Galata Bridge and the Enimonou transit complex, hidden amidst a dense commercial area (in fact, the mosque was designed for shops on the ground floor). Buy a packet of 10 diff. picture cards from the caretaker for 5 TLira. Easy to get to -- really glad we went.

A little gem in heart of spice district. This tiny mosque has a gorgeous interior, it's a it tricky to find, so just ask shopkeepers when you are close. The detailing of the mosaic is superb and the walls and ceiling blend together in such a picturesque way, you can meditate here for a while just groovin to the charm.

Like an oasis of peace!. Our group arrived late in the day, harried and rushed from our jostling with tourists and merchants in the bazaars and larger tourist venues. The peacefulness of the mosque, the beauty of the courtyard and worship space, the late afternoon sunlight that slowly faded as evening approached, all of this made our experience here special and one we hope each visitor to this wonderful city gets to share. As another reviewer said, while the space is small, each square foot of wall is a marvel and if you wanted, you could spend a day moving about examining each pattern. But go! Even if it is for a 30 minute rest from the rest of your sightseeing in the Old City.
visit in the morning. A beautiful mosque - take time to look closely at the hand painted ceramic tiles. We visited twice and found the morning visit to be quieter than the afternoon.

Small but beautiful. The tile work is amazing. Not a must must see, but should get included if you like ceramics and tile work. Very quiet and serene. Located next to the spice market and can be a combo visit.
Fascinating mosque. The tiles in this mosque are superb; and it's located right beside the spice market. It won't take long to visit but, like us, you may want to go back.

My favorite mosque. Slightly hidden above the bazaar I'm not sure how many people are able to find Rustem Pasa Camii but it's worth the hunt. Small, especially when compared to Blue Mosque or Sulameniye Camii, it's an oasis of peace in the city's chaos. Iznik tiles cover every wall inside and even after half a dozen visits I'm not sure I've seen them all. Between the tiles and the stained glass windows this little gem is breathtaking.

Enjoy the beauty in peace. We found this small mosque to be a quiet and beautiful place to experience the design, history and purpose of the mosque.Strangely it was without the the tourist queue of the other famous mosques.
beautifully tiled. This mosque was up a stairway, and had a small courtyard. It had very beautiful tile work inside. Definitely worth finding.
Visit to mosque. Can be difficult to find the entrance, it's a small stairway beside the Spice Bazaar. Beautiful times, more intimate than the other grand mosques.

worth a look. Beautiful interior, thousands of blue tiles. Ladies bring a scarf to cover your head and shoulders ( or they do have some there you can borrow) and no shorts above the knees to be worn by either sex.

Iznik Tiles Galore. This is definitely one not to miss. It has some of the best tiles you will see and it is in an interesting area near the spice bazaar. Be careful of your timings though as it is closed during prayer times.

A nice stop in the spice market. We were on a food tour and our guide asked if it was okay to stop - and I am so glad we did. The tiles in this mosque are gorgeous and I would recommend a stop here for everyone.

Charming - Mosque of Tiles. I knew before I left for Istanbul that I wanted to the Rustem Pasha Mosque. I was not disappointed. The elaborate detail work on the mosaic tiles is amazing and beautiful. The carpet in the mosque was also intriguing; every mosque has a different color scheme, and I really like the orange and blue contrast in the Rustem Pasha Mosque. This is a smaller mosque, so if you are expecting the scope and grandeur of the Blue Mosque, please be advised that most mosques are not like the Blue Mosque. Definitely worth visiting! Also they have bookmarks, postcards, and other small things that show off the tile work in the Rustem Pasha Mosque specifically, so bring cash!
Beautiful. This was the first mosque we visited in Istanbul. It was nearly empty and was a quiet place of contemplation. The tiles are beautiful and it was one of our favourite places.

Stunning and Different. Take a look at this Mosque its different than The Blue Mosque, in comparison its a small mosque. I got in easily and found it gorgeous. One of my favorites and close to the ferries with easy access.

Was a little disappointed. It's a very small mosque but what makes it unique are the Iznik tiles that covered the walls inside. Was not as impressive as the other mosques in Istanbul but if you're in the neighborhood, why not?

Beautiful!. This is the best example of Turkish tiles I found in a mosque while in Istanbul. It's a small ish mosque, especially when compared to the Blue Mosque and Suleymanie Mosque, but beautiful interiors. You have to go up steps to get to this mosque as it's higher than street level which I thought I'd mention as I struggled to find it!!

A delightful place. This mosque is not as difficult to find as the maps imply. Directly across the Square from the New Mosque [opposite the Bus Station], you will see its domes easily. Turn left into the market lane and it is located just on the left. Climb the stone stairs and you will see why it is worth it. Bear in mind that there will be worshippers there, so respect is needed. If you are interested in such architecture, you will enjoy this.
Neat little mosque. The tiles in this mosque are beautifully preserved. The mosque is tucked away near the Spice Market. It is not flooded with tourists, so you can enjoy it at leisure.

Lovely interior, unique Mosque. This must be one of the oldest mosque, the interior decoration is outstanding with intense colours of blue tiles. Less crowded and you can appreciate the décor more. The entrance is from the bazaar with tunnel like steps leading to the mosque!
Go there to see the best examples of Turkish tiles.. But if you are into tiles, go there last because no other place will look as good after this one. Look inside as well as outside the mosque.
Do Not Miss. This was the most beautifyl mosque that we had the opportunity to visit. The architecture and the Izik tiles were spectacular. Very hightly recommended.
Sensational find which many tourists miss. If you are wanting to see some fantastic Isnik tiles up close in the quiet retreat of a mosque, don't miss this.

Small and Beautiful Mosque. We were told about Rustem Pasha by a woman who worked at our hotel. She said the story goes something like this. . .the mosque was commissioned by a man who didn't have the nicest reputation and was intensely disliked by his architect. To get back at him the builder decided to create a very small, average mosque. When the man saw it he was less than please and his ego bruised. He told the builder that if he valued his life he better make this small mosque among the most beautiful. He did and then some. Rustem Pasha is a little hard to find (especially the entrance) but is worth the effort. It's like,the Blue Mosque in miniature, and the intensity of color is enhanced because do its small size. The delicate tiles are placed in intricate patterns throughout, and because it doesn't attract the huge throngs of visitors, in addition to being a place of worship, it's also a place of quiet reflection where visitors can marvel at its sheer beauty. If women aren't adequately covered they have a supply of fabrics that can double as skirts to cover knees or head scarves. Directly outside the exit there is an attendant who sells books and some small lovely trinkets.
Peaceful oasis near bazaar. A little difficult to find but great quiet atmosphere and well worth seeking out. Beautiful mosaics.
Beautiful small hidden mosque. This beautiful small hidden gem is located inside the bazaar. Highly recommended with gorgeous tile work.
Nice. It is situated in the busy Tahtakale shopping District. Nice tiles, and architecture. It could be worth a visit if you are passing through that area.

Small but quiet. This mosque is very pretty inside but also hard to find the way in! It is surrounded by markets and has limited signage. Once inside it was nice. Small mosque but not many tourists so you could sit and enjoy. Once again girls take a scarf as you need to cover your head. If you are having trouble finding your way in just go up any of the staircases on the outside :)

peaceful small Camii above bustling bazaar. peaceful small Camii above bustling bazaar, with beautiful Iznik tilework and charming atmosphere. Prayed Zuhr Salaat here while at the Spice Bazaar which is close by.

a pearl. we've got streets, avenues, lanes etc. but in istanbul there are, at least, 36707 classes for this kind of thing. and this number may be doubled, because there are the covered and the ope-air ones. and some subclasses between those two. this mosque is in the middle of this labyrinth. in the middle of the rough surface one can find a pearl.

A Blue Tiled Mosque. Probably less visited than other mosques in Istanbul , we were the only group there at the time, but well worth a look in for the exquisite tiles that decorate the small interior. A lovely little gem of a place.

Beautiful and different from other mosques. Lot of mosques in istanbul have similiar character,as the most famous ones are built by Sinan.this tiny mosque is totaly unique,what is caused by its beautiful decoration from iznik tiles. Cute little jewel,set in a busy market street,so its quit difficult to find. Definitely one of top places.

Oasis amidst chaos. If you can find this tiny doorway outside the Spice Bazaar you will be well rewarded. Climb up the steep marble steps into a courtyard above the melee of the streets below. Enter the mosque, have seat on the floor, and you will be refreshed. The walls are covered with Iznik tiles of various designs. This mosque is not overrun with visitors so it is very restful.

Spice Baazar. Incredible mosque, hidden inside the Spice Bazar. Very charming and well conserved. A Must see! Try to get there before the prayers begin, it is amazing to see them come and do the cleaning to enter the mosque. Visits are not allowed inside during the prayers, you'll wait outside.

Good to check. It's one of the most loved mosques in Istanbul due to its architecture that is very well done and maintained. Out of respect and At all times, shoes must be taken off and women requires a scarf to cover their hair.
A showpiece of the best Ottoman architecture!. It is situated in the busy Tahtakale shopping destrict. It was designed by Sinan. Nice Iznik tiles, particularly desirable!

Lovely and peaceful. Small, intimate, gorgeous tile. If you want to visit a real mosque, this is a good one. Tucked away in a corner near the Egyptian spice market this mosque should be on the must-see list.

A Real Jewel. Slightly off the beaten tourist path this mosque is less crowded and quieter than the larger near by mosques. It is located to the side of the spice market. The wonderful tiles are easy to view close up in this small mosque. A must visit while in Istanbul!

Small with many lovely tiles. this mosque is one of my favourites in Istanbul. The size is small but it is very pretty. The tiles inside feature the colour red, instead of the more common blue tiles. I like climbing up the stone steps form the street below and emerging into the courtyard, now above the noisy streets. There is often a water cooler there to have a sip of water before entering the mosque. As will all mosques there are scarves available if the ladies forgot to bring their own to cover their hair and any bare shoulders. This little mosque is worth the few moments of your time.

What a hidden gem!. This is a typical feature of all the great cities in the world. Scores of historic places that we walk pass everyday but nobody cares to see that there was a beauty monument hidden right there which was constantly overlooked! The Rustem Pasha mosque fits this bill.This mosque was designed by the great Sinan. What strikes you immediately is the beautifully ornated Iznik tiled walls that covers the interiors of this mosque. You may find yourself all alone in this place since this mosque is a bit off the normal tourist trials. But all the efforts taken to get here is richly rewarded. Plan to take a seat inside the mosque and marvel at the architectural brilliance in front of you. Very quiet and soothing indeed.

One not to miss. We visited five mosques while in Istanbul but this was our favourite. Much less busy than the well known ones, smaller and less opulent but with stunning tiles, and because it's quieter you can see more.

not easy to find but worth it!. not easy to find...however, it is worth visiting it:) it's small but it's a hidden treasure. We got the entrance upstairs in the egyptian bazar. its large quantities of İznik tiles is really impressive,So cute! it's next to the new mosque (yeni camii). ask someone if you don't get it:)

Fantastic Little Gem. I walked by this mosque several times while shopping in the area. I had no idea behind the tall wall and a man selling sweaters was the mosque. On our last day we traveled up the stairs to explore, and I'm very glad we did. It was very quiet, had very few people, and was incredibly beautiful. It is smaller than most of the mosques we went it, but the tile was among the most beautiful. Don't miss this one, the tile is a must see.

One of the Best Places to See Iznk Tiles. This is one of the best sites to see really exquisite Iznk tile work. One of the most interesting tiles is the one showing the Kabula in Mecca. This is on the outside of the building to the right of the front entrance. This unique mosque is an small jewel of a spot, just as San Chapelle in Paris is. You do have to know exactly where to go to look for the street level entrance not far from the Spice Bazaar.
Loved the art. The hand built tiles in this mosque are amazing and so detailed. Its worth visiting. A small mosque with a lot of hard work done and a very interesting story behind it as well.
Great building. Love this place. Quite unique in style and structure. Evening is a good time for photos. However, the food hawkers around may be a bit expensive.

Peaceful. Look out for the entrance which is at street level. You have to walk up steps to get into this small but perfectly formed mosque. Beautiful tiles and peaceful space away from the hubbub of the Egyptian market below.
Rustem Pasha. Relatively small mosk but absolutely beautifully and uniquely decorated. Must see if you visit Istanbul
Still connected with the history of Istanbul . Really well preserved mosque, with a lot of history behind the walls, beautiful tiles, with inscriptions of the Quran, it worth the visit
Small but beautiful. This is a well-hidden, upstairs mosque well worth finding and visiting. And there is a water cooler outside for those who want to fill up their bottles with filtered water.
Hard to find. Difficult to find, mostly above the markets. A cute small gem of a mosque, gorgeous tile. Ask at shops, worth a look.

A quiet gem. An unexpectedly delightful sight with a real sense of peace right at the heart of the city. A little difficult to find, it is on the first floor, but well worth the effort. Also has a cool verandah outside for a rest.

Tourist free.... We visited the Rustem Pasha Mosque on our second day in Istanbul and this mosque is a hidden gem. We had been to the Blue Mosque the day before and while stunning, it was hard to appreciate with so many tourists around. The Rustem Pasha Mosque is close to the spice bazaar, quiet and peaceful and has a beautiful interior lined with blue tiles. It is definitely worth taking a detour during your visit to the spice bazaar.
Wonderful Blue tiles. Tucked away above/close to the Spice Bazaar. Gorgeous interior of stunning blue tiles. Well worth seeking out!

Hidden nice place. The mosque is small and situated behind the Egyptian Bazaar, if you are bored from the hustle and bustle of the shops you may get few minutes of relaxation while observing the beautiful blue ceramics which cover the mosque's walls
A place to visit closed to the Egyptian bazar. The mosquee has the one of the most beautiful iznik tiles. Has it is on a first floor you can observe the streets behind you and take good pictures.

More Blue than the Blue Mosque. Excellent interiors, great calligraphy inside and not forgetting the blue glass on the windows. However the approach was through a very narrow lane close to the old Egyptian spice bazaar.

Unique intrior art. Located next to the new mosque before the Galata bridge. It is small but with beautiful interior design. You can make the visit after the visiting the Egyptian Bazaar (Misr Carsisi).

Skip the Blue Mosque- go here instead!. This beautiful mosque is filled with gorgeous blue tiles, and best of all it's off the beaten track! While the blue mosque is packed with tourists, Rustem Pasha is peaceful with only a couple of people wandering in. You get a real sense of atmosphere, peaceful with a lovely breeze blowing through. It's just as intricate and beautiful as the blue mosque, though on a smaller scale. If you forget to bring a scarf for covering your head don't worry: they have sarongs and headscarves that you can borrow as you go inside.

Interesting place. Although this is a smaller one compared to Blue mosque, it's very interesting. Infact there are more blue tiles inside than the blue mosque. Make sure to dress appropriately but if you are not, they provide scarves at the entrance. There are some good small places to eat nearby.

Truly the "Blue Mosque". Located at the end of the spice market, this small mosque, located above the street level, it stunningly beautiful. Far and way the most beautiful of all the mosques we visited in Istanbul.

A wander and wonder on my last day in Istanbul. This moderately small octagonal mosque is situated in the Faith district of Istanbul. The interior is walled in exquisite Iznik tiles - the best quality ever produced - and beautiful inlaid wood work on the doors and sections of the ceilings. This site is situated within walking distance and close proximity to the spice market and definitely worth a visit. Although this mosque does not receive as many visitors, this mosque is a gem worth visiting as it is also the first example of Mimar Sinan, a great Ottoman architect's work.
Impressive. Absolutely beautiful and worth visitong. Inside is blue. One of the places I liked mosed in Istanbul.
Uncrowded Mosque. This mosque was not packed, so you could understand how things were set up better. Also, there were tiles and decorations going down to the floor, so we could see them better

A hidden gem. In the midst of bustling streets is this tranquil hideaway, elevated above the street level.Its entrance is a fairly small archway that leads up winding stairs to a platform overlooking the street traders and roofscape. Inside it is a spectacular showcase of the best variety of Iznik tile designs, with every surface seeming to have a different design and all of them within easy sight.Do look out for the exquisite craftsmanship of the corner tiles, with the uppermost one being the most complex shape of any Iznik tile that you will find.Even just sitting in the courtyard is a blissful break from the hustle and bustle of the surrounding street markets.

Sultan. Due to history mosque i like it other wise the name rustum is a hate ful in in Islamic history.The surrounding area is very. Dirty and ful of mosquitoes,the slow at the basement are fine but. Very expensive.
Magnificent Tile Works. Hidden Gem located behind Spice Market.quite, beutiful and peacefull.If you go to spice market, just do not miss it.
good architecture!!. I didn't get in but it looks like a good architecture from outside. Inwould recommend every tourist visit to Eminönü.
An expression of love. The story behind the mosque is as fascinating as the mosque itself make sure your guide tells you the full story ..voted most beautiful mosque in Europe don't miss it
Little gem inside the spices bazaar. Hidden in the Spice bazaar, this small mosque was beautifully decorated and after Aya Sofia was probably our favorite.

Still my favourite mosque in Istanbul . I'm a mosque junkie. Over the years I've seen nearly every one of the 40+ mosques scattered around Istanbul.
This is still my fav. Quite, small and not crowded. The tiles are superb. And you seem to be able to get more up close and personal than other mosques.
Make an effort to get here!

Worth a quick glimpse of Iznik. If you're curious to see the origin of the famous Iznik tiles, that turkey pretty much sells on, then Rustem Pasha Mosque is the place. It is really simple, quiet , still in use, and significantly smaller than any of the tourist-populated mosques you'll come across in Turkey- you can take your pictures in peace. If you're into architecture or art history, you'll love this. It'll take you less than 20 mins to snoop around.

beautiful. If you are into tiles this is the place.small succinct mosque next to the spice market.you could start of here and walk back toward sultanahhmet or walk up the hill towards sullimanie mosque and then on towards the grand bazar.well worth a visit.

Very beautiful small mosque. So far, the most beautiful mosque I've visited in Istanbul. It's a small mosque decorated with interesting blue tiles and the thing i mostly liked about it - it's not full of tourists.

Our favourite mosque. Of all the mosques we visited, Rustem Pasha was by far our favourite. It was a little challenging to find the entry; the blue tiles were beyond amazingly beautiful; it is a small and "cozy" mosque, which made it quite approachable for us; not too many tourists. The other mosques we visited were awesome and sort of intimidating (as fine religious buildings are often designed to be); this mosque felt much more ... um ... "comfortable." Highly recommended!
Skip it. It is a small mosque which is still used daily for prayers. It does not have any unique design or architecture to spend 20 minutes. It is free but it is still not worth the time.
Beautiful small mosque. The Iznik tiles in this small mosque close to the spice bazaar are absolutely stunning. Less crowded and a bit hidden but definitely worth the trouble.

Hidden gem - must visit just for the Iznik tiles. One of my favorite mosques in Istanbul. Because its off the beaten track, the mosque is not inundated with hundreds of tourists which allows one to enjoy the beautiful Iznik tiles in peace. If you visit the Sulemaniye Mosque, make sure you go down and across a couple of streets to find this mosque in the bazaar. Its worth the visit.
Fine small mosque. This was an especially fine small mosque. There is only a doorway with small sign at street level. You must go upstairs to the mosque itself. Highly recommended.
Blue beauty. It is a very small mosque but beautiful with the Iznik tiles. Sometimes they provide free Quran in english. The wood work is very nice too.

A sense of history and community. The almost obscure entrance to this mosque is part of its charm and sense of being part of the community and not a monument.The fabulous Iznik tile interior makes it special.Well worth the time.
Quaint but lovely.. A small mosque (by Istanbul standards), but well worth a visit. Decorated with blue Iznik tiles. Nothing like the Hagia Sophia or Sultanahmet mosques, but different.

Small mosque - shopping market around this is awesome. I would suggest you take advantage of shopping around this mosque. This place is cheaper and better than the Grand Bazaar. Mosque is small and does look bluer than blue mosque.Negotiate the price down, don't feel shy. Turkish shop owners also enjoy the negotiation. You can really assimilate in this area better than Grand bazaar.

Beautiful, worth seeing. This mosque is right in the centre of the Market 10-15 minutes walk from the Suleimanya mosque. The tiles work is extremely beautiful. Definitely worth seeing. Beware that unlike other mosques, no shawls, or long skirts are given on site for women wearing short skirts or sleeveless shirts so come prepared as you may not be allowed to enter.
Quiet and blue. The inside is decorated with so many blue tiles (Iznik?). Being different from Blue Mosque, it is tiny, quiet and lovely. We loved so much,
Worth the walk. Through the spice market upt the hidden stairs and wow. This small mosque is beautiful. It's a working mosque so no shoes and a head scarf for women.
The Best. This is simply the best mosque in the city to visit - It is smaller than most of the others but this makes it even more charming

A beautiful Mosque with exquisite tiles and quiet ambience.. I chose to visit the mosque on a personal tour on my second visit to Istanbul. Much smaller (but older) than the Blue Mosque, I visited at around 5pm and I was the only person there with my guide. Inside the quiet interior, it was hard to believe just outside there were crowds of people rushing too and from the Spice Market. After the crowds of the Blue Mosque, I appreciated being able to get up close to the hand painted İznik tiles. A very beautiful place to visit.
Beautiful Mosque. Be sure and visit here and be sure to go upstairs and see how it looks from up there. Not very crowded and well worth your time.

charming and amazing blue tiles. This mosque is really great,
Hidden away in the bazaar area, when you go up the stairs you will find a charming mosques, older, with amazing tiles. The blue of the tiles floods the building, if you are in the area, this is a must see.

Hidden Gem of a Mosque.. Older than the blue mosque, and smaller, this mosque is located close to the Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar. As a tourist, you can walk right by the mosque and never notice it, so be vigilant in your search as this mosque is a gem. This a functioning mosque so you have to arrive to the mosque when it is not closed to tourists for prayers. Should women not be properly attired, they will provide you with a headscarf for your head and a robe to cover your shoulders and legs. Once inside it is full of beautiful blue tiles all over the walls and stained glass windows. We were lucky to arrive with very few people in the mosque and we were able to soak in the beauty of the magnificently designed blue tiles. This is a must find!

Magnificent Small Blue Mosque. This hidden gem is located in a very busy street which is very close to the Egyptian Bazaar&Spice Bazaar.İt is very difficult to locate this Mosque if you are walking through the crowded streets with mostly the local people.So you may need to look for the entrance through the crowd and once you are inside it,that's another world.You will love the very colourful special tiles from the town of İznik.İt is sad to see that many locals do not care this Mosque as we feel that there is less interest on this part,because we see few people visiting and praying at this place.Pls when you are in Eminönü area,plan yrself and find this small but very good Mosque and have some time in peaceful athmosphere.Highly recommended for anyone visiting this part of İstanbul .
Beautiful. We went to this mosque. Is not dissapoint beautiful and hide but worth it.Istambul has a beutiful mosques but this... this mosque its beauty is priceless.

Smallish but beautiful. We visited this mosque during a weekday just prior to Ramadan and it was worth the visit. The tiles are stunningly beautiful and the architecture very nice. It may be hard to find but is well worth it.

Most beautiful mosque I have visited. We almost passed by this mosque on our way down from Suleymani mosque. It is a bit hidden inside a very busy area. We found one of the entries and we were very lucky because nothing prepared us to this small, but amazing place. Blue tiles on the outside and inside make this mosque really one of a kind. Make sure you get information about it before you go, as it is not very easy to find, but definitely worth a trip.
Family holiday. Lovely inside. Be aware of dress requirements. And check prayer times. Beautiful building and surrounds.

Most Beautiful Mosque in Istanbul!. Although small, this is easily the most beautiful mosque in Istanbul.The interior is covered in Iznik tiles, like the Blue Mosque. Unlike the Blue Mosque, however, Rustem Pasa is peaceful, doesn't smell like feet, and doesn't have the annoying chandeliers that block your view of the dome.
the best examples of Iznik tiles. Hard to find the access; it's a doorway, with stairs going up, marked with the mosque name on a little plaque on the street wall

Blue Mosque without the crowds. This tucked away stunning mosque was like a mini version of the Blue Mosque, with out the crowds and a welcome relief from the hustle and bustle of The Grand Bazaar. Appropriately dressed, I sat quietly on the almost deserted vibrant orange carpet, and took in the quiet serenity and reverence of a stunning sanctuary.

A Nice Smaller Mosque. Next to a busy shopping district, it's smaller and quieter than it's bigger siblings around the city. Outside they have a small shelf with free Qurans you can take and read or keep as a souvenir.

A taste of old Istanbul. When you descend here from Sultanahmet area, you will find yourself in a different world: no more nice parks with flower-beds and fountains, no more postcard-perfect views - you are here in the narrow streets of the bazaar with its constantly busy folks, where your main concern would be not to lose your way. It's not easy to find the mosque here: it's not on a waste square, it's not even among the shops - actually, it's above them. So, first you have to find the staircase to go up to the mosque. It's a wonderful surprise: first, the tranquillity of its courtyard - it gives you a feeling of relax immediately. Then, the interior of the mosque - its walls are overwhelmed with splendid blues tiles. You could easily have the impression that you have arrived in the "real" Blue Mosque. So, a hidden gem, don't miss it!

One of the hidden charms in Istanbul. This mosque is one of architect Sinan's masterpieces. Besides being a beautiful example of his work, the "sampler" tile wall on the exterior is one of its most unusual features. Be sure to spend time exploring the wonderful Iznik tiles on the interior.

The original Blue Mosque!!. A hidden gem. If you don't look up, you'll miss it. But thankfully we had a friend show us this place, it seems like it was the prototype of all mosques around Istanbul. What I really liked it the way we took to find it near the Spice Bazaar where we saw the 'animal' shops that were selling leeches, and hardware lane and then low and behold..the mosque! A real gem.

A well-kept secret. A gem amongst gems, this neighbourhood mosque hidden away away in a busy street just off the Spice market is awesome for its wealth if Iznik tiles. A beautifil and serene place not to be missed.

Beautiful mosque. As beautiful and awe-inspiring as the Blue Mosque is, I would have to say that this one was actually my favorite. The Iznik tile is gorgeous, and the smaller scale made me feel more welcome. Once you find your way in (up some stairs, which are marked if you look for it) it is peaceful, cool and beautiful. I was there not too long after a call to prayer, so there were still a few men praying, which added to the serene feeling. As elsewhere, there are shawls available if you are female and come on it without a headscarf.

A Spice Market Gem. This little mosque sits pretty above the spice bazaar but is by no means an easy find. Wind your way close from the busy side-streets and you'll find the stairs, which give little hint of what's ahead. The portico is the highlight of the mosque, a cool and serene contrast with the busy marketplace below, and the tile-work for which the mosque is rightly praised can be appreciated from within the arcade. The mosque is still very functional, and we were met by worshippers flocking from the door as we waited to enter. The interior tile-work, although perhaps hard to appreciate for a westerner, where it has become somewhat trad, is undeniably impressive here. Great to contrast with a visit to the vast and imperious Sulemaniye mosque complex.
Favorite Mosque. This is serene and lovely inside and out. We spent much time studying all the different tile sections.

Beautiful, smaller Mosque. Must see.. This was a wonderful Mosque to visit after the Suleymaniye Mosque. The Rustem Pasha Mosque is very small and nearly completely covered with blue tile. Absolutely beautiful.

Active worship area. The surroundings are a bit crowded being a market but the mosque is one of the beautiful mosques around in the city and what makes it special is the intricate blue tile works all around. It is names after the person who commissioned its construction. The place can be visited while it in not in service and visiting the market. It is worth your time.
Worth it if ur nearby. Just at the entrance to spice bazaar ..just hidden away ..wil take only 15 minutes so if in the area just step in ..beautiful tiles.

Interesting if your in the area. We enjoyed this mosque it is very open to tourist though I wish people would respect this is a house of worship. Women should cover their heads arms and legs need to be covered above the elbow and knee. Saw people walking up quite close and taking photos of both the Imam and the students. The mosque is quite informal and the ceiling and walls quite lovely.
Worth a short visit. This small mosque may not be impressive in size but I loved the blue tiles inside - very charming! 15 minutes should be enough for a visit to this mosque.

Hidden Gem in Eminou. This is a beautiful little mosque located above a shop in the Eminou district. Gorgeous tile work and a tranquil atmosphere - even in peak tourist season...Look for the insets in the stone pillars outside the mosque which were formerly in Roman structures - the original "recycling program" (?). This gem is definitely worth a visit!

Fascinating and exotic area to wander around. We loved learning about the history of the city, and we're impressed with the tolerance and charm of the people. A very civilised city. Many vendors are too persistent in pressing their wares on you. As a pedestrian, negotiating traffic can be hazardous. Trams easy to use.

Beautiful tile works. The mosque is actually pretty famous for the tile works it has and it is one of the best I have ever seen. The mosque is near to the Egyptian bazaar and is fully adorned with blue tile works. The surrounding areas of mosque could be a little hard since it is a market area with lots of narrow alleys and overly crowded with vendors, tourists and shoppers alike. This is also an active worship place and therefore tourists are not allowed during the service hours. Also you have to appropriately dressed while visiting and they also have a small shop to the front where you could but scarves to cover your heads in case you are not carrying one.
Beautiful Tiles. This mosque although much smaller than the Blue Mosque or Suleymaniye Mosque is just near the lowerentrance to the Spice Markey and is worth a visit to see the wonderful Iznik tiles

Small mosque with great treasure of tiles. Rustem Pasa Mosque was not well known until recently and it was not a part of the daily tours. Its location is actually great, just next to the Egyptian Bazaar (Spice Bazaar) at Eminonu. Outside the mosque is surrounded by small streets generally crowded with people so it's not easy looking at the mosque from a distance and see it. But when you go inside, the blue tiles are impressive and it's another must sees of endless Istanbul historical treasures. Not only the tiles are gorgeous but the architect is also a very important figure : Architect Sinan from the 16th century who also built other impressive and famous buildings such as : Suleymaniye Mosque at Istanbul, Selimiye Mosque at Edirne and many more. Architect Sinan's work count up to 375 buildings...

A gem of a small mosque. Most people miss this amazing little mosque, and for me it is one of the most beautiful due to the amazing decorative Iznik tiles.Rustem Pasa was the Vizir of Soleyman the Magnificient and also the son-in-law being married to the Sultan's daughter Mihrimah Sultan. For all his sins and he had many! He had this mosque built by the great architect Sinan.If you are at the Misir Market, just walk up to the mosque. Turkish people are very helpful with directions! Then go and have lunch at Pandeli, near by.

A hidden gem. Near the Galata Bridge and only accessible from the bazaar via two sets of stone stairs (one near the edge; both signposted, although not well; look for Rüstempasa Camii) which open out onto the low walled courtyard in front of the mosque, this makes a beautiful, quiet and lesser visited little stop on any tour of Istanbul. As with every other major place of worship tourist access is only allowed outside prayer times. If you happen to arrive during prayers sit on the stone bench running around the courtyard, listen to the goings-on in the narrow streets below, admire the tiles on the exterior beneath the arcade and enjoy some downtime. There's a small bookshop at the entrance which also provides coverings for women and sconces for footwear.The interior is glorious; architecturally, by virtue of the liberal use of Iznik tiles and for the absence of crowds. An easy way to lose an hour and the highlight of my time in Istanbul.
Gorgeous Blue Tiles. Blue tiles are magnificent! This is our favorite mosque In Istanbul. It is near the Spice Market and well worth visiting.

A gem. It does not have the size of the larger sites but it has a tranquil majesty and really, truly could be called a 'blue mosque'
Easy to visit and not easy to forget, well worth the effort.
Worth a visit after Spice Bazaar. I wouldn't make a special visit just for this but if you are in the area then it would be worth going to visit for the blue tile work and designs.

hard to find, beautifull to see. Hard to find but so beatifull to see!!! It deserves the way between the small shops and the bad smells and also the starirs to reach it. Beautifull blue fresces and quiet place

Beautiful hidden jewel. Rustem Pasha Mosque is one of the most beautiful **and quiet!!** mosques in Istanbul. It's hidden away in the rabbit warren near the Spice Bazaar and easily has the most incredible collection of tilework outside of Topkapi Palace.

A marvellous variety of Iznik tiling. This mosque, which seemed friendly to tourists when we were there, exhibits a stunning number of tile designs, both inside and out. It is easily found after exhausting encounters in the Spice Bazaar, by turning left and inquiring in the narrow market alleys running parallel to the waterfront. Not to be missed.

A small jewel in the heart of the markets, don't miss this one!. Rustem Pasha was an unexpected highlight of our time in Istanbul. It gave the most local intimate feeling of any of the 4 mosques we visited. The Iznik tiles are spectacular, The atmosphere is quiet and almost meditative, not many praying, but groups of men outside quietly visiting and waiting for prayer. Small outdoor stand with some books, postcards, and mementos of the mosque which were all in good taste. No bags for shoes, so few people, we left them on the outdoor racks by the entrance. It reminded me in many ways of a local Parish church rather than a vast tourist attraction. We were completely charmed!

Blue and blue. This mosque is hiding in a narrow street of Eminonu. So, it was a little bit hard to find, but it was worth. The tiles of the inside were blue tone. The calm atmosphere made me forget the noise outside.

The glories of Iznik tiling, tucked away near the waterfront. It is amazing that this extensively tiled and friendly mosque has remained intact for nearly 500 years! It is surrounded by the liveliest market activity.
Magical. Probably my favourite place in Istanbul. Gives you a tingly feeling. Kept in an original state makes you feel like a trip into the past.

A hidden gem. This quaint mosque, hidden away from the hustle of tourists was a great find in one of the market areas. We were able to visit without fighting off crowds of tourists. There is much history to the mosque and even a great kebab place downstairs!

Peaceful and beautiful. This mosque is well worth searching for when in the bazaar district. The entrance is an unassuming staircase off the side of one of the bazaar streets.The interior is gorgeous, with amazing tiles all around. It is also much more peaceful and quiet than the other larger mosques, and it offers a nice break from the hustle of the bazaars. There are cubbies for shoes, and scarves are provided.

Smaller and Not Highest Priority But Worth a Visit. If time is limited, there are "bigger and better" famous mosques to visit in Istanbul, but if time permits, this smaller more intimate mosque is a gem. I may be wrong but I believe its famous blue tiles are not only beautiful to see and enjoy, but may be historically important because the art of tile making experienced a decline and this may be one of the last mosques to incorporate the fine tiles of yore. Perhaps because it is not physically as overwhelming as some of the larger mosques, one can perhaps better appreciate the space and its function as a house of prayer. I am very glad to have visited this mosque.

A gem. A small mosque, easily missed since it is surrounded by several larger mosques. It is close to the spice market. But, so well worth seeing, it is beautiful, being decorated from floor to ceiling with gorgeous blue Turkish tiles. Not to be missed.
Tiles. Ah the tiles ( Iznik )! Wonderful, no one there because they could not find the two small entrances that lead here ( at the sortie of the Egyptian Bazaar ). Definitely to be seen .
Worth a visit. Much smaller than the Blue Mosque and less crowded but the tile work is really exquisite. I personally preferred it to the Blue Mosque and its much more peaceful in here
Good. Good mosque. Very quiet compared to the crowds in the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. However worth a visit if you are visiting the spice bazaar.

Fantastic Iznik Tiles. This mosque has the best Iznik Architecture and is very less crowded. You can spend ample of time admiring the Iznik tile work with out feeling rushed. The steps of the mosque are a bit difficult to find as it is located in a small street of the Spice Market. But just follow the lone Minarat from Eminönü tram stop.

Favorite Mosque. Of the 6 mosques visited while in Istanbul this one was my favorite. I am so glad we stopped in during our Istanbul Eats tour. It was gorgeous. It was like standing in a treasure chest.

A jewel. This mosque is a stunning piece of architecture and a little off the beaten path. Well worth a visit to see the beautiful Iznik tiles that line the interior walls. The courtyard out front is a very peaceful place to rest after a day of walking and sightseeing. Worth a visit for sure.
gorgeous small mosque. This is the most beautiful mosque I visited in Istanbul. As beautiful as the Blue Mosque, but on an intimate scale. The tiles are fantastic!

A hidden gem covered in Iznek tiles. Hidden on a small street near the Spice Market, Rustem Pasha is a small mosque designed by Sinan, the architect of the Suleymaniye Mosque just up the hill. Without the crowds of the other mosques, this is a peaceful, quiet place to relax and to enjoy the beauty of all of the Iznek tilework that covers the walls of the mosque. The mosque is above street level and is reached by either of two stairs; just look for the signs, it is definitely worth it!

Wonderful tiled interior. This small mosque has a jewel like quality. The interior is totally tiled in beautiful old Iznik tiles, and there is a fabulous mix of patterns. The mosque is located near the Spice Market and is a little difficult to find because the entrance is a nondescript doorway leading upstairs to the mosque courtyard. It is worth the search.

Beautiful. This mosque is tucked away near the Spice market and could easily be missed. There is a stone staircase up to it. Head/leg coverings are provided if you don't remember to come prepared. Its beautiful inside and well worth a visit.

Small beautiful mosque next to spice market. This is a small mosque, but worthwile, also not many tourist. Combine with spice market. Easy to miss because it’s not at street level. Make sure you bring some plastic shoe bags from another more touristy mosque, as you’ll not find them here. If you leave your shoes outside they may disappear (that’s what our guide told us)

One of my favorite mosques in Istanbul. The mosques of Istanbul are a treat, and visitors are allowed inside (which is not the case in all Muslim countries). This is one of the smaller mosques but a great delight, full of beautiful tiles. If you love Islamic art and architecture (as I do), this is one you don't want to miss.

An exquisite gem of Islamic art!. An extraordinary and breathtaking artistry in full display of historical and cultural significance. It combines many elements from the other mosques and churches. The details are mind boggling in their precision and expanse as well as geometry. This monument is a hidden gem and takes some effort to locate thru labyrinths of bazaar lanes!

Exquisite mosque. This little mosque near the Spice Bazaar is fully tiled with the famous Iznik tiles and is just beautiful. The intimate space is quite different to the magnificence of say the Blue Mosque or Aya Sophia. I went back twice. It's free, though they like a donation.

My favorite Mosque in Istanbul. We almost missed the entrance as we wound through the streets by the spice market but once we were inside it was as if we'd discovered a secret garden. It is somehow completely quiet despite the yelling fish vendors and traders just outside its high walls. All I could think was that this is what one should feel in a spiritual building. Stunning...don't miss it but in be sure to not intrude with noise (or shoes).
Outstanding Tile Work. This mosque is one of the less visited hidden treasures. We highly recommend it for its beauty and peacefulness. (It is close to the spice market).

Small, hidden mosque near the Golden Horn waterfront. Easy to miss so ask in the neighbourhood. Some of the prettiest and most unusual tiles in the city. Near the Spice Market (which, by the way, was a disappointment - VERY touristy) and the New (Yeni) mosque.

Small gem. This mosque is located in/near the Spice Bazaar, and is an exquisite example of blue Iznik tiles There is a leafy garden courtyard in front of it where we waited for the prayer hour to finish before visitors like us could enter.

Less than what we expected. We have visited a lot of mosques in the past few months, and this one didn't seem to have as much oomph as the others we had seen. We concluded it was not worth all the effort of going to visit it. Aspects were very nice but overall didn't impress too much.
