A beautiful pocket of quiet in the Spice Bazaar. Take your time, enjoy the tiles up close in the peaceful mosque. Step outside and view the bustle from the plaza of the Spice Bazaar.

A Jewel near the Spice Market. Gorgeous mosque right near the Spice Market, opposite the New Mosque. It's a bit difficult to find the entrance, but persevere, and you'll be thrilled you did. While the Blue Mosque and Sulemanye Mosque are designed to awe with their massive size and decorative programs, the Rustem Pasha Mosque feels like a discovery, off the beaten path but in plain sight. We read about it having the best preserved and most beautiful program of Iznik tile decoration. I think this is what I imagined the Blue Mosque would look like. It's gleaming, glistening tiles everyone in a riot of patterns, all in shades of blue. It's so quiet and intimate, but still awesome in its spiritual power. I did my prayers here in the women's section (which, like all women's sections is cordoned off with a wooden gate). I'm not the biggest fan of this technique (which is due to the need to segregate the sexes, but results in women getting the short side of the stick when it comes to appreciating the beauty of the space), but for whatever reason, I enjoyed the feeling of separation from everyone, from reality. This was probably my most transcendent experience in Istanbul, and I would highly recommend taking the opportunity to duck in, even for a few minutes. It's sublime.
One of the most beautiful mosques in Istanbul. There are so many beautiful and impressive mosques in Istanbul, but this relatively small one was really memorable. Worth a quick visit.

Beautiful. This is a small mosque in the Eminonu market, off the normal tourist trail close to the Spice Bazaar. It is worth a visit to enjoy the beautiful tiles inside, not far from the Eminonu new mosque (Yeni Cami) which is also worth a visit.
small but nice. this is a small nice mosque, I like the mosaic walls and its blue colors. take the stairs to enter the mosque

Embedded in the market like a beautiful tile. This is a beautiful mosque in the old marketplace of Eminönü. Rüstem Pasha Mosque is famous with its Iznik tiles which gives a blissful interior feeling. If you enjoy historical mosques, please do not miss Sinan's masterpiece.
Impressive. Beautiful mosque, enjoyed it more than the Blue Mosque. Because the mosque is much smaller, visitors can see and appreciate the Isnik tile more intimately.

Hidden Gem - Under Rated. Easily accessible! No big crowds! All the interesting features of other mosques but to a smaller scale. The area around the mosque also is interesting as well. Walked through the street market and over to the spice market as well!
Little Gem. This mosque is much smaller than its enormous counterparts, but is delicate and beautiful. It is close to new mosque, which is also worth a visit.

Great tilework, worth stopping in but probably not a destination site. This smaller mosque has some fantastic tile work and is definitely worth stopping in if you're in the area (It's near the spice market and is a little bit hidden in plain sight in a well traveled area). It's less crowded than some of the bigger mosques which was nice since we were in Istanbul in high season. I'd recommend visiting if you're in the area but it's probably not worth a detour.
Very Interesting Mosque. We were taken here to se this interesting mosque with more blue tiles. It is in a very residential area and is a working mosque for the locals.
Most beautiful mosque in Istanbul.. This is only a small mosque but the tiles inside are wonderful. Also the fact that it is in a busy street, up some stairs, gives it a special atmosphere.

Little but very beautiful. This mosque is a very little one, but thanks to our guide we did not miss it. The tiles in the mosque are just amazing and we learned that there are more tulip designs in this mosque than the Blue Mosque.

last but not least. That mosque was the last one we visited before we left Istanbul. I was started to get tired of taking off my shoes and putting my scarf on ... However i certainly will never regret getting into that mosque, one of my favourite ones. In the bazar, it's fun to get there and the mosque is amazingly beautiful : it's covered in Iznik tiles and it gives the place a different atmosphere.

Amazing Craftsmanship. Tile work was amazing. Best in the Istanbul. Not very popular like other historical places. You can feel the real peace.. even if you are not a Muslim they will accept you.. Don't go on Friday around 12;30 -13;00
The Gem of Mosques in Istanbul. Amazing and top of my list of Mosques for its beauty. Its tiles are the best and copied in many of today's tiles and pottery and fabric, etc
Seek out this little gem. A bit tricky to find, so keep asking when you're getting near the Spice Market. It's a little gem indeed.

Peaceful, beautiful mosque. Once you find this beautiful little mosque, slightly hidden away in the bazaar area, don't do what we did accidentally, unable to identify the way in, and go in a doorway which leads downstairs-as that's where the men go to wash before praying. Make sure you go in a doorway with stairs going up (there is more than one of them) and you should be fine. It was a peaceful, beautiful mosque inside, with only a handful of tourists inside...and of course, a few men trying to pray in peace. The man who stands outside where you take your shoes off was welcoming, and they provide a free headscarf and a wrap for your waist if you're not sufficiently covered up or haven't brought your own (though if you were planning to visit a mosque, you'd hope that you HAD thought about these things beforehand).A lovely mosque to visit.

A haven amidst the chaos of the spice market. This is my favourite mosque and epitomises all that is wonderful about Istanbul. It is a beautiful,tiny mosque hidden in the Hurley burly streets. We loved the serene calm and beautiful tiles
So pretty!. What a neat surprise to find this mosque, above the shops and little alleyways. Loved the unusual tiles and the quiet space. Beautiful place.
Superb tiling. Much quieter than the Blue Mosque, but the superb tiling in the interior was even better. Tranquility.
Up close and personal. While the other mosques are stunning, here you can see the beautiful tiles and calligraphy in a small and intimate space. Worth finding!

Small yet beautiful mosque!. Although that mosque is smaller than all the other famous mosques in Istanbul, it's still got its unique identity ... Tiles are really nice and mosque is neat and noce from inside.
small mosque. Visited many mosques, and this is worth a trip to see the fabulous Iznik tiles.First to use tthe "tomato red" color in tiles.

A Little Gem in Blue. This small mosque located near the Spice market is absolutely beautiful inside. The tiles are every shade of blue and the lighting inside the mosque shows them off well even on a rainy day. Take a few extra minutes and visit this mosque - its convenient location as well as its smaller size make it an easy addition to any itinerary. It is another masterpiece by the architect Sinan.

Amazing. Find the set of stairs in the dark alleyway, through along the back of the spice market, and find your way to the top. It really is worth the hunt. Absolutely beautiful, amazing tiles, and very quiet when we went in April. Even on a second visit in Istanbul, this place is amazing.

i wish it had stayed undiscovered. this is my favorite mosque in istanbul. it's a little bit of a hassle to find it because it is tiny and not well marked and the only way i can describe it is to say it is near the spice bazaar but you have to walk the direction of eyup and you'll run into it. it's very peaceful. the main reason to go there is that it is the original location of some of the most beautiful ceramics and iznik styles, which are now of course copied and you can purchase replicas of.

Lovely building. This makes for a nice visit, which you can combine with a visit to the adjoining Spice Market. Quite hard to find, look for the stone staircase going up. The interior is quite stunning, and it has a calm and peacefulness about it which is lacking in the Blue Mosque.

Stunning.amazing. Peaceful. A beautiful blue tiled mosque hidden away up steps on the busy route to the bazaar. Both times I visited there was only me - in sharp contrast to the hordes at the Blue Mosque

The most collection of Iznik Tiles. This mosque is located next to Egyptian Bazaar. You have to walk up the stairs to reach the main floor. The size of the mosque is smaller than Blue Mosque, but it has strong character. There are many different style of Iznik tiles and calligraphy around the Mosque's interior wall.
Most beautiful site. The most interesting mosque to visit in Istanbul, with delicate and interesting mosaics and tiles. Also less crowded than the other sites.

Wonderful Tiles. If you see one mosque besides the obligatory stop at the Blue Mosque, see this one! The gorgeous Iznik blue tiles here were even more vivid and lovely than those at the Blue Mosque. This mosque was like a wonderful little jewel box - not huge but richly decorated. Especially since it's just down the road from the ferry docks at Eminonu and the Spice Bazaar, the Rustem Pasha Mosque makes for a great quick stop.
Mosaic heaven. Worth going to look at the mosaics! Hard to find though but very near the Spice market and up some stairs.

One of my favourites in Istanbul. Have seen many Mosques in Istanbul but this one is pretty special. Hidden by the Spice bazar, intimate and still grand, very peaceful. Beautifully decorated. Recommend a visit.

A beautiful and intimate mosque. As many have noted, the cobalt blue tiling in the mosque interior makes it very special. In many ways it is A more evocative Atmosphere And that of the massive And impersonal blue mosque interior. Strongly recommended.

The most beautfiul mosque in Istanbul. Without question if you want to see a beautiful mosque, the Rüstem Pasha Mosque is the one to see. It is located above shops in the Eminönü area very close to the Spice Market. (When it was built the revenue from the shops helped towards the costs for maintaining the mosque)There are 4 gates which lead up to the mosque - 3 of them are on Uzun Carsi St. If you can't find them just ask a local and they are usually more than happy to help you. To access the mosque you must go through this gate/doorway up a small set of stairs which then open out to the courtyard. Here you will see the facade of the mosque which has several large Iznik tile panels. You can enter the mosque on the left hand side and when you enter, just take your time. The reason why this mosque is the most beautiful mosque in Istanbul is that it is decorated wall to wall in Iznik tiles which creates almost a blue garden of designs. Not only are the tiles amazing but when you look at each of the panels you will see many different designs. These tiles were created during the time when the best quality tiles were being created and so they are superior to the tiles that you will see in other locations such as the Topkapi Palace and Blue Mosque. The tiles not only have the blue colour but they have the lesser used coral colour which had just started to be used when these tiles were created. The mosque is smaller than others in Istanbul but it has a charm to it which I did not find at other grander mosques.The Rüstem Mosque is not widely visited by large tour groups. I spent a large amount of time here for a professional photography shoot and during this time (over half a day) there would have been 3 groups of approximately 15 people each come through. The staff who work here are also very friendly and helpful. Take some time out just to sit in the courtyard and enjoy the atmosphere away from the busy street below. Most people will only spend 1/2 hour here but you could spend longer just looking at the different types of tiles. I was able to view the interior with the lights off and with them on, when the lights are on, it just lights up the whole inside of the mosque which is amazing.If you only have time to visit a couple of mosques in Istanbul this for me would be one I would never hesitate to recommend being on your list.
Very intimate mosque in Bazaar Area. Much less touristy, amazing tilework, very authentic feel. Very close to Galata Bridge in Old City and worth the stop, though less known than the main mosques.

Beautiful and not as crowded as Blue Mosque. This was a beautiful mosque that is not visited as much as the Blue Mosque but it was just as beautiful. You could walk around freely and soak up the atmosphere of it without being crowded.
Amazing. this is glorious and amazing mosque. entrance is free. the best way to see its glory is to took bosphorus cruise and to see it from the sea.

Beautiful tile work, interesting surroundings. Visited this mosque as part of a tour; was very glad it was included as I had not planned to see it otherwise. The blue tiles are actually much more blue than the Blue Mosque! Very interesting to look at, and some fascinating history as part of the "story" of the mosque.

small but impressive. It's not easy to find this small mosque cause it's hided in bazaar district but if you have good guide like we (Oguz Arkan) or good map you will find it. Mosque is beautiful because of it's colorful tiles. There is not so many people like in Blue Mosque so you can enjoyed better.

A jewel. Rustem Pasa feels like a neighborhood mosque more than a tourist destination- we were lucky to be there when there weren't any tour groups. The tiles were breathtaking and thanks to the Trip Advisor forums we found the entrance no problem!
Nice mosque. This was a very nice mosque with ornate tiles. We visited today and ti wa a very nice visit -- some really nice views and a nice insight to a 'regular' not touristy mosque.

stunning. i had been trying to find this mosque since 2006 { yip, should have asked a guide } but it`s more fun exploring this city at your own pace and finally more or less by accident i found it not far from the spice bazaar but it was worth the wait to find,it is stunning the atmosphere and the decor inside is truly remarkable, i am not per sey a building buff but this was great
Ok. This mosque is a little dark and confined for our tastes. You are unable to take any photos here, too.

The real "blue" mosque. This is the most beautiful mosque we visited in Istanbul. The interior blue İznik tiles is just astonishing, giving a giant contrast to the small scale building size and crowded Hasırcılar Çarşısı shopping streets. Again, another great and sensational work by Mimar Sinan.

Small, tranquil Mosque in a bustling marketplace. This was a small mosque very near the covered bazaar. It had beautiful tile and was very peaceful. Designed by the famous Turkish architect, Mimar Sinan, it sets on the slope of a hill in a bustling marketplace and offers a tranquil break to a weary tourist. The tile are exquisite and the outside terrace is lovely. If you are at all interested in the work of Sinan, it is a must see.

Very pretty. This mosque is noted for its beautiful tiles and it was beautiful. However, in Istanbul, beautiful tiles are everywhere. And we had just come from Jordan, where mosaic tiles were everywhere. So, I must say, that although the mosque was lovely, I would not forgo the more famous Blue Mosque or the Sophia to see this site.
Great place . İ was here last week , And i had 10 days holiday , i seen here on the map And look so nice And people was so friendly , nice wive And nice weathr

Follow the stairs..... First floor Mosque in the Middle of Old Bazar, we went on Sunday it was peaceful.
Intereting courtyard.
A masterpiece designed by Sinan the Magnificent. The mosque was completed in 1563. It has the most exquisite and extensive iznik tile decoration of any mosque in Istanbul.
Beautiful and less visited mosque. A small mosque, but stunningly decorated and intimate. THis is quieter and less visited mosque than some of the others
Beautiful Mosque. This was our favorite mosque to visit during our trip. It is above the market and not easily identifiable on its own but well worth the search. The tiles are extraordinary.

A little cute mosque in Istanbul. Located right behind the spice bazaar in Eminonu District, this mosque is very cute and beautiful both the designs inside, and the architectural view from the outside.

Another beautiful mosque of Istanbul. This mosque is rather small but very beautiful! It's all covered with blue tiles inside, therefore I suppose it is very nice to visit during the summer time. However, the mosque is a bit tricky to find: there is no square or space around it, it's all surrounded by the market but if you look carefully, you will see the signs leading to the mosque.

Small but beautiful. Different to the other mosques, it has many beautiful iznik tiles on the walls. The entrance is via a sort of hidden staircase and then you will enter on a balcony, in the middle of the bazar neighborhood. Don't miss this one!
Pretty. A pretty mosque in a quaint location - enjoyed my visit :) It was a nice look around and the area is busy with local life which I enjoyed observing.

Treasure hidden in the souq. Rustemi Pasha Mosque is hard to be noticed in the hustle and bustle of spice market and might disappear if compared to the bigger Yeni Mosque. But if you dare to climb the stairs to the first floor, you'll be very surprised to discover this little mosque with its cozy terrace... a true paradise if you wish to excape the crowd for a while!

Beautiful mosque near the Egyptian market.. The tiles and the setting are amazing. The space in front of the mosque is beautiful. I liked the architecture the balance of spaces and the fact that it is a relatively small mosque. The architect is Mimar Sinan who did also the Suleimaniye Mosque. Definitely worth visiting both, Rustem Pasha is a small jewel Suleimaniye is comparable to the greatest European cathedrals, both have great architectural value, an excellent balance of spaces and masses.

Gorgeous little mosque. Beautiful smaller mosque. The whole inside is covered with intricate tiling. I live in the Middle East, and this is one of my favorites that I have seen. Note that you must leave strollers outside.
Gorgeous tiles. This mosque is worth it for the beautiful tilework--and you can see it up close. Other mosques have blue tiles but they can only be seen at a distance.

Gorgeous little mosque. Everyone should visit one of the little mosques. This one, with its beautiful tiles, is one of Sinan's masterpieces. It's close to the spice market and combines well with a coffee at Hafiz Mustafa. I would visit in the morning, when the area is buzzing.

Favorite mosque in Istanbul. This small mosque was my favorite of all after a week's visit to Istanbul. The inside is cozy and completely covered in mainly blue and white ceramic tiles. Beautiful place, very quiet, apparently not seen by many tourists. (I was alone in there for 20 minutes!)
A beautiful little jewel. The tile work inside this small mosque is stunning. It's still a treasured religious site so plan your visit in respect for that.
Amazing place!. This small mosque was, for me, the most beautiful I've seen, but then I might be slightly prejudiced because blue is my favourite colour! The tiles here are just mind boggling!

An overlooked jewel. This mosque is easily missed and takes some time to find the entrance to besides the spice market area. But it is worth the effort. The beautiful blue tiles it is decorated with and the quit welcoming atmosphere is a nice break for the hustle bustle of the surrounding area. Pls. Note I was there in December and perhaps that is why I was the only one I the mosque.

My favourite Mosque. I visited a fair few mosques in Istanbul (including the Blue & Suleymaniye Mosques) and I think this is my favourite, partly because it was quieter than the others and also this one seemed to have an air about it - it felt ancient & the decorations on the walls, I admired them more. It's right in the heart of the bazaar, so finding it may prove difficult, but definitely worth the visit.

Very nice, but I preferred others. I went here on the recommendation of tripadvisor, and while it was very nice I preferred Blue Mosque and Suleymaniye Mosque, both of which are bigger, better maintained, and in my opinion more awe inspiring. That said this mosque is less touristed if you want to feel a bit more local flavor.

Don't miss this gem!. I saw 6 mosques in Istanbul, and this was the most beautiful. It's small, tucked away in an alley near the spice market. You don't notice it until you're there but once inside, are you in for a treat. The proportions are just right. It feels light, almost delicate. The tile work features various designs as usual but here, they complement each other beautifully. You feel the architect's loving attention in every little detail. Frankly, I don't know if it can get better than this. I certainly didn't see I.Tip: if you see this and then visit the Blue Mosque, you will be stunned at how messy and garish the Blue Mosque feels. The contrast is really quite fun to experience.

Quiet, serene mosque with few tourists & amazing tiling. This mosque is definitely worthy of anyone's attention. Away from the tourist trail, it is nestled within the busy market surrounding it and can be a little difficult to find the small entrance, but once inside, you'll find a peaceful and quiet place of worship with amazing tile work and few or no tourists. It is a very different experience to the Sultan Ahmet mosque, which is a magnet for huge crowds of tourists. This is an interesting and worthwhile find and the market around it is where the locals do their day to day shopping, which is also worth some exploration time.

Most beautiful mosque in Istanbul. To my point of view, this mosque of Sinan is the most interesting structure in the entire Golden Horne area, actually even in the entire city.Everything is blue. The tiles are so elegant. The mosque which is near of the Spice Bazaar looks simple from outside, but if you enter, you will find a hidden gem. My favorite mosque in Istanbul. Don't miss it!

Small, precious beauty!. Rüstem Pasha Mosque always enchants me with its most beautiful tiles and carved woodwork (doors).Don't miss this mosque, you don't need to see all the big ones - but this one, really I mean it, go there for a quiet, beautiful, enriching visit.To get there: take the right turn inside spice bazaar and just follow the narrow street through the souk, until you see the minaret on the right! (Actually it is also very near to "La Maison d'Alep" which is just around the corner - read my review for it here on TripAdvisor, too)
A trouvaille above the bazaar. When you fint this mosque it is fantastic: The whole mosque is decorated with blue Iznik tiles. This mosque is really blue!

both a fine mosque and a Iznik museum. this is the finest collection of Iznik tiles. When these tiles were designed and fabricated, they were the highest quality in the world. A wonderful variety and combinations which can be viewed both up close and as an ensemble.

Hidden gem. Beautiful little mosque, tucked away but very easily accessible. Right next to the spice bazaar, near the New Mosque. Quiet as less known about I guess. Stunning colours, lovely souvenirs for sale at very reasonable prices. Recommended for all. Free entry.

Much better than some other famous mosques. Very difficult to find as all entrances are withing the area of Bazaar and not really visible. However, once found, you enter into small but very charming mosque, pretty and calm.

Unknown treasure in the city.... If you are in Istanbul and visited the Spice Market, I would suggest you pay a short visit to one of the most beautiful mosques in the city, Rustem Pasha Mosque. The Mosque was built in 16.century by the most important Ottoman architect, Sinan for Grand Vizier Rustem Pasha on a terrace over a complex of shops, whose rents were intended to financially support the complex. The Mosque is famous for its fantastic tiles from Iznik with floral and geometric designs and chosen as the most beautiful historical mosque in Europe by Newsweek Magazine in 2008.

Impressive!. It was the first mosque that we visited and because it was included in our Istanbul Eats tour. There was only a few people when we got there, so we got to enjoy the place in silence. The Iznic tiles were really impressive!

Pretty and quiet Mosque, more tiles than the blue mosque. This is a beautiful small mosque near the bridge over the golden horn. It was very peaceful and quiet amongst the bustle of a local bazaar. It has an interesting history and is covered with beautiful blue tiles. Even the outside of the mosque has tiles.

An easily missed gem. Rustem Pasha was not, by all accounts, a pleasant man but the Mosque that was built in his honour is a little gem. Take the effort to search out the staircases to its terrace and marvel at the tiled interior which make it one of the most deorated in the City.

Took ages to find it. And, when I did finally see it I couldn't believe that I'd missed it as it stands out by being so high, just up from the River.
Lovely tiles and so peaceful.

A little gem in a fascinating neighborhood. We walked here from the Great Mosque on a Saturday - didn't see the warnings until later. It was great fun but if you are claustrophobic, try to see this Mosque on another day! It has a different layout to others and is much quieter and peaceful. The tiles are beautiful and when you come out, you can snack your way down the street stopping for pide, deli items and lacoum - and that is before you get to the spice bazaar!

Visit this and the Spice Market at the same time. Located above the Egyptian or Spice Market in Sultanahmet (district Eminonu) this mosque, is known for its outstanding tile. Using many different designs of blue and white with touches of red, the tiled walls of this mosque gives it a different feel from many of the others. It is a little gem.

Lost and found :). We were lost in the spice bazaar trying to find the Suleymaniye mosque, when one of the shopkeepers whom we asked for directions suggested that we also stop by Rustem Pasha mosque that happens to be right in front of his shop :)We wouldn't have ever guessed that there's a mosque in this place, the entrance is really easy to miss.He told us that this mosque is pretty different than all the other mosques because of the tiles used to decorate it. And he was right, it is quite small compared to the others , but definitely different, even the atmosphere inside was different, and the tiles were so beautiful.Don't wait till you get lost in the spice market to visit this mosque, plan ahead, and go !!

One of my favourite sites in Istanbul;gorgeous tiles. I enjoyed my visit here much more than my visit to the more famous Blue Mosque.It is on a smaller scale and there are fewer visitors.We arrived just after reopening after the lunchtime closure.The tiles are gorgeous and , unlike the Blue Mosque you can get right up close to admire them.As with other mosques,ladies remember to take a head covering like a scarf and dress modestly although they do have loan items for this purpose.

Authentic sight. This is a mosque very close or even within the spice bazaar. If you go to Süleymaniye first, consider walking from there to the spice bazaar. Before getting into the oofed part of th spice bazaar, keep your eyes open for the entrance and then walk up the stairs from the caotic bazaar streets and into a peaceful court. The praying area is nice, but what really hits you is its location among the busy bazaar streets

Neat little mosque. It's kind of hidden near the spice market but if you go on line you can find out how to get in. You will need a head cover and you have to remove your shoes, it's a smaller mosque but bluer than the blue mosque inside.

Rustem Pashsa Mosque. The tiles in this small mosque are spectacular. While it is a functioning Mosque, it is also a "tile museum." It is easy to reach from the spice market, down a few narrow market streets. The openings to the mosque can be hard to find as they are stairwells up off the street. You can see the minaret from the spice market so just follow that general direction.

Beautiful Mosque. We visited this mosque in the bazaar district and loved the beautiful Iznik tiles that decorate its interior. Rustem Pasha was an Ottoman statesman who served as the grand vizier of sultan Suleiman the Magnificent. He married one of the sultan's daughters. He collected vast wealth and used it to build this beautiful mosque that is overshadowed buy the larger Suleymaniye Mosque. The mosque was designed by Mimar Sinan the imperial Ottoman architect and erected between 1561 and 1563. It is well worth the time to visit this beautiful structure, and enjoy the peaceful serenity that is offered there. Be sure to pick up a small free copy of the Quaran before you enter.

How to get to this little gem. You leave the egyptian basar at the south western corner and take the long straight road lined with shops on both sides. Just before the 4th street on the right there is a small entrance (on the south western corner of the mosque).You will have to climb some narrow stairs, follow the usual rules (properly dressed, barefoot inside) and will find an amazing display of ornaments on tiles in (seemingly) all different colours and patterns you can think of.Not too big and nothing spectacular in terms of architecture (the close by sülemaniye mosque is much more impressive) this is just a hidden gem. And btw, on the way I described you walk along the shops where the turkish people actually buy stuff, some good deals to be made there.

a little gem of a mosque. Hard to find, but worth the effort; Iznik tiles are fabulous both inside and out, it's quieter than the Blue mosque and a restful place to be amid the hectic streets of the Spice Bazaar quarter.
Find this little gem. It is a beautiful gem tucked away in the heart of the Bazaar District. A showcase of Iznik tiles. A mosque not to be missed. The entrance is tricky to find but worth the visit.
What tile work!. This small mosque is just west of the Spice Bazaar and should not be missed...even after seeing the tile museum in Konya. The tile work is incredible!
Hidden spot behind Spice Bazaar. A little bit difficult to find this mosque but worth to visit. Regardless of the hustle and bustle of the street, the inside is very calm.

Small but marvellous. The guided tour we took happened to be on a Friday and thus blue mosque was not open for the full day to visitors so our guide decided to take us to the Rustem Pasha Mosque.It is a small mosque tucked away in a crowded street but still worth a visit. It is small and not as crowded as the blue mosque but it has its own charm. It has beautiful architecture with lovely Iznik tiles.Very close to eminonu terminal.
Worth a visit. One of the most beautiful mosques in the city, and well worth the visit. Not as crowded as the Blue Mosque but every bit as moving.

A small architechtural gem. The blue Iznik tiles in the Rustom Pasha Mosque are much more accessible than the Blue Mosque. You can look at it at eye level to your heart's content and take some spectacular pictures too. We went there before the tourist crowd got there and were able to experience the beauty and serenity of the mosque.
marvellous!. this a small mosque built at the end of 16 th century has the magnificent samples of the Ottoman tiles.Really amazed when i got in.must be seen!

Amazing amount of beautiful tiles from Iznik. The mosque is opened to infidels when there is no service inside. Women have to cover their heads with scarfs. You can take as many pictures as you wish. And it is free. You can buy some souvenirs for 3TL as gifts for your friends if you want to support this beautiful mosque.

Gorgeous. Interesting setting, above the fray. Smaller and thus more intimate than the giant mosques, this was an island of peace in an otherwise crazy area (I was suffering Spice Market burnout at the time). If you are in love with the tile work of Istanbul, this place should not be missed. Central location.

Beautiful small mosque in market area (and how to get there). Hard to find, but very nice tiles inside. Best way to get there is off of Uzuncarsi Street coming from the New Mosque-Spice Bazaar area, then look for the red/white Osmanli Kebapcisi food stand. Entrance is just behind it, with a very small sign that reads "Rustempasi Camii". Go up the small stairs to get to the mosque entrance.

Alternative to "Blue Mosque". Rustem Pasha - also known as the "New Mosque" is located just outside one of the major entrances to the Spice Market. Smaller than the Suleymaniye Mosque aka Blue Mosque, this one was made by the same architect and offers a more relaxed experience without all of the lines. Decorated in similar blue tiles and with similar lighting, it certainly gives the feel of the Blue Mosque and can be a more pleasant touring experience.
Beautiful .. Beautiful .. Must Visit. Its one of the amazing ones .. small but Perfect .. must must must visit!Really it's a masterpiece msA!?
Beautiful Tiles. This small mosque near the spice market had priceless tile work and lovely arches. It was beautifully built by the same architect who buildt Suleymaniye Mosque

The right scale for stoic mosque architecture to look well.. Rustem Pasha is one of several mosques designed by the architect of the Blue Mosque. It's dramatically smaller scale makes it the Saint Chapelle of Istanbul. Just slightly off the main path, near the Galata Bridge and Spice market, I'd put it high on my list of Istanbul sights.

Rustem Pasha Mosque. It was quiet and deserted when I visited, as compared to the other mosques. It is very close to Yeni Mosque so worth the trip if you are nearby. The mosque is smaller and covered in blue tiles.
Unique. A very old Mosque close to the Spice Bazaar.Famous for it's colourful tiles that are set in floral design.

Kucuk cami. This Cami is very nice . It is somewhat small but extremely beautiful. It is also surrounded by a market that is not much known by tourists which may be a plus for those who wish to wonder and explore areas that are still anonymous .

eznic tile. its a big musuim. very nice and beautiful tile and its flowers and painting are difrent one by one. a small mosque in spice bazar but very good and if you love history and art must visit there. KAHVA SARAY restaurant behind the mosque is very good and the stuff speak english and happy.

favorite mosque. After visiting the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia, we found this beauty. It's a little tricky to find, but worth the effort. We were the only visitors so it was very quiet and peaceful. The tiles were some of the best and we were able to admire them up close, without crowds. There were also free Qurans and pamphlets on Islam available outside the mosque. This is a must see!
perfect liitle mosque. trapped in the middle of the market - dont loose sight of the dome or you will miss this little treasure.

A respite for the faithful and tourists alike!. We were happy to find this beautiful mosque tucked away in the narrow alleys behind the Misir (Egypt's) Bazar. The mosque is built above street level so you have to take the unassuming stairs to the courtyard above. Once inside you discover a gem of floral decorations on its thousands of Iznic tiles. The mosque is a quiet oasis away from the hubhub of markets below. A respite for the faithful and tourists alike!

Don't overlook this one. After all the huge mosques which often look alike, this much smaller scale one is refreshing. And it has wonderful Isnik tiles that you will not see elsewhere. Easy to reach near the spice bazaar.

Surprise. It's a small mosque above spice and local shops found in a narrow pedestrian street. It's not as impressive as the blue mosque but it has its own uniqueness. It's balcony over looks the shops below.
Beuatiful tiling. Takes a bit of finding but worth the effort. Nothing to look at from the outside but wonderful interior.

Hidden treasure. The trip to this hidden wonder is as interesting as the mosque itself. Winding narrow streets filled with locals, spices, food stalls, kitchen products and everything for the home lead you to this lovely fully functioning mosque. While not on the same scale as the infamous Blue Mosque, the mosaics and prayer rooms are glorious. The fact that its not as popular or touristy as the Blue, makes the experience reverent. The textures, colours and patterns of the tiles and calligraphy reflect a rich heritage. This mosque is not to be missed. .

another beautiful Sinan Mosque. Rustem Pasha Mosque was commissioned by Suleyman’s son in law and built by Sinan. It was completed in 1561 It is located in an old and busy market area. The mosque is known for its beautiful Iznik tiles from the sixteenth century covering entire walls. It is a very special mosque and really lovely inside.for info and photos read http://havefunflysafe.com/2012/11/29/things-i-have-learned-in-istanbul/

beautiful small place of worship. I did not like the fact that the place was hard to find but it was well worth it in the end. I liked the beautiful islamic calligraphy inside the dome.would recommend.
Beautifull place to rest after the local market. You should visit this mosque after your exhausting journey trough the local market. No crowd, and it's one of the most beautiful mosque I've seen.

A hidden gem not to be missed. A small unique Mosque entered through a local market near Suleymanye Mosque. Very few tourists see this so no crowds to worry about and you may even find a bargain in the crowded market outside!
It's pretty but can't compare with other Mosques. Well after seeing larger Mosques like the Blue Mosque ( sultanhamet) this one wasn't that impressive . I would skip it!

An enchanting mosque. The mosque looks amazing from the outside. You have to remove your shoes to enter the mosque. I also had to cover my head before entering the mosque. The interiors were impressive with walls decorated with the beautiful and popular Iznik tiles in pretty floral and geometric patterns. I ran my fingers over the cool tiles and felt the enchanting designs with my hands. A lantern hangs low from the large central dome which has arched windows. The bright light streaming through the windows illuminate the tiles to a brilliant blue color. The courtyard is lined with cute little potted plants that enhance the beauty of the mosque. The architecture is magnificent. The atmosphere is magical and creates a sense of inner peace.

Iznik and Sinan at their best. As I recall this is a Sinan mosque. It's a small tile-encrusted jewel cleverly constructed on the slope between the market and the Golden Horn. Perect proportions. You cannot see better Iznik tiling.

Magnificent Tilework. This Mosque has one of the finest work of blue iznik tile work. There is a free pocket size copy of Koran for those interested in the relegion.As you enter the mosque, it at once brings a feeling of peace with its blue coloured tiles and your eyes get transfixed to each of the walls. Many of the mosques have a pulpit ... maybe the influence of Christianity. This was built by Rustem Pasha, a general, who had married the daughter of Sultan.
Rustem Pasha Mosque. small mosque near back of spice bazaar, really friendly to tourists, they even gave complementary copies of the Koran to visitors.

The Prettiest Mosque in Istanbul. It's only small and hidden away near The Spice market, but this mosque was by far the prettiest I came across.Named after Rustem Pasha, a Balkan General who became known as The Louse of Fortune, after marrying the Sultan's daughter and managing to infest all of his in laws at the wedding with lice. Thankfully the authorities have thoroughly fumigated the place now and it is quite stunning. Most mosques have intricate and exquisite blue tile work, but this is generally accepted as being one of the prime examples.
Another must. If you have more time and like to go to visit mosques this Rustem Pasha mosque will charm you with its exquisites mosaics.

Divine. This small mosque is tucked away amongst the stalls surrounding the Egyptian Bazaar. It has a fantastic collection of Iznik tiles. The mosque is peaceful and you get the chance to view the tiles up close.

a hidden gem. not the easiest to find but worth the hunt. You can see it on the right side if you face the Spice Bazaar with the sea behind you. There are shops underneath the mosque. Look for the stairway & a brass plaque on the wall. The tiling is the best in my opinion. Be prepared to wait if it is prayer time & be respectful i.e. discreet clothing & a head covering for women.

Favourite One!. As my Favourite mosque, Rustem Pasa is really famous with its beautiful Iznik tiles, dating back to 16th, 17th and 18th centuries!And as unique one this is more blue than Blue Mosque... After visiting Spice market, you can walk to the Rustem Pasha Mosque and at the secret enterance you can find steps going up, you can find the beautiful mosque there !

Amazing tile interior. The interior is covered with exquisite Iznik tile work. Absolutely stunning. The entry is somewhat difficult to find, if you don't have a guide ask in the Spice Bazaar. You go through a simple door that doesn't look like it leads to much of anything, and walk around a corner to the front of the mosque. Worth looking for.
A gem. A gem in the middle of the whole sale market. Not to miss..so easy to get there and the wholesale market where you can get souvenirs for half the price you would every where else!

Beautiful mosque...loved the blue tiles!. Much smaller than the Blue Mosque or Suleymaniye.... the Rustem Pasha mosque is equally stunning. It is in the more crowded section of Istanbul...we got to the mosque by simply asking people along the way. When we got to the mosque, we were led inside by a very friendly gentleman...who made sure that we took off our shoes the "right way". He did not speak a word of English....by then we had become champions at gesticulating.As other reviewers pointed out, the beautiful blue tiles and the white dome on the inside make this mosque stand out. I also felt that this mosque was much brighter inside than the Blue Mosque, even without the lights. We got here at around 5 PM...there were only 4-5 other people inside with us...all in all, a beautiful experience.
Don't Miss It. This small stunning mosque in the old city has gorgeous Iznik tiles and is so accessible. It sure is worth the visit. See it and compare to the Blue mosque.

Rustem Pasha Mosque. The Rustem Pasha Mosque was designed by Ottoman imperial architect. The Rustem Pasha Mosque is famous for its large quantities of exquisite Iznik tiles, that’s what differentiates this mosque from the others as No other mosque in Istanbul makes such a lavish use of these tiles. The mosque is quite old as it was built around 1561 until 1563. It’s not as large as the Blue Mosque or the Suleymaniye Mosque; it is nonetheless impressive and welcoming.

,as a mosque,one of my favorites. I wonder why all the tourists are trying to visit Blue Mosque, if you are not in a hurry, you can enjoy spending time in Rustempasa Mosque ,and architecturally much better ( small size mosque)

The Rustem Pasha Mosque. Close by the Grand Bazaar, the Rustem Pasha Mosque offers a space of tranquility in all the busy-ness of the nearby Grand and the Spice Bazaars. It is beautiful, with its Iznik tiles depicting tulips in numerous formats. Not as large as the Blue Mosque or the Suleymaniye Mosque, it is nonetheless impressive and welcoming.

Better than the big touristy mosques. Right next to the spice market, this mosque with a beautiful interior is a great find. Come see this! They were even a bit less strict about attire than the other mosques, as well.
A little jewel. This is a little jewel ensconced one story above a bustling marketplace. Studded with colorful Iznik tiles.
Fantastic ceramics. Small, peaceful and quiet. We were the only visitors and once the staff had finished vacuuming the carpet it was quiet and peaceful - despite being built over a market

Spiritually Beautiful!. We visited this Mosque as part of our tour. Its located near the spice bazaar and across the street from the Bosphourus River. Upon entering this beautiful mosque you can see the painstaking attention to detail in the blue tiles lining the walls and ceilings. An active 16th century Mosque in the center of a busy trading district, the atmosphere inside is tranquil and calming. Its a place of worship and once inside you feel spiritual. A definate must see while in Istanbul!

A work of art!. Stop and see the Rustem Pasha mosque, it is a beautiful work of mosaic art inside. It has more blue than the famous Blue Mosque! Take time to learn the people story behind this mosque and it's relationship to the larger mosque next to it, ( then visit the nearby Egyptian spice bazaar and sail on Bosphorus cruises.)
A jewel. Maybe one of the nicest mosques in Istambul, and still remains quite free of mass tourists. Lovely colours and decorations and semi hidden in a narrow street of the Spice market. Lovely

Beautiful Mosque- not so much on tourist trail, so a little quieter than the major sites. The tlie work on the Rustem Pasha Mosque is amazing. Fantastic colours, and very well preserved. Friendly and helpful staff.Nice selection of postcards of some of the tiles and also a small book about the mosque, available just outside the entrance to the prayer area.Nice touch was a free mini quran in English available for people who want to know more about Islam.

Stunning!. The blue tiles displayed in this mosque were impressive, I actually preferred it over the blue mosque. As a female you must cover your head, but they were lenient about my leggings, unlike the blue mosque where I had to get a skirt to cover them. Entry is free. Favourite mosque in Istanbul. The location hidden behind the spice bazaar away form the hustle and bustle a little gem, an oasis of calm and stunning stunning tiles.

Iznik everywhere!. Rüstem Pasha was very rich, and married the daughter of Süleyman the Magnificent. To prove how great he was, he put expensive Iznik tiles on every inch of the inside walls. Great Interior. The interior design of this mosque was really amazing with the original blue Iznic tiles. I enjoyed visited the mosque and praying there as well.

A blue tiled jewel, next to Galata Bridge. Right next to Galata Bridge is this small gem of a mosque exquisitely decorated with blue Iznik tiles which glow in the light from the windows piercing the upper part of the dome structure. A photographer's dream.

A hidden gem. This mosque is a gem and the only place with blue decors inside. Some say that this is the original blue mosque, This mosque is close to the Spice Bazaar, Galata Bridge and New Mosque. Not easy to get to as you have to go into this alleyway and up these old steps before you reach the mosque. It is a small mosque but quite stunning inside.

The Ultimate Blue Mosque. You walk up these steps in a alleyway and come across this gem of a mosque. It's not a huge mosque but this is probably the ultimate blue mosque with their blue interiors. A nice little mosque. When your giving blue mosque and aya sofya 5s you cannot do the same here. Exquisite!. A newer mosque, built in the mid 1500s. Heh, "newer." Exquisite tile artwork inside. Spiritual men were inside reading from the Koran and chanting/singing. A wonderful start, for experiencing Turkish mosques.

Sweet Mosque Great Tiles. Definitely one of the mosques to see, quieter than others with lovely tiles and charming peaceful atmosphere. Corner of the spice bazaar so a good antidote to the busy shopping going on around you

A fitting monument for a rogue. The mosque is wonderful, with its best of Iznik period tiling, and Sinan design. Small and fascinating. This is a must near the Spice Market. Don't confuse with the New Mosque. The tiles in this small "neighborhood" mosque are exquisite. It is included on most Old City walking tours.

Exceptional mosque not to be missed. This is one of Sinan's masterpieces built to an octagonal plan that was inspired by Justinian's church SS. Sergius and Bacchus, also in Istanbul. The lavish wall decoration in Iznik tiles was inspired by contemporary turbes (mausolea) since this was a commemorative monument, built by Rustem Pasha's widow, Mihrimah, daugter of Suleyman the Magnificent. Rustem's mosque is a significant piece of Ottoman architecture as well as history and well worth a visit. Guidebooks in English and post cards are available at the entrance.

A Gem worth seeing. This small mosque of Rustem Pasha is normally missed out by most tourists, this despite being located only a few meters from the Spice Bazaar. It is a superb example of Ottoman Turkish architecture, creation of the great Ottoman architect Mimar Sinan, building a mosque to an octagonal plan. It was built on the former site of Hacı Halil Mescid with a size measuring only 40 by 40 meters square. The short staircases leading up to the mosque are concealed. Ascending to the open courtyard of the mosque, it feels like stepping into a different world. Sinan seemed to have brought the idea of the garden inside his creation through applied decoration. The marriage of exquisite Iznik faience (colored tiles) and architecture designed to showcase them, is wonderfully harmonious in this Mosque. The tiles, made at the height of Iznik's supremacy, have a good deal of the famous red color that was the envy of other tilemakers (blue, yellow, white and green were easy colors to produce, but red was extraordinarily difficult.) Take note of the kündekâri doors of carved and inlaid wood, and the intricate gilded trim (kalemisi) high on the walls and ceiling in the vestibule. The flowers ornamenting in the tiles of this mosque can be seen in the curling leaves and cloud-bands that characterize the “Saz Style.” Thickets of naturalistic flowering branches complement arrangements of clearly recognizable flora in the Imperial “Four Flowers Style,” which celebrates the rose, tulip, hyacinth and carnation. Rather than be measured in size and grandeur (as compared to the bigger and more famous mosques in Istanbul), the Rüstem Pasha Mosque is an architectural gem with exquisite artistic refinement and for those who like architecture and art, this is a must see.

Exquisite small Mosque. Near to Egyptian Spice Market. Well worth visiting if you want to see a small Mosque with wonderful blue tiles and so much quieter than the Blue mosque. Simple but cheap and friendly restaurant in a vault in the courtyard. Highly recommended.

A MUST SEE FOR THE TILES. This smaller mosque has beautiful blue tiles throughout and is definitely worth the stop. The mosque is tucked away near lots of little alleys and shops and a little difficult to find. It is near the Spice Market. The outer courtyard is elevated above street level and it a quiet place to reflect with free water, free Qaran's and a nice little souvenir stand.
AMAZING TILES!. We found this little mosque by chance. This was the nicest mosque of them all. Not as grand as the others but the tiles were amazing.

A hidden gem. This is a small but marvelous mosque built by Ottoman master architect Sinan. The most beautiful ceramics give it an exquisite beauty and special touch. Any traveller to Istanbul should not miss this hidden gem.

Mosque of Rustem Pasa. The mosque was built on a high terrace over a complex of vaulted shops, whose rents were intended to financially support the mosque complex. Narrow, twisting interior flights of steps in the corners give access to a spacious courtyard. The mosque has a double porch with five domed bays, from which projects a deep and low roof supported by a row of columns.[2]woow very nice place you must visit also vey gift shop for memory shoots I will visit again

Absolutely a hidden gem!. It is not easy to find. I asked around and found a little door, then went upstairs, there it is - quite and beautiful. I was wowed by walls of 16th century blue Iznik tiles. So beautiful!!! After spending time in crowded popular mosques, here you can thoroughly enjoy art without crowds, smell, and noise.

Easy-to-miss tiled gem in the heart of Istanbul. This is one of those places that is easy to pass by if you don't know about it, but is well worth the modest effort of finding. It's near the Spice Market and up some steps. The tiled decorations are exquisite. The scale is nothing like the massive size of Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, or the Mosque of Suleyman the Magnificent. It is more modest, and its tiles aren't perfect, which adds to its charm. Well worth a stop.

So very beautiful. This little mosque is a must see. It is SO beautiful, you won't want to miss it. The walls are almost completely covered with the beautiful Iznik tiles. It's a very special place, kind of tucked away. If you weren't looking for it, you'd probably miss it.

Don't miss this. After the disappointment that was the Blue Mosque (too crowded) this beautiful mosque was a revelation. It was quiet and serene and you could enjoy the spirituality of the surroundings without the endless click of cameras and the loud voices of tour guides and tourists. The tiles are wondrous and you have a chance to view them at your leisure.

Gorgeous!. I am extremely squeamish so having to take my shoes off was a turn off, but oh so worth it! The artistry used to decorate this place considering the restraints imposed by religious beliefs is a testament to the endless resources of human ingenuity. I was very happy I decided to visit this very special place.
The most beautiful tiles!. It's easy to find the Mosque just beyond Galata Bridge. Such beautiful tiles -- leaves the Topkapi tiles in the dust. Definitely worth a visit.
Beautiful Tiles. This small mosque near the Spice Bazaar is definitely worth a visit. The tiles are amazing and you get a closer look than you do atthe Blue Mosque.

Great,but beware of the guy who sells tiles outside the mosque,they're overpriced.. Amazing tilework,and since it was small,a lot more features were easily observable.And no tourists!! A must visit when in Eminou. But beware of the guy who sells tiles outside the mosque,they're overpriced.

A hidden gem. After touring the more famous and well visited mosques, it was a pleasant surprise to visit this small, but very ornate mosque tucked above the Egyptian Spice market. Two different doorways are almost hidden amongst the stalls with short staircases ascending to a terrace in front of the mosque. The tiles are lovely shades of blues, reds, oranges and are ornate patterns. After two small tour groups came and went, we were able to walk around and inspect the artistic work alone, quietly above and awy from the hustle and bustle of the bazaar below.

Amazing tiles. Well worth a visit fot the amazing tiles. The craftmanship is impressive. Remember that the quality of the art declined over the following centuries so at this mosque displays the peak of the art.
Antique beautiful mosque. We enjoyed visiting this mosque which was kept to its original plan. The mosaic work on the walls were great .
hard to find but worth it. Very close to the New Mosque - also worth a visit - but the tiles are wonderful. Less crowded than other places, a little gem, near the Spice Bazaar.

Well worth a visit. A comparatively small building compared to some of the mosques in the city but definitely worth 20 minutes.A little hidden away (you have to go up a set of stairs next to an alleyway) but very peaceful and the tiles are impressive. Also very quiet when we arrived early in the afternoon.Close to the docks where the cruises go from, the 'New' Mosque and the spice bazaar so plenty other things in the area.

Charming surprise. At dinner our American neighbour at the next table told us to be sure to visit Rustem Pasha Mosque. what great advice, not only for the mosque, complete with free Koran if you wish, but also for the busy surrounding streets full of excellent small restaurants and busy tradesmen's workshops. Because of its size this mosque has a charm absent from some of the larger sites. Rich in tiles, it is full of colour, and being less visited, is wonderfully calm.

The best kept secret in Istanbul. My friend and I were on the tram one day and got into conversation with a tour-guide who was kind enough to give us the recommendation to see this mosque which was not initially on our agenda. The next day, after an incredibly long day on our feet in the sweltering sun, my friend and I were pretty much exhausted trying to find this mosque within the windy, curvy streets of Istanbul (we're not brilliant at navigation, clearly). We were so ready to give up, proclaiming that we didn't care if we missed it, that it wasn't on our agenda and that we were all 'mosque'd out' anyway (we visited 5 already that day). But within minutes, one of us would bring it up again. Drat! There is a happy ending to this story though as we finally found it. And it was SO worth it. The tiling was exquisite. It is pretty much the underdog of all mosques in Istanbul. Understatedly and hauntingly beautiful. Definitely a must-visit. Just make sure you know how to find it (it isn't hard..!)
Tucked away. we stumbled on this place when my wife's feet were giving way. Well wortha visit. We took photographs inside and they remoinded us how good the place was.

Grand moaque done in an understated manner. Enormous structure, both outside and inside. A grand house of worship built with understated architecture and interior design, putting the emphasis on the spiritual rather than the material.

A (Too Well) Hidden Gem. This is a small mosque basically on the eastern side of the large plaza next to the New Mosque. It is easily seen from the steps of the New Mosque, but it is not easy to find the Rustem Pasha Mosque's door. The entrance is close to the intersection of Mankeme Sk. and Kutukular Cd. You enter through the small, open-air restaurant named Osmanli Kebapcisi. (Yes, you walk through seven or eight tables.) At the simple entrance to the mosque is a sign which tells you a little bit of the history of the mosque. You go up the stairs and enter the courtyard and then mosque. It is worth finding this mosque because of the beautiful tile work and peace and quiet. This is an oasis, not an ocean.
Beautiful tile work. This mosque was one of our favorites. The mosque is not large but the tile work is magnificent. It is outside the spice bazaar area and is also near Galata Bridge.

" We called it "Eye Candy", the small Turkish St. Chappelle ! Blue and beautiful!. It is in the midst of a busy market narrow street, tiny compared to the rest of the 'camiis" but it is worth seeing as it has own character and is very easy on the eyes.
Tile overload. How many photos of Iznik tiles can you take? This mosque, located up above the Spice Bazaar, has them, floor to ceiling. not crowded, and a free Quran if you want one.

Beautiful iznik tiles. I found this mosque when I was on my way to Spice Bazaar. The mosque is small but the architecture is amazing. It was adorned by the famous Iznik tiles; which was said to be made special for this mosque. There were hundreds of black pigeons at the mosque's courtyard. You could reach the mosque by taking a tram from Sultanahmet to Kabatas, but make sure to stop at Eminonu stop, just before the tram cross the famous Galata Bridge to the Asian side of Istanbul. Hop out from the tram, cross the road and you'll immediately see the small mosque tucked nicely among the other buildings facing the Bhosphorus strait. You'll notice the Spice Bazaar beside the mosque.

Rustem Pasha Mosque. Comparitively a small Mosque to the Blue Mosque but lovely from the inside. There are blue tiles everywhere in the Mosque. Also when you leave they present you with The Holy Quran which is a very nice thing to do.
Go to this Mosque, smaller but incredible. I liked this Mosque as it was not on the large tourist route and it was just so lovely. Time to look around at your own pace without hundreds of people.

Unexpected surprise. One of my lasting memories about Istanbul is this beautiful little gem in the heart of the Spice Market. Right there in the hustle and bustle one can just climb a flight of stairs and go into this small mosque and experience peace and quiet in one of the most beautiful mosques!
Nice little Mosque. This Mosque lies next to spice market. It's worth visiting for the extraordinary Iznik tiles inside and outside.

Wow! Excellent!. This small mosque tucked away a few blocks off a busy street has a very odd entrance, but don't be afraid and go up the stairs and experience this hidden gem. Gorgeous, beautiful tiles await and a smaller size mosque to enjoy. As always, remember your etiquette in being in a mosque pertaining to shoes, quiet behavior, photography (no flash and be respectful of including/excluding people in it), where you walk inside, people praying and of course, remember the obvious; it is a house of worship.

One of the most beautiful mosques in Istanbul. A hidden treasure, full of blue tiles inside.It's in Eminonu, neer the Egyptian Bazar; the entrance it's quite hidden, but it's a beauty.And never crowded!

Good to visit this little gem when you visit the spice market. A little tricky to find as its upstairs but worth a little trip. The blue tiles are gorgeous. It's tranquil - uncrowded. The kind salesman in Barnes and noble in New York Sid we should not miss this little gem and we are grateful to him for recommending.

Off the usual tourist, but very rewarding. Anyone visiting the Spice Market should also see this beautiful mosque. It's a discreet gem, reached up a flight of steps and across a shady courtyard. While lacking the stunning scale and magnificence of the Blue or Suleyman mosques, its more intimate scale, tranquil atmosphere and lovely decoration are highly appealing. Other nice touches are the provision of a water dispenser for visitors and free copies of the Koran translated into English to take away.
Quiet and adorable Mosque. It' s size makes it so special. Near de Egipcian Market. I loved it. The retirement and absorption ambiance makes it a place you must visit.
Probably my favorite mosque. This is a small mosque with a somewhat hidden entrance. Not as monumental as some of the bigger ones but distinctive because it is full of beautiful tiles. Don't miss it.

beautiful mosque. Very beautiful with all the lovely blue Iznik tiles. They were giving free books of the Koran outside - nice idea - and had very good cards which were superb value. I wish I had bought some more.

Skip the huge lines at the Blue Mosque and see this instead. Stunning tile work in compact mosque. There were no lines at all. No feeling of being rushed once inside. Very easy access located across from New Mosque, it does take some resolve to wind your way thru the surrounding market to find the entrance.
A hidden jewel! A must see!. If you are visiting Istanbul, treat yourself to a tour of the Rustem Pasha Mosque. It is amongst the most beautiful places I have ever seen.

A Must-See Mosque. This a beautiful hidden gem, number two on my list behind only the Blue Mosque. It's on a second story above shops in a market area so walk around the wall surrounding the dome until you find the doorway that takes you up the stairs to it. The tile work is incredible! The mosque also had postcards of the tile work for sale and I picked up a free Quran, something I think is a wonderful gift to have available for visitors who wish to understand Islam better. Like all mosques, be sure to take your shoes off in the appropriate place and make sure women's heads are covered with a hood or scarf.

Rustem Pasha Mosque. The place with its own character and face.. I love Rustem Pasa Mosque! It's not so big, but it had one of the most beautiful interiors in Istanbul. It also has its own character and face. I got used to go there alone or with my friends just to have a little break in the middle of the intensive Istanbul life. Usually, I come to Eminonu by tram from Sultanahmet, where I live. Then I just walk about two hundred metres or so by a spacious open square, turn the corner and practically plunge into the old good times of history...I go up the stone stairs and after leaving my shoes outside of the entrance, get in the mosque. I spend some time there in a quiet and peaceful atmosphere, looking around, examining the beauty of its interior. Even I was there for already a dozen of times, I am always impressed by the magic of its blue colours! I admire the Iznik tyles, used in the decoration of the interior and the part of the exterior of this mosque. I see many copies in the city, sold as the souveniers, like the magnets for the refrigerators and I always recognise the pictures, taken from that little mosque, which is not so well known by the ordinary tourists, spending most of their time in Sultanahmet or Istiklal...If you are looking for something special, please take your time and come along here to see the beauty, hidden from the crowds...

Awesome. This little mosque requires a bit of effort to find, but is so worth that effort. It is on the upper floor of some shops near the Spice Market. The tiles are exquisite, the best we saw and the guardian was very friendly and helpful.

More blue then the Blue Mosque. This mosque is an undiscovered treasure. FREE to visit and absolutely lovely. Small in scale, but more blue Iznac tiles then the famed Blue Mosque. Near the Egyptian bazaar, one level up from street. If you love tiles, this is a must see!

Best tiles in town. Another Sinan masterpiece inlaid with thousands of the finest quality Iznik tiles. The interior is lovely. Closed during prayers for about 30 minutes but worth the wait if you go. Free copies of the Quran outside in paperback. I had never read it.
Dont miss it. It's hard to find but worth it when you get there. Small and intimate with magnificent tiles. Makes a change from the better known larger mosques

Less visited but well worth seeing. The tiles inside and outside of this mosque are as good as the guidebooks say. It is a neighbourhood mosque with a totally different atmosphere to the major tourist attraction of the Blue Mosque and worth visiting for that reason too.

what a beautiful mosque. This mosque looks very ordinary and drab from the outside, but once you are through the door - wow! It is covered in the most amazing ceramic tiles and it rivals the Blue mosque for interior beauty. The entrance was difficult to find, but is off the main Ragip Gumuspala cd road through a doorway and up some stairs

Small and beautiful inside. This is a very small mosque but with beautiful tiles inside. We had to leave our shoes outside, women had to cover their heads and they didn't let us in wearing leggings since they could distract men praying (even though there weren't any). However, they lent us some scarfs and long skirts to cover ourselves. You don't need much time to visit it and it isn't very crowded.
nice hidden mosque. when we found it we liked the natural feel and the few tourists in the place. you can borrow scarf if you forget to bring your own.

A must-see if you love colour and beauty. This is a intriguing place! So pretty. So small and intimate. Beautiful abstracted tulip (the flower of Turkey where they originate) tiles. A must see especially while at the Spice Market. Interesting market stalls around the mosque for the locals. A bit of everyday Turkish life. Buy a few souvenirs from the lovely man outside - this helps support the mosque.

Rustem Pasha Mosque. This mosque is an ottoman imperial mosque designed by no other than the imperial architect Mimar Sinan for the Grand Vizier Rustem Pasha (husband of Princess Mihrimah). Located right at the beginning of the Uzuncarsi street (local markets that winds up to the spice bazaar) in Tahtakale Mahallesi.The mosque is constructed on a terrace with several shops under it. Entrance to the mosque is from both ends through narrow winding stairs that leads to the courtyard where there are about 5 domes supported by columns.The mosque is famous for its exquisite iznik tiles inside and out. It's smaller than some of the best works of Sinan but this stands out for reason that it's probaly the only mosque in Istanbul with so many beautiful iznik tiles decorating the whole interior and exterior of the mosque.

A place to clean the soul and feel the quiet. This mosque had a quiet fine athmosphere, especially after the horrible spice market chaos. I do not recommend the spice bazaar, but I highly recommend the beautiful mosque with the blue tiling inside and outside, a sacral feel to it and a wonderful safe place to recharge energy and calm in a noisy city.This part of the city, Eminou district, had many offers of boat cruises, but the choice of the Mosque was something we did not regret.Warning,from local people we spoke to: Do not eat at restaurants close to the spice market. Many people get sick. Also beware of pickpockets, they follow tourists into the market.

My favorite mosque. Not as big or grand as the Blue Mosque or other mosques we visited. I loved the small intimate nature of this mosque. Hidden above the Spice market. The iznik tiles fascinated me. It was quiet and not crowded. Loved it.
Only if you are going to Spice Bazaar. Nothing to shout about. There are other beautiful mosques in Istanbul. Worth stopping only before/ after visiting the Spice Bazaar.
very nice tiles work.. most beautifull tiles work that i have seen ever. we realy liked to visit Rustem pasha mosqe and bazzar which is out of the spice bazzaar and behind the Rustem pasha mosque.

Worth a visit near the spice market. Hidden off an alleyway near the spice market, the mosque's small size is more than compensated by its dizzying array of blue and white decorative Iznik tiles. The fact that the mosque is raised above street level helps to set it apart and above the din of everyday life. Well worth a visit.
Tiles. If you love tiles, this is one of the most unique places to go and see how the tiles of the past surived from so many disasters.

My favorite place in all of Istanbul. It's hard to find, but worth the search. The tiles are unforgetable. Remember to avoid entering a mosque during prayer time, and bring a head cover. There is a great foto book of this mosque's tiles, so bring some cash to purchase it.
Beautiful!. Sinan at his best! A small (as compared to the Blue Mosque & Suleymaniye Mosque) but equally beautiful.

Masterpiece of Iznik ceramics. A small masterpiece of Iznik tiles, a little bit hard to find the entrance but definitely worth seeing it! There is also a free pocket edition of Qur'an as a gift to visitors. Fantastic atmosphere.

Great place and location....nice and quiet.. This is a beautiful little Mosque...not as massive like others, but the tiled interior is stunning. A visit here is a must if you are visiting the spice bazaar. The walk to the mosque from the bazaar is fascinating...we stopped for tea and Pide somewhere along the street and enjoyed just sitting and watching the people in the shops. The entrance to the Mosque was a bit tricky to find...lok for the stone sign on the wall and climb the stairs. Go to Rustem Pasha for a nice quiet visit to a beautiful Mosque.

A little tiled gem. This is my favorite mosque in Istanbul. It is small and intimate, with gorgeous blue Iznik tiles. It is down the hill from the much larger Suleymaniye mosque, and not far from the Spice Market. Use the Rick Steves Istanbul guide to find it.
Small and pretty mosque. Well worth a visit, shops outside the mosque are interesting and also provide an excellent photo opportunity

Don't skip this beautiful, artistic mosque!. After a full day of walking we nearly skipped entering this mosque, because we were so close to the spice bazaar. I am so glad we didn't! The tile work both inside and out is spectacular, and you can practically feel the history breathing out of this place! We took a moment to buy a small 'eye' for a souvenir, knowing that the money goes to the mosque. We also got a small Quran printed in English as a gift for visiting.
Small but nice mosque. Don't miss this small mosque located near the Egyptian bazar. There you can admire magnificient mosaics in a peaceful atmosphere.

Little gem. Hidden upstairs off some alleys by the Spice bazar. Easy enough to find once you see the minerat from teh spice bazar. Amazing Iznik tiles. Also free copies of the Koran in english being given away.

All of the below. Agree with the superlatives expressed by others. The stairs up are not easy to find but we and two locals praying were the only people in there at 2pm! Area around with all the local shops is amazing. We ate in the Namli Pastirmaci - out of back door of spice market toward the Mosque and its 25m on the right. Cheap, very clean and very local.

Fabulous tiles. You should make the effort to see this mosque for the elegance of its architecture and the beauty of its wonderful Iznik tiles. Actually quite easy to find, just go straight through the Spice market and look for the doorway at the end of a row of shops and go up the stairs. You may well have it all to yourselves which is quite a contrast to the scrum in the Blue mosque. Not as big but a lot nicer.

Beautiful. I followed the minaret from the spice market to find this gem. I was in a busy market street when I just happened to see the entrance door and small sign. i.e., the entrance is hard to find, so I would suggest having a map pinpointing entrance with you when you visit. You go up a stairway and come out into the courtyard of the mosque. I went to see the Iznik tiles (see my closeup photos) that cover the interior and was overwhelmed by the feeling of serenity when I entered. No tourist crowds, which made it even better. Beautiful, just beautiful. I must remind ladies to be respectful and cover their heads. The gentleman selling souvenirs outside the door was very kind. The souvenirs were very reasonably priced so I stocked up, knowing I was supporting the upkeep of this beautiful Camii. Be a good traveler and leave a donation.
