Stunning, small, empty, great tiles. The tiles here are stunning. And, because the mosque is small, you can get up close to them. It is a treasure. Very few tourists seem to find it, but Lonely Planet's directions (and a little common sense will get you there. Combine this with the spice market, Eminonu and just plain wandering the streets and it's a great outing.

Really wanted to see this and was not disappointed. The tiling here is as good as anywhere in Istanbul and better than in some of it's bigger Mosques. The craftsmanship was fantastic and the fact that the colours are still so vibrant is testament to the skill of the makers, way back when. Access is awkward enough if mobility is an issue, lots of steps

Small mosque. I did not think this was any where close to comparing to the other mosques that I saw in Istanbul, so I probably would not put this high on my list of places to visit. I would visit Sulymanie and Blue before trying to get into this one.

Beautiful interior. The trip to Rustem Pasha mosque was part of our guided tour. After seeing so many grand mosques and other monuments in Istanbul, this mosque externally doesn’t hold your attention so much but is quite exquisite once you step inside. The mosque has used huge quantities of tiles in its interiors with beautiful floral and other geometric patterns. We were told by our guide that all the tiles were dissimilar in their individual patterns. The mosque was designed by the famous Ottoman architect Sinan for the Grand Vizier Rustem Pasha. The mosque was completed in 1563, two years after the death of Rustem Pasha. Rustem Pasha was of Croatian descent and taken to Constantinople as a child where he eventually became Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Sultanate and died extremely rich.

Not to miss. Not as large as the Blue Mosque but it is incredibly beautiful. It is a bit difficult to find as the entrance is in the middle of crowded market alleys but it is definitely worth a visit.

another spectacular small mosque. The architect Sinan does not miss his design mark , and this small jewel, with Iznik tiles in abundance, is contemplative and peaceful.Tucked in behind a busy street, and a jumble of markets across from Eminonu terminal, give yourself time to meditate, absorb the silence. we were rushed by evening prayers.
peaceful retreat. In the midst of all the bustle, the Rustem Pasha Mosque is a quiet oasis. It is a bit tricky to find, however. The tile-covered walls are very beautiful.
Blue mosque junior. This mosque is similar to the Blue Mosque with all the tiles but just smaller. We actually thought it was the prettier mosque. We're glad we took the time to go in.

I really enjoyed this small Mosque. This is a truly beautiful Mosque. It is small so you don't have the grand feeling as you do in the Blue Mosque and the Suleymaniye Mosque. The Blue tiles are amazing. I think it is great seeing this one in addition to one of the grand ones. You must remove your shoes when visiting and the changing area is exposed to the elements - suggestion, bring an extra pair of socks.

tucked away beauty. we arrived here as a quick side visit on a walking tour, but they were closing for prayer, so we revisited on our own. Beautiful mosque with wonderful Iznik tiles, nestled near the Spice Bazaar.Take some time out to visit this lovely place
Near the spice market rustempasha mosque. Liked the tiles which are uniqueİt was not crowded at allThe creramic tiles wrre excellent and better than the Blue mosque

hidden jewel. We heard about this small mosque from the giude, and although we were looking for it, we had trouble finding it, because it is hidden among streets around Spice Bazaar. But even the search itself was worth the effort, just wandering around little streets. It's not that touristy, so long pants or skirts are a must, as well as covering your head (but don't worry there are scarfs to borrow). Interior simply charming, don't miss if you are going to Spice Bazaar anyway

the most beautiful ancient mosque of Europe. its truely one of the best decorated mosque of Istanbul. Its much smaller but nicer than Blue Mosque which is another popular Ottoman mosque with tiles. Thanks to Mimar Sinan the architect, you can visit this less touristic mosque for seeing the very beautiful tiles of Ottoman-Turkish tiles.

most beautiful small mosque. The Rustem Pasha is hard to find. It is in the middle of the Spice Bizaar, shortly after men's underware and electrical supplies; if you come to an immense area of wooden spoons, you know you have gone too far. If you end up in small animals and everything you need for a pet, start over. There is a small stairwell up to an open square, above the spice market. Then you enter the most beautiful, restful, spiritual space. Takes your breath away.

Ok--But There are More Impressive Mosques in Istanbul. The Blue tiles are beautiful, but compared to Suleymaniye and the Blue Moque, this one just feels a bit disappointing. It's probably worth a quick stop if you're not going out of your way to see it, though.
Small and simply beautiful. Very colourful inside. Offered a short prayer and felt extremely good. Learnt about the history behind the mosque. Well worth visiting.

A Hidden Mosque. It was the first mosque we saw in our trip, but I can tell you that even before seeing the Blue Mosque, it was a truly surprise because of its walls decoration on Iznic tiles, all in different scales of blue. That´s what make this tiny mosque special and different form the others. There are not too much tourists in this attraction, so it´s very relaxed to come into it. It is also situated in a calm handcraft quarter near the Egyptian bazaar that you can visit afterwards.

Finest example of Iznik tiles. The Rüsten Pasha Mosque is one of the hidden treasures of Istanbul. We went to this mosque on a free tour given by our hotel, the Sirkeci Konak, and after seeing this one, the Blue Mosque paled on the interior tile work. This is a somewhat hidden but must see mosque.
iznik tiles. if you want to sea iznik tiles, made quartz stone you have to go visit to the Rustem Pasa mosque. its a amazing mosque,

A gem. This is my absolute favorite among Istanbul's many wonderful mosques, for the reason that it has the most beautiful blue and turquoise Iznik tiles that can be seen anywhere. It is small, and located near the Egyptian bazaar. However, the entrance may be difficult to find, as the mosque is situated above street level (you have to walk up one flight of stairs).
An Average Mosque. This was like a bonus during the tour to Topakapi Palace. good Mosque but not comparable with Sultan Ahmet's Blue Mosque.

Beautiful tiles. The Rustem Pasha Mosque is in the lively area of the Spice Bazaar and what makes it different from the other mosques in Istanbul is that you have to climb a winding staircase to get to the actual Mosque. With your back to the Bosphorus it is on the right hand side of the Spice Bazaar. The tiles and tilework on the inside and outside of the Mosque is really exceptional and beautiful.

Little Mosque, big beauty. Just finding this mosque is fun and when you finally get there you will see what a lovely gem it is. I think its worth a visit if you have the time and make sure you explore the surrounding area too, it very lively.

A hidden gem. I went with a someone that had been there before as it is not too simple to track down but if you like the amazing tiles that are everywhere in Istanbul this is the must see place - smaller than the majority and exquisite.
Another gem in Istanbul. This is one of my most favourite places to visit in Istanbul. The tiles are beautiful and there is such a large variety of tiles. It is also a very peaceful place.

The cutest mosque in Istanbul. I know that all mosques in Istanbul looks like the same, but this one in special is very cute and cozy. Being there brings some peace (only if it's not full of tourists).

Over-run with tourists. No one else on the streets but tourists. The tram runs right through it, so staying in other neighborhoods off the tourist path made it easy to hop the tram and get into Sultanhamet. Prices are higher here for shopping. An historic area, but not very authentic.

Nice discovery out of the blue. Following previous comments (TRPADV), we visited the Rustem Pasah Mosque in the last day of our stay in Istanbul. Location is fantastic, the monument is very well kept and (it was a Friday) with the necessary respect for those doing the prayers, the visit was actually worthy.
Just one other mosque. All the mosques are about the same. So, after viewing several of them, they become boring. The only one I would recommend to visit is Hagia Sofiya.

one of the truly amazing things to do in Istanbul. Forget the Blue Mosque. This mosque is the real deal. Tucked into the Spice Market, finding it is a bit tricky. But it's worth it. Felt an amazing sense of calm here. Just beautiful. And shopping all around it, how can you go wrong?
Beautiful Mosque. The tiles are absolutely stunning. On par with El Alcazar in Seville. As a destination it works very well since spending time on the Galata Bridge and Eminonu is a great combo.
Hard to find but well worth it. Gorgeous tiles. The coziness of this site is a positive contrast to huge mosques. The entrance is tucked away and hard to find.

When it rains in Istambul. Close to the spice market is the very blue (even blue-er than the Blue Mosque). This is a neighborhood mosque (one tower only) and not an imperial mosque, so it is smaller and more intimate. Worth a short visit.
Amazing Jewel. The mosaics in this beautiful mosque should not be missed. Rick Steve's calls it the San Chapelle of Istanbul, and he's spot on with that description!

A little gem tucked away beside the spice Market. If you like tiles, this is an outstanding display of some unique tiles. The whole interior is tiled. Easy to get to by tram or walking but not easy to find. Located up some stairs. you can visit New mosque and spice market in same visit.
A gem. Hidden away, quiet and peaceful it was a great contrast to other sites and gave a greater sense of the authentic Istanbul. Spectacular tiles, hallowed atmosphere.

A smaller but exquisite mosque. This is another by the genius architect, Sinan who built so many in the Istanbul area, though his crown jewel of mosques is in Edirne, three hours to the northwest of Istanbul. This one is beautifully tiled in blue - one of the more stunning mosques you can visit - one of my favorites. Don't miss it.

A Gem. If one can visit only one mosque, this is the one. It is beautiful. The best Iznik tiles. Every surface is covered in gorgeous floral tiles. A concentrated dose of color but serene and wonderful.
Art > Money. Chief Architect Sinan build this mosque on top of the shops to show people how Rustem Pashas fond of money. Beautiful carpets inside but narrow stairs and entrance.

Wonderful Tiles. Rustem Pasha Mosque is near the Egyptian Market in an area that caters to those in the market for kitchen equipment. It's a small mosque up a hidden stairway with an incredible collection of tiles. If you are near the Egyptian Market or just across the street by the Bosphorus ferries, it's worth a visit.

Not top priority if time is limited. This is an active Mosque open to the public except during prayer time. Interesting and historical Mosque Since this is a smaller Mosque and not located in the midst of the other main sights see the other Mosques first if time is limited.
Hidden jewel. Don't miss this small mosque...it is, in its way, more spectacular than the Blue Mosque--and was created by the teacher of the Blue Mosque's architect.

So beautiful!. This little mosque is tucked away on a side street near the Spice Bazaar - we found the whole area very interesting and more 'real' than the pristine Sultanahmet area. The mosque itself is rightly famous for its beautiful tilework and we enjoyed visiting such a beautiful place which was not crowded or filled with loathsome tour groups. Women have to cover their heads to enter this mosque as a sign of respect.
Hidden Sinan Gem. Small mosque tucked away near Spice Bazaar, absolutely covered in gorgeous Iznik tiles largely covered in colourful Ottoman flower designs.

The most beautiful. I found this small mosque tucked away near a bustling area of Istanbul the most beautiful of the mosques I visited. Sure, I loved the Blue Mosque, but this smaller mosque feels much more special and intimate. Not to be missed. I still wonder why this mosque is not on all the must-see lists. Also, there are some good metals shops nearby that make very good pepper grinders, etc. Much higher quality than those in the Grand Bazaar.

A real gem!. Hidden up some stairs on a back street near the spice bazaar is this mosque.The tiles are beautiful and there is such a variation of them too.Definately worth a visit.Shame about a tour group that came in and ruined the silence and the tour guide who clearly hadn't bothered to tell the ladies to cover their hair as a mark of respect!

Hidden treasure. Really worth seeking out, though a bit obscure. Tile mosaics are to die for. What a sleeper! It is located above a floor of shops that were intended to pay for its upkeep. Feels like a real working mosque, not a tourist attraction, even though it does have some of the best tilework to be found in Istanbul.

Gorgeous mosque. Tourists know to go to Sultanahmet Mosque (aka The Blue Mosque), but this little mosque is off the beaten path and well worth seeking out. It's much more intimate and subdued - and the blue interior is every bit as beautiful as the Blue Mosque.

A hidden gem. Based on some reviews on this site and in my guide book, I decide to check out the Rustem Pasha mosque on my recent trip. I'm glad I did as it was my favorite of all the mosques I visited. It is located right at the end of the bazaar section close to the Spice Bazaar so it's not out of the way. The tiles were captivating. The go all the way to the floor so you can see them up close and are surrounded by them instead of having to look up at them. I highly recommend visiting this mosque.
Hard to find, but worth it. Smaller & more intimate than the Suliman or Blue Mosque, great tile work. Harder to find but you should see it.

My favourite Mosque!. This is a small mosque with beautiful blue, green and red tiling all over the walls and ceiling. Because it is small, it has a more intimate feeling when you're inside, different than the massive size of the Blue mosque.

One of many mosques worth a visit. Close to the Spice Market, this mosque is worth a visit. There are almost 4,000 mosques in Istanbul so you can't see them all, but this is one to visit if you are nearby. Women must dress appropriately and wear a head scarf which is provided upon entrance. Men do not wear shorts.
Intimate. Much less crowded, more intimate mosque that was just beautiful. Same type of tiles you see in the more famous ones. Very pretty.

A riot of Iznik tiles. A little tricky to find, up a level above the street, but well worth it. Fantastic tiles but not as beautiful as the Blue Mosque, Sokollu Mosque, and out next to the city walls, perhaps the best, the Mihrimah Sultan II Mosque, a true gem of Sinan's.

A Hidden Gem. Away from the crowds and off the beaten tourist trek is this exquisite mosque, almost entirely covered with Iznik tiles. It is a bit difficult to find but well worth the effort. The day we visited there was only another couple of tourists there, it was quiet and peaceful with the light coming in through vine covered windows. There are also some interesting shops in the areas surrounding it, with prices way below the Grand Bazaar.

Hidden away behind the Spice Market. I visited this mosque based on our guidebook but otherwise would have totally missed it. It is a small but excellent example of the blue tile-work (as you can also see at the 'Blue Mosque'), but you need to go down the street beside the Spice Bazaar to find the entrance (up some stairs to the raised landing).Worth a visit if you like a more intimate and quiet view of Ottoman architecture without the crowds at the Blue Mosque. Actually quite close if you are already in that area.

Beautiful, worthwhile visit. This mosque is a little gem hidden right by the Spice (or Egyptian) Bazaar. Once you locate the steps leading up to it, which yes, are a little hidden, suddenly you find yourself facing a serene, yet intricate, facade of decadent tile work. Once inside, the tiles continue all around and you are transported back in time. It is a smaller mosque than most of the very well known ones, such as the Blue mosque or the Suleiman mosque, but you should be just as excited and eager to see this gem as you would any other.
Best Kept Secret. Middle of the bazaar (not the Grand Bazaar) and hard to find but well worth it. Quiet and quite beautiful.

Beautiful tile work in under visited mosque!. Rustem Pasha Mosque may not be on everyone's to-visit list, but it should be. Hidden away near the Spice Bazaar, Rustem Pasha Mosque has some of the most exquisite tile work you will see in Istanbul.

Historic tiles. This is a beautiful, old mosque with exquisite blue tiles. Women need to cover their heads and their legs, so if you don't want to use a loaner scarf and skirt from the mosque, come prepared.
A little gem. A small mosque near the Bosphorus which is a little difficult to find but a little jewel with beautiful tile work.

A pleasant visit to one of the quieter mosques. Not that easy to find but much quieter than the more touristy mosques in the historic area. You can collect free copies of the Koran outside in several different languages too.

The most 'inimate' mosque to visit. Yes, it is smaller, much smaller, than many other mosques, but that is its charm. There is a far greater percentage of the interior covered by magnificent Iznik tile work here than it the 'Blue Mosque' and the resulting 'blue' impression is more notable. Plus you can stand right up close to that art and examine the fascinating detail. If you are at the Spice market, take the time to go here.And I agree, it is tricky to find. I had to ask instructions and point at a map. It is close to the main road along the edge of the Golden Horn waterway, at the bottom of a road called Makheme Sk on the northern fringe of the bazaar area, immediately off the western corner of the large open square opposite the south end of the Galata bridge. In this narrow enclosed street, facing the direction of the water (you can't see it), there is an arch in the wall to your right and a small sign announcing Rustem Pasa Camii. Go up these stairs.If it is lunch time when you leave, return to the street, turn left, and a few metres along on the right you will find a lady making gözleme on an iron dome (like an inverted plough share), the pancake-like thin pizzas from Turkey - an ideal light snack. A cheese gözleme should cost 5TL or less.

A smaller mosque by the famed architext Sinan. This quiet peaceful mosque near the Spice Bazaar is a great place to experience the genius of Sinan's architecture away from the large crowds. It's peacfeul and you can take your time here. Worth a visit when going to the nearby Spice Bazaar.

First you have to find your way in.. It took us a while to discover the entrance having started from the Spice Market, but climb the narrow staircase and the Mosque is a delightfully tranquil place, full of light and covered with exquisite blue tiles. Take off shoes and women borrow an attractive turquoise headscarf before entering.

Every tile has its own story. My great love of Istanbul took me to the hills of Uskudar (Anatolian part of Istanbul) to visit this unique mosque. Even if I had a map, I was still asking to local people how to reach this place. So, I recommend taking map and also remembering how to ask the place for this mosque: "Rustem Pasha Jamii'ye nasil gidebilirim" (how can I go to Rustem Pasha Mosque). I was so happy finally reaching this place. It is small, but elegantly built mosque with every single tile telling you something. Beautiful Mihrap inside wants you to look at it more and more. It really worth of spending some of your time finding this beautiful place.

Don't miss this little mosque!. This mosque is smaller than the more famous mosques around Sultanahmet. To make up for it's lack of grandeur it has some of the best examples of Iznik mosaics, is much quieter and more peaceful, and has fewer tourists. It is also within the neighborhood of the spice bazaar.
under rated. This is a small mosque tucked away by the Spice Bazaar. Beautiful tiles (many original) and not so many tourists. Definitely worth the visit.
beautiful mosque. Our tour guide took us to this mosque,which is very impressive, Appreciates the mosaic tiles inside the mosque. Worth visiting.
Outstanding. The tile-covered interior of this little mosque is incredibly beautiful and worth the short walk from Sulemaniye Mosque.

(Not too) far from the madding crowd. This is one of the most beautiful mosques designed by the architect Sinan and it is much, much less crowded than the "Blue Mosque", the Hagia Sophia, and Topkapi; one can therefore enjoy a little quiet contemplation of the beautiful Ismik ceramic tiles and the harmonious proportions.
worth the effort. magnificent tiles-the best mosque tiling we've seen in this city. neighboring shops are very colorful

Exquisite mosque. This is a small mosque with a slightly hidden approach up some stairs from the street (Hasircilar Caddesi). It is exquisitely beautiful inside with very fine blue tiles and in many ways is more inspiring than the more famous (and much bigger) Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmed Mosque).

could have stayed for ever. This was tricky to find but I am so glad we did. The decoration was exquisite, the colours so fresh it was hard to believe they are so ancient. While we were there several people came briefly in to take photos and move on; this seemed somewhat disrespectful to us, we prefered to sit and take in the atmosphere, the beauty and the tranquility, just above the bustle of life going on below us. We could have stayed forever and left feeling refreshed and inspired.

The titles. I'm not sure I need to say any more, they were spectacular. This became one of my favorite stops during my trip. You need to remember the mosque is above the bazaar, as in 1st floor in case you csn't find it.

Small gem by great architect Sinan. I love going to less-known places in Istanbul where one can avoid the crowds. Rustem Pasha is a favorite. A real working mosque in a real neighborhood. Well worth the walk down from Sultanahmet.
wow. All the mosques in turkey are beautifull, The work that has been done in the mosques speaks for itself when you visit. very down to earth people. Islam is the fastest growing religion!

A fantastic mosque. It is really a beautiful mosque that is decorated by nice arabic calligraghy of the ottoman empire. It is colourful and looks cheerful from inside. It is one of the most impressive islamic art in Istanbul.The Egyptian bazaar ( spice bazaar ) is few steps nearby. You can easily reach the mosque by the tram ( Eminonu stop ) .

A smaller gem of a mosque. For those interested in visiting the major mosques of Istanbul, Rustem Pasa is a must see. Its charms are manifest, and it tends to receive far less tourism than the more well-know mosques. It possesses an architectural integrity and sense of peace not as evident in its more famous rivals.

the mosque i liked the most. Rustem Pasha mosque is a small one compared to other mosques in Istanbul but it's absolutely unique and beautiful. it still holds its original handmade tiles, which are colored with all different shades of blue prints and they look marvelous as if they were just installed yesterday. on the entrance they have copies of the Quraan translated into English, which are free for visitors to take. i actually liked it more than the famously known Blue Mosque
A delightful place. This had a lovely atmosphere, much less busy than the Blue Mosque with the most beautiful tiles. It felt more like a place of worship than the anonymous large Mosques.

Quite a finding. We searched for it but couldnt find the entrance so asked a turkish person, he was very helpful and took us to the entrance... you climb the stairs and reach this hidden jewel... Very blue from inside and worth the search! It is inside Spice bazar, easily accessible from the eminonu tram station.
Often overlooked, but go!. The best example of Iznik tiles in Istanbul. A bit challenging to find the entrance, but worth going.
An operating Mosque of charm. Smaller and more intimate than the Blue Mosque. Hidden away yet, once found, the tiles are a revalation
Fabulous tiles. A bit hard to find as it is up a little alley but the beautiful tiles are worth the effort. And it was not crowded as so many other Istanbul mosques are.
My first mosque visit in Istanbul. It is not as big as the other Mosques, but has a lot of character, much quieter and lot less tourists. Good shopping nearby as well.

still a favorite mosque. OK, so I've gone there 4 times over the past two trips. It is a little gem and you get to look at the lovely tiles close up, the way you can't in the Blue Mosque. It is quiet (you might be the only one in it) and in an interesting part of town. And the tiles covering the walls make you feel as if you are inside a small gem.

The best. If you only have limited time then go to see this mosque. You are able to get up close to the beautiful blue tiles which this mosque is famous for. It is smaller and more intimate and a better experience as the tiles seem to enclose the space more completely.
Beautiful Iznik tiles. Definitely worth a visit - very close to the Spice Bazaar, and well worth the trip to see the beautiful tile work.

One of the prettiest mosques in Istanbul. This is the prettiest mosques we visited in Istanbul. The tile work is stunning. It is near the Spice market and where the boats leave for the Bosporous Strait cruise. I would highly recommend you visit this mosque if you are in the area.
beautiful tiles. it is a little mosque near by spice market. it has the most beautiful iznik tiles, make sure you see it.
The best mosque. My husband actually visited this mosque each day that we were in Istanbul. The tile is beautiful and the location most interesting!!!
Small and Peaceful. This mosque is a very small mosque, which I suppose makes it so peaceful. It is not overcrowded with tons of people. It has a very rich history.

"Blue Mosque". This mosque is tucked into the spice bazaar. Although there is only a small sign to indicate the mosque, watch for it as it is definitely worth the effort. The tile work and the painting makes this mosque the one to see. As all of the tile are predominantley blue painted, I would call this mosque the "Blue Mosque"!

Perfect setting. The setting is brilliant, hidden away in a busy bazaar you might almost miss it. Th e mosque is small but has an amazing history and is covered with fascinating tiles that date back centuries. It is also a nice quiet place to relax.
Beautiful and uncrowded. Spectacular Iznik tiles cover the mosque inside and out. Pleasant to visit and photograph with few people there, even in August.

Lesser Known Mosque but famous for its Stunning Iznik Tiles. A gem amongst the mosques of the Sultanahmet! Here you will see the very best of Isnik tiles with stunningly beautiful geometric and floral designs. The mosque, itself, dates back to the 16th century and was designed by the Ottoman Imperial architect, Mimar Sinan. If you feel like visiting only one mosque, while you are in Istanbul, this is the one I would choose.When I visited in May of 2010, I had the place to myself, a far cry from the hordes at the Blue Mosque!

The Real Blue Mosque. This beautiful mosque is off the beaten path and is close to the Spice Market, making it a more intimate setting with less crowds. The blue tiles are very numerous, and feature traditional Turkish flowers such as the tulip, and are centuries old. In many ways, I thought that this mosque was more blue and more beautiful than the "Blue Mosque."
The real blue mosque. Amazing blue iznik tile work covers the entire inside of this small mosque located near the Spice market. rustem Pasa is well worth a side trip.

small but exquisite. yes the blue mosque (lots of queues), Suleymaniye mosque are bigger and more money spent on renovations but this one is inimate, and has the equisite izmir tiles nearly everywhere- something that the other mosques dont have in the same quanity. Most of them are over 4 centuries old with tulips, roses, carnations, and hyacinth. sit and enjoy the atmosphere. go early if you can.

Divine. If you are into Turkish tiles, this is the mosque for you !Honeysuckle, hyacinths and pomegranates grace the walls of this mosque from a time when Iznik tiles were at their best.The architect was the great man himself, Sinan.
our favorite istanbul mosque. Since it is smaller than many of the mosques in Istanbul, it's intimacy gives you a wonderful chance to appreciate it's beauty and meaning. The tile work is amazing
One more mosque?. If you have seen the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia, you will find this a bit of an anti climax. LOTS of hand painted blue tiles, but not much else frankly!

More beautiful than Blue Mosque. Build by Mimar Sinan, the most famous Turkish architect (mimar meaning architect in Turkish), Rüstem Paşa Mosque is my favorite.The thing is, it is a bit hard to find it, which gives you more hope to find it. Also, the entrance is just a "hole" in a stoned wall and you have to climb stairs. What I really like, is that the street is really busy and when you arrive in the tiny yard/terrace of the Mosque, with the trees, it is really peaceful and quiet.The mosque itself is more blue then Blue Mosque because of the Iznik mosaics.Not so far from Spice Bazaar, you can reach the mosque by tram, from the Eminönü station.
Old tiles in old Istanbul. This little mosque, right on the side of the charming Egyptian Market of Istanbul, is worth a visit. Its old tiles reflect the best technique in tile manufacturing.

Don't Overlook this Mosque. This was my favorite mosque visit. Fewer crowds, it was quieter that the better known mosques; smaller, more intimate with a sense of the sacred. And the Iznik tiles are exquisite.
Beautiful blue iznik tiles. Beautiful mosque, not too large and can see everything easily. The tiles are gorgeous
Absolutely Gorgeous. not as overwhelming or as crowded as the big mosques, very beautiful, worth looking for
most beautiful iznik tiles. cheap great postcards and downstairs there's tahtakale for food and about anything else you might need cheap
Very beautiful, but don't forget a scarf!. Visited with my tour group. The wall tiles are absolutely gorgeous. Be prepared with socks and scarf, or you will have bare feet and a loaner head covering.
Small but Huge!. This perhaps is the most beautiful mosque in Istanbul. The Isnik tiled walls make it really unique. Worth the visit 100%
Great & amazing mosque. Great & amazing mosque .You need at least 1 to 2 hours to cover it all .
Visit if you have the time. A smaller mosque than others we visited, but beautiful blue tiles inside. One of our guides recommended this mosque. Does not disappoint.

Rustem Pasha Mosque. This is even more impressive in its own way than the Blue Mosque because it is entirely covered inside with blue tiles. It is a true gem and an absolute Must See. It's surrounded by the Spice Bazaar and the entrance is a bit hard to find but just ask someone. We were led to the door. It's just lovely!
nice mosque great good. the mosque is nice but the neighborhood around it is excellent for eating some real local street food
Worth visiting...Don't miss!. Perfect decoration of Iznic tiles...The mosque is very close to Misir Carsi and represents one of the most elegant religious buildings of islamic art!

Small but beautiful. A small, lovely moque tucked away in near Spice Bazaar. Quite hard to find the entrance. Closed briefly during prayer times. Beautiful tiles inside and out and a tiny shop to buy cards.

beautiful little mosque. We enjoyed visiting this small mosque that feels out of the way even though it is very close to the Egyptian bazaar. It has a nice, quiet court yard and beautiful decoration inside.
Old and architectures. Another old mosques, the walls are still remain as it is.
A magical little mosque with incredible Iznik tilework!. While a little difficult to find, this mosque near the Spice Market is an amazing gem of tilework. Don't miss it!

Stands proud within easy walking distance of the city spice bazaar. Built during the Ottoman Empire, the Rustem Pasa Mosque showcases the best Ottoman architecture & exquisite Iznik tiles, which cover the walls, columns & the facade of its porch, and are considered some of the most exquisite of their kind in the world. Compared to some of the other mosques in the city, which are colossal and have a breathtaking architecture you can take in from afar, the Rustem Pasa Mosque is hidden behind the shops around the Spice Bazaar. So finding it can take a bit of searching, but it really is worth it. The interior has a stillness, beauty & calm that offers respite from the clamour of the markets outside its walls. A man sat in quiet contemplation & I felt a bit guilty watching him pray yet interested at the same time. It was the cosiest and possibly the most lavish mosque I saw in Istanbul.

A pilgrimage site for me very time I visit Istanbul. I am not Muslim, but this is a must stop for me on each trip to Istanbul. Exquisite Iznik tile work and serene atmosphere make this place a calm oasis in the middle of the Spice (Egyptian) market. Never ever get tired of seeing this lovely space.
most amazing tiles. Iznik tiles as you won't see them anywhere else. Worth a visit. Does not take too much time out of your trip, but great feast for the eyes.

A mosque different then others. This mosques small compare Suleymaniye and Blue musque but it is so special with it's different stairway entrance and beautiful blue tiles from 16 Century.
Because of it is among the hidden streets of Istanbul it is quieter and more peacefull.
a jewel of a mosque. My favorite mosque - better than the blue mosque. The tiles are mind-blowing. Smaller and less touristy than the others.

Rustme Pasha Mosque. It is little gem, my favourite mosque in Istanbul in terms of internal decorations. It is a small mosque beautifully decorated internally with the best Iznik tiles we have seen anywhere. It`s right next to the Spice Bazaar.
There is small gift stand outside with a good selection of gifts all to do with tiles.
You can skip it if your time is limited. It is a nice place but maybe I wasn't very impressed because we have similar mosques in Egypt.

Intimate. Rustem Pasha is not the easiest mosque to find.
It is located inan interesting array of small shops in narrow alleyways.
The mosque itself is small and intimate, beautiful architecture.
Recommended for those with intest in Islam or Islamic architecture
Nice blue mosaic tiles inside!. Don't let the small size of this mosque fool you, it has very beautiful blue mosaic tiles inside. It is near the grand Sulemnaye Mosque, so look for it.

small mosque, great art (iznik tiles). A small mosque hidden somewhere near the spice bazaar. Climb some stairs and we will find it. Beautiful Isnik tiles inside all over the walls with amazing blue and red colors. Not to miss.

Gorgeous Iznik tiles. Wandering the market, this could be easily missed but it's worth the stop. Duck in under the low doorway and go up the stairs to the courtyard. Great place for photos - the walls of this small mosque are covered in some great examples of Iznik tiles. The mosque is like a little pool of serenity above the hustle and bustle of the market - from the courtyard, you can peek over the walls to watch the market in action from above. It's a quick stop but it's free and well worth it.
Blue Mosque. Wonderful architecture and mosaic work close to the spice bazar

Small but Exquisite. There is no better place in Istanbul to see the artistry of the Ottoman ceramic tile makers in Iznik, Turkey. The tiles, done in many different patters and colors, are spectacular and very accessible to the visitor. This is a place you must visit in Sultanahmet.

Most unique. This is the most beautiful mosque in Istanbul. The blue of the mosaics is rich and delightful. Some of the detail work is the best I've seen. It's close to the Spice Market which is a real must-better than the Grand Bizarre.

Beautiful ceramic tiles in an inspiring context. Not to be missed! Although not as large as some of the mosques in this incredible city, this one is arguably the most beautiful. It is much bluer than the Blue mosque because the walls and columns are covered with amazing Iznik blue tiles of a great variety of designs. The overall effect is really moving. The detailed designs are a pure delight and one can spend a long time just exploring them. The architect Sinan, who built so much in 16th century Istanbul has surely created one of the world's masterpieces. For a memory of your visit, the excellent book available outside the mosque 'Rustem Pasha Mosque and Iznik Tiles' is strongly recommended.
best tiles. It was made for Rustem pasha which is located closer to spice market and new mosque. And it has the best tiles; better than Blue Mosque

Impressive. A small mosque with beautiful blue mosaics. The entrance, located in a street with lots of small shops, can be a bit hard to find! For the ladies: don't forget to bring something to cover your hair.
A lovely small mosque near the Spice Market. The ceramic tiles are gorgeous in this Sinan-designed small mosque. It's close to the Spice Market in Eminonu so easy to visit.

Tiny Gem of a mosque with exquisite blue tiles. This mosque is more impressive than the Blue Mosque as its proportions are so balanced and the beauty and serenity is more enjoyable as there are few tourists... its difficult to find....
Beautiful small mosque. This is a beautiful small mosque with lovely tiles and we actually thought more stunning than the much more hyped Blue Mosque
A lot to admire. Definitely worth a visit. Lovely tiles, great architecture. Respect the fact that it is a functioning mosque !
Very beautiful. Small and beautiful mosque. The Imman greeted us and was very nice. It is located near the Bazar de las Especias.

Tiles more beautiful than Blue Mosque. The tiles inside this small mosque took my breath away. We stayed here for a long time enjoying their beauty, and it was nice to have only a few people around rather than the big crowd at the Blue Mosque.
Too much hype created for this. its just like any other mosque. Infact people there do not even know about it.
Very nice, and a bit different. Another mosque by the great architect Sinan but with a much different feel due to the extensive use of interesting tiles.
hard to find!. but fun and well worth the sleuthing efforts to locate -- my favorite mosque in istanbul.

A hidden gem. Near the spice bazaar, a little difficult to find, but well worth it. It has beautiful tiles and they are easier to see and admire than the ones in the Blue Mosque because it is much smaller.

Very tranquil, spiritual and beautiful mosque. Hidden Jewel! Do not miss. Famous for the Mosaic. Don't go there in hurry, take some time out to marvel the beauty of small mosque and take in the spiritual atmosphere.
Famed for it's tiles. Sinan's favorite design, covered in Iznik tiles, beautiful beyond belief.

Hidden gem. You have to find this mosque. It is amazing, all walls are covered in iznik blue tiles, and it has such a charming atmosphere. It is a bit tricky to find - but local shop owners are very helpful, so don't hesitate to ask for directions!
worth a visit. a lovely gem of a mosque hidden away in the backstreets. The climb up the steps is not suitable for those with mobility problems, but the museum really is worth the climb
Dont miss this mosque. Small but perfectly formed! Superb 16th century Iznik tiles. A haven of peace very close to the Spice Market.
A very old mosque. It's a very old mosque right next to the Egyptiona spice Pazar. A small one though
Our favorite mosque in all Turkey!. This little gem is worth going out of your way (and it is a bit hard to find), but go inside to see the pretty Iznik tiles.
Worth it.... Just outside the Spice Bazaar, an absolute MUST visit, and don't forget to poke into all the streets that surround this place!
iznik tiles. if you're a fan of iznik tiles, then this is the mosque for you. beautiful.
small gem. A quiet spot near crowded area. Builded not to impress with size but with beauty.
Beautiful interior.. Much quieter than most of the other tourist attractions. That makes it a good place to go visit. Very beautiful inside.

Top pick. If you only have time for one mosque, then this is it. It may be heresy to say so, but I would give the Blue Mosque a miss and discover this one instead. And discover is the right word, for one wends there way through back streets off of the Spice Market to find it. It is rarely crowded and the tiles are much better than in the Blue Mosque.

An absolute gem not to be missed. You don't have to be a tile freak to be knocked out by the gorgeous Rustem Pasha Mosque, although it helps. It is small and quiet (after the crowds at the Blue Mosque and Haghia Sophia) and you can get up close to the detail and enjoy the peace. It is also near the boat tours boarding point and the Egyptian Spice Bazaar so easy to fit in to a busy schedule. Just lovely!
Beautiful tiles. This is a beautiful, small mosque. The main feature are the tiles. It doesn't take too long to visit. There aren't many people there, so you can look around more freely.
Beautiful intimate mosque. Tucked away in the side streets beyond the spice market it has a lovely intimacy and is the blue mosque in miniature, with a nicer feel.
Worth the hunt. It's a little difficult to find, but just look for the smaller domes just up from Eminonu and then walk towards it through the alleys. A bastion of peach, and beautiful tiles.
Sinan's jewel, spectacular tiled walls.. A short walk from the Spice Market, this is Sinan's jewel, spectacular tiled walls.

Rustem Pasha Mosque. This is the gem of Istanbul, the tile work is spectacular and the
size is wonderful, a tiny little mosque loved it. Plus it's close to the
spice market and makes a good walk from the bridge.
A special place. intimate and unostentatious, this small centrally located mosque is well worth a visit
hidden gem. Turn rught out of the spice market to find this lovely little mosque, vitied by few tourists
Beautiful!. Beautiful smaller, older mosque with intricate tile work worth seeing!
Small and an easy visit. It is one of the smaller mosques but the tile work is fabulous. If you are in the vicinity for the spice market, take out 10 minutes or so to enjoy this beauty.
Nice mosque. This mosque is one of the most beautiful in Istanbul. It is one floor higher than the street and you can easily miss it if you do not pay attention at signs.

A Place Apart in Time. Find your way through the Spice Bazaar to enclosed stairs that lead up to the Mosque. Spectacular Iznik tiles, but for me the best part was the ancient marble ablution area, settled and worn smooth with use and time. Wonderful sense of peace and place, with the tumult of the market just outside.

Favorite mosque in Istanbul. This is the mosque to go to in Istanbul! It's small, personal and the decorations are to die for.Almost every inch of the interior and some of the exterior are covered in beautiful tiles. Just sit down in the back and enjoy! Can be a bit hard to find the entrance cause it's just a small opening in the alleys but just ask some shop owner and they will help you.
Glorious tiles. It's really worth tracking this place down. It has the most glorious tiles and a wonderful atomsphere.
An early mosque. A genuine ancient mosque kept in fine condition. Some fine hand-made tiles on the walls.

Breathtaking!. We stumbled upon this mosque at prayer time as my husband and I wanted to make the noon prayer. a kind stranger helped us up all the many many steps picking our pusc chair up single handed. once upstairs we were astonished. the mosque was amazing and a real gem. the Imam recited beautifully. some of the tile work was amazing.

A surprise. This is probably one of the major surprises you will have visiting this little Mosque, but one of the most intimate ambience. The most important legacy from the great architect Mimar Sinan for Vizier Damat Rustem Pasha (husband of one of the daughters of Suleiman the Magnificient)
Beautiful design. Nice architecture and also historical. Very well preserved

Little Gem. The Rustem Pasha mosque is a block from the Spice Market. It is a spectacular marvel of Iznik tiles. To fully appreciate it, go here before you go to Topkapi Palace. This is a quiet mosque, but it is absolutely stunning.

Looks like most other mosques...nothing special.. We Katie's this mosque becauseitwas described as the Saint Chappelle of Istanbul...nothing close. It was a small mosque,and it was fine..just not nothing really special like we were led to believe.
Great surprise. Small but fabulous mosque. My wife and I probably enjoyed this site as much or more than the Blue Mosque. Smaller, much more intimate and fantastic tile work!
Beautiful gem.. Don't miss this small one. Our favorite. Close to the spice market for a nice afternoon.
lovely little gem. If you look closely at mosaics of all the mosques you will find that this mosque has different tiles and they are lovely looking.Easily acessible from Eminounu docks.
very good tiles. I went This mosgue and liked so much cause no touristic and noone try to sell you tours or carpet

Hidden Away in The Spice Market. A beatuiful mosque, with an abundance of decorative mosaic tiles. Very few visitors during the week and only a handful of locals praying early in the morning and at lunchtime, so no worries about being herded around. An oasis of calm and tranquility. Well worth a visit.

Rustem Pasha Mosque. Excellent examples of fine craft works in the tiles, ceiling, floors, a quiet spot in the busy city, could have stayed all day just looking around. Shopping in that district is also very interesting, better than the touristy bazaar.

Under-rated Must-see Mosque.. We preferred this mosque to several others in Istanbul. The blue tiles of tulips are wonderful. Being smaller makes the experience more intimate. We are happy we explored this one.
Rustem Pasha. A reverent place. Empty when we were there. Loved the Isnik tiles.

Hidden treasure. We walked past the mosque 4 times before we realised where the entrance was! There are no signs, just a dark staircase beside stalls lining the Spice Market so after asking a local we managed to find it! As it was the first mosque we actually visited in Istanbul i thought it was stunning inside, decorated with tile work and original doors etc. Its worth a visit and you probably only need about 30 mins as its not a very large mosque.

An intriguing Mosque, An Intriguing Story. The mosque itself is out of this world with visual appeal. Given to a young heir to a Sultan by his mother on his 16th birthday, the mosque is tucked away in the area of the Spice Bazaar or Misir Carsisi. One must walk down several crowded alleys to get to the stairs which take you up to the mosque itself. The treck is well worth it. Built around the 16 century, the tiles are original Iznik blue tiles set on the walls of a very small interior. When one enters, not only does one see the beauty that surrounds the eye, one is also filled with a quiet tranquility from the busy streets and alleys below. This is a "must see" for visitors to Istanbul.

Don't Miss This Little Mosque. Perched on the second floor near the Spice Bazaar this little working mosque is a bit tricky to find. I generally look for the minaret, but if you are having difficulties you can ask anyone and receive immediate directions.I love the Iznik tile work in this mosque. I think it is even better than the Blue Mosque. Although located in the heart of the tourist district I rarely see other tourists there. I do see lots of Turkish people worshiping at this mosque. If you are visiting the Spice Bazaar or catching a ferry at Eminonu or walking across the Galata Bridge you should take an extra 30 minutes to see this exquisite little mosque.Because this is much more house of worship than tourist attraction, visitors should dress appropriately. Shoulders and legs should be covered and women should wear a scarf or head covering.

Small very old mosque. This is a tiny but ancient mosque near the Egyptian spice bazaar. You usually will only see it if you go on a tour, which makes that worthwhile. It's much darker than the larger mosques, but the again the tiles are awe inspiring.

a moving experience. We were the only people there on the day which allowed us to wonder around at will. Inexpensive and beautiful book marks and other tourist gifts were sold outside. We were given a free Quaran which was very touching.

Worth seeing, but not incredibly unique. We saw this as part of a walking tour, and while the story behind its construction is interesting, I'm not sure that we had the knowledge of Islamic tile work to fully appreciate the beauty of this mosque.

Small but beautiful!. Not too far from the Spice Bazaar, you must wander into the Rustem Pasa Camii. It reminds me of a miniature version of the Blue Mosque with its hundreds of hand-pained blue Iznik tiles. Beautiful!

My absolute favorite. Great hidden gem; the best time is to go between prayers and if not with large family sit in a corner for few minutes and you feel the calmness in the heart of city with a strong pulse.

Beautiful Blue Mosaics. Its a smaller version of the blue mosque but it was built before the blue mosque was built. So technically, its where the idea came from. Its entirely blue! I loved it, couldnt stop snapping pictures of the mosaics

Small hidden jewel of Istanbul. The one of my favs in Istanbul. Small, full of iznik tiles, quiet and simply beautiful.
Even if it's not so easy to find the entrance among narrow crowdy bazaar streets but certainly must visit object.

A lesser known jewel. A turkish friend said we must see and I am very glad we did. It's hard to find as it's on the second floor in a crowded area around the Spice Market. If you map doesn't show it, ask someone. The Turks want you to have a wonderful time in their country.

The tiles! the tiles!. The tiles of the Rustem Pasha Mosque are like nothing you will see on earth. This little mosque is a gem. Don't miss it! I am re-tiling the backsplash of my kitchen after being here...

Prefer Mehmet Pasha instead. Rustam Pasha Mosuqe is a small, not so crowdy mosque of a Grand Vizier named Rustam Pasha. Yes it is serene but I did not find anything exquisite or worth visiting here.In case you are tired of oh so crowded places, go to mehmet pasha mosque instead. It is similar to Rusta Pasha wrt crowds.Only a few minutes walk from Blue mosque, Mehmet Pasha is much more important. This is the only building outside Kaaba,Mecca which has the black stone. I am not sure why is this not highlighted anywhere.We got the fact from a local istanbul guide book in our hotel.Rustam Pasha Not a must visit from my point of view.

Rustem Pasha Mosque. This place is an oasis of peace in the middle of the bazaar, when I was here it was just me and the guy looking after the shoes outside, not another soul around. Outside in the courtyard is also a nice place to sit for a quick breather. The mosque is gorgeous but when you've already seen Sulemanye, Aya Sophya and the Blue Mosque, these are hard to top.
Provides some Perspective. A mosque that allowed me to compare the GRAND mosques with a small 16th century mosque with great tiles.Very close to the Spice (egyptian) market so a nice combo visit.

Small, Hidden Gem. Rustem Pasha is hard to find, but worth the effort. It is a small, ancient mosque hidden around the corner from the Spice Market. The Iznik tiles found in the Rustem Pasha are among the best in Istanbul. It's on a small side street adjacent to the Spice Market, and you'll have to really look to find the entrance. If you have trouble finding it, as a local policeman. And when you exit, treat yourself to a doner kebab sandwich at the stand by the entrance. It was the best sandwich we found in all of Istanbul.
excellent. Best tiles of any of the big mosques...more intimate atmosphere - not so crowded

Little gem by the spice bazaar. Beautiful mosque designed by Mimar Sinan with exquisite Iznik tiles inside and outside. Feels very intimate as it is much smaller than other mosques in Sultanahmed. Highly recommend it. Don't forget to bring a head scarf if you are a woman.
must see for mosaic lovers. this is a must see for anyone who loves the turkish mosaics... beautiful tile work
the most beautiful mosque of Istanbul. Small with an amazing tile work, next door to the Egyptian Bazar (the spice market)

A hidden gem worth visiting. If you are wandering through the narrow alleys of the Spice Bazaar (which you undoubtedly will), spare a few moments and seek out the slightly hidden stairwells that lead to the entrance of this mosque. The exterior may not compare to the other grander buildings of Istanbul, but the interior is a mesmerising sea of blue Iznik tiles that is bound to leave you gaping with wonder.
A Hidden Delight. My favorite mosque in the city. Hidden away from the crowds, its small size allows one to get up close and personal with the blue tiles.
Small mosque with lovely tiles. Was our first site that we visited in Istanbul--beautiful colors, low-key attraction to visit--a nice introduction to the MANY mosques in Istanbul.

Another little gem!. Not so easy to find tucked away in a corner near the Spice Market it is worth the effort with its original Iznik tiles of the highest quality - ceramicists will love it. The Blue Mosque may have 21,000plus tiles but it's their quantity which impresses rather than the quality. Arrive in plenty of time before prayer time, as the mosque officials will ask you to leave 30 minutes before in order to clean the mosque; also remember - ladies - a head covering.

A little treasure of Islamic art. This little mosque is just around the corner of the Egyptian Bazar (Spice Bazar).It is smaller than the other ones you may visit but it is a "delight" for eyes: completely pannelled with blue tiles and featuring carved wood ceilings.It is a more intimate view into the Islamic art and religion; by the way they offer you a copy of the "Quran" in English: let's build bridge and get to know each other

Hidden Gem in the Bazaar Quarter. The entrance to this hidden gem is off a busy local shopping area in the Bazaar Quarter near the Spice Market. From a tourist perspective it's quieter here than other, more famous mosques, and frequented by locals at prayer time (try to get here before one of the 5 daily calls to prayer, as you'll be asked to leave at prayer time). The situation (with a 2nd floor courtyard surrounding the gorgeously tiled main hall) is unique and a tiny patch of serenity in a crazy market area. One of the 'sleepers' of our trip (along with the Basilica Cistern). Don't miss it.
Visit this mosque while at the spice bazaar.. A beautiful mosque that is easy to visit compared to the Blue Mosque.
Small but pretty. Instead of the Sultanahmet mosque, I would recommend to go to this small but pretty mosque. Ceramics of Iznik that keeps theri red color for centuries are even touchable.

I'm not a mosque man myself... But i liked this little mosque it had a sensibility to it that made the effort worth while. I might even have sat for a bit and contemplated the universe but I am shy. Make the effort it is worth it after the mammoth blue mosque. if you had to do just one mosque this would be it.

Hard to find, but worth it.. We had a hard time finding this mosque as it is located within the streets surrounding the spice bazaar. We finally asked a gentleman who walked us all the way to the somewhat hard to find doorway. It is much smaller than the Blue Mosque and had a very intimate feel. Hardly anyone was there so we were able to enjoy the experience without the crowd. Beautifully decorated tile. If you are near the spice bazaar, it is definitely worth the effort.
See this one. If you go to the Spice Bazaar do take the time to visit this beautiful, small mosque. The blue tile designs are so beautiful.

The most beautiful set of Izmir tiles in Istanbul.. This cute Mosque, in the bustling area of ​​the Gran Baazar is difficult to locate, but once found, do not underestimate it by its small size and its austere façade (as compared to other monumental mosques). Do not miss it and enjoy its interior adorned with some of the finest Izmir tiles in Istanbul.

An Intimate Gem near the Spice Market. Rustem Pasa mosque is intimate in size, virtually totally decorated in the most beautiful Iznik tiles during the peak of the Iznik production when the tile makers used blues, greens and reds... red was a real breakthrough. The mosque is up one level from street level so look for the staircases up from the busy market streets. It is an intimate gem, designed by the great architect Sinan and just down the hill from the large and magnificent Suleymaniye mosque. The two together make for some inspired viewing.
A gem. This is one of Sinan's minor masterpieces, with lovely Iznik tiles covering much of its exterior walls. A quiet escape from the nearby bazaars.
A little gem mosque. Also less visited - so worthwhile.Tile work beautiful
Blue tiled Mosque. Small, beautiful mosque with decorative blue tiles on all the walls. Definitely worth a visit.

A must see!!. If you want to see quintessential Istanbul style and architecture (as well as some of the most beautiful tile work in the entire world) you should see this jami! It is a little hidden and hard to find, but very worth the effort!

Underrated, but beautiful Mosque. This is a tiny mosque down by the Golden Horn. It is a littledifficult to find and the entrance is kind of hidden behind a vendorstand. Just ask around and someone will help you find it. Take thestairs to the right and go up to the mosque. This is a small mosquewith tens of thousands of blue iznik tiles everywhere. It is verypretty on the inside and worth seeing if you are in the area. Therearen't a lot of visitors here and we only spent about 20 minutes here.I do not think you should go out of your way to see this mosque, butif you are planning to walk by the Golden Horn or go up to theSuleymaniye Mosque, then pay a visit here. The tilework is amazing andthis place is probably underrated.

Beautiful Iznik tiles!. This mosque, located above the chaotic streets below, is noted for its beautiful Iznik tiles. So beautiful that this was the ONLY place in Istanbul that I bought a souvenir. It was quiet and mostly empty mid-afternoon, a welcome respite.

exquisite jewelbox. This mosque was my favorite in Istanbul. It is hidden away from the masses of tourists, it is smaller in scale, and it has the most beautiful blue and patterned tiles everywhere. Unlike the Blue Mosque you can see more of the tiles at close range here which makes it more intimate.Do make sure to read up on how to find it. We blundered around a bit before we found the way in.

Beauty and tranquility. One of the most beautiful Mosques of Istanbul, not crowded with toursists, amazing tile, serene ... a true hidden gem.you can arrange to a visit if you were near the spice bazar ... Istanbul is filled with beautiful mosques, some are not that famous ... this is one of them

The most exquisite small mosque in Istanbul. Given that every street in Istanbul has a handful of mosques, and there are "this way to the X mosque" everywhere, you can't really find this fantastic place unless you are looking for it. Just take the street leading away from the northwestern gate of the Spice Bazaar, three blocks down you'll find the stairs leading up to the courtyard!

Hidden Gem. We visited many mosques on our recent trip to Turkey and this was one of the most beautiful. The entrance is somewhat hidden in one of the passages near the Spice Market and takes a bit of looking to find. The inside is cool and serene and an escape from the frenzy of the Spice Market. The inside is covered with many different patterns of blue tile and is quite spectacular. We enjoyed sitting down in the back and taking it all in. It was not crowded at all on the day we visited.

The most beautiful tiles I ever seen. The Rüstem Pasha Mosque is located in a street near the Spice Market, in Eminönu. It was designed by Ottoman imperial architect Mimar Sinan for Grand Vizier Damat Rüstem Pasha (husband of one of the daughters of Suleiman the Magnificent, Princess Mihrimah). Its building took place from 1561 to 1563. The most interesting point on this site is the Iznik tiles from the early Iznik period (1555-1620). These tiles show a tomato-red color only available in this mosque. The tiles show beautiful floral and geometric designs and cover all the mosque interior as well as the porch façade (in and out). If you're going to the Spice Bazaar, also enjoy this mosque, it is really beautiful.

Contemplative Iznik tile beauty hidden in Istanbul. Make a point of seeing this small, exquisite gem of a mosque hidden from unknowing eyes. The tiles used in creating this gorgeous contemplative space make this mosque a jewelbox of perfection. Slowly take in all of the variety in tile color and design and pinch yourself that you are getting to see the glories of the Ottoman Empire with your visit here. It won't take long to see, but I promise you, your jaw will drop.

Hidden Grandeur. Rüstem Paşa Mosque is almost hidden in an alley near the Spice Market (Egyptian Bazaar) but it has such a grandeur that is should definitely be visited. Rüstem Paşa, both sadrazam (prime minister) and son-in-law of Sultan Suleyman the Maginificient, due to his rank in the society, could not have constructed a big mosque with a big courtyard as the members of the sultan family but yet, this relatively smaller mosque, with the genious architectural skills of famous architect Mimar Sinan, stands today in full grandeur. What's initially striking in this mosque are the tiles that are used to decorate the outside walls of the mosque which is unfamiliar in terms of architectural norms of the time. Inside as well is adorned with beautiful and very precious tiles. It's a breathtaking mosque that must be visited once in Istanbul!

Sinan in full glory. The Rustem Pasha is a wonderful small mosque near the Spice Market. It was designed by the great architect Sinan. It is a must see for the Iznik tiles alone, but it is also a lovely, delecate building. Islamic/Ottoman architecture at its very best. Blue Mosque will awe and the Mosque of Sulliman amaze, the Aya Sophia will leave you with wonder but you will love the Rusem Pasha. It will be one of the special places in Istanbul that you will brag to your friends that you found and that not every other tourist to the city visits.

Small but Special. Compared to some of the other mosques in town, which are huge and have a breathtaking architecture you can take in from afar, the Rustem Pasha Mosque is hidden behind the stores around the Spice Bazaar. So finding it can take a bit of searching, but it really is worth it.The interior was the coziest and possibly the most lavish we saw in Istanbul.
